Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Utah Agricultural Code
======================================================

Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 1 - General Provisions
**************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-101 Title.
------------------------------------
This title is known as the "Utah Agricultural Code."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-102 Construction.
-------------------------------------------
This title shall be liberally construed and applied to promote and carry out its policies and purposes.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-103 Principles of law and equity applicable.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Unless displaced by the particular provisions of this code, the principles of law and equity supplement the provisions of this title.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-104 Procedures -- Adjudicative proceedings.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
The Department of Agriculture and Food and the department's divisions shall comply with

Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105 Code enforcement -- Inspection authorized -- Condemnation or seizure -- Injunctive relief -- Costs awarded -- County or district attorney to represent state -- Criminal actions -- Witness fee.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(1): To enforce a provision in this title, the department may:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(1)(a): enter, at reasonable times, and inspect a public or private premises where an agricultural product is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(1)(b): obtain a sample of an agricultural product at no charge to the department, unless otherwise specified in this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(2): The department may proceed immediately, if admittance is refused, to obtain an ex parte warrant from the nearest court of competent jurisdiction to allow entry to the premises to inspect or obtain a sample.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(3)(a): The department is authorized in a court of competent jurisdiction to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(3)(a)(i): seek an order of seizure or condemnation of an agricultural product that violates this title; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(3)(a)(ii): upon proper grounds, obtain a temporary restraining order or temporary or permanent injunction to prevent violation of this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(3)(b): The court may not require a bond of the department in an injunctive proceeding brought under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(4)(a): If the court orders condemnation, the department shall dispose of the agricultural product as the court directs.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(4)(b): The court may not order condemnation without giving the claimant of the agricultural product an opportunity to apply to the court for permission to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(4)(b)(i): bring the agricultural product into conformance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(4)(b)(ii): remove the agricultural product from the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(5): (3)(a) If the department prevails in an action authorized by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(6): Chapter 3, Utah Dairy Act; Chapter 5, Utah Wholesome Food Act
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(6)(a): Unless otherwise specifically provided by this title, the county attorney of the county in which the product is located or the act is committed shall represent the department in an action commenced under authority of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(6)(b): Chapter 3, Utah Dairy Act; Chapter 5, Utah Wholesome Food Act The attorney general shall represent the department in an action to enforce:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(6)(b)(i): Chapter 3, Utah Dairy Act
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(6)(b)(ii): Chapter 5, Utah Wholesome Food Act
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(7)(a): In a criminal action brought by the department for violation of this title, the county attorney or district attorney in the county in which the alleged criminal activity occurs shall represent the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(7)(b): Before the department pursues a criminal action, the department shall first give to the person the department intends to have charged:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(7)(b)(i): written notice of the department's intent to file criminal charges; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(7)(b)(ii): an opportunity to present, personally or through counsel, the person's views with respect to the contemplated action.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(8): A witness subpoenaed by the department for whatever purpose is entitled to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(8)(a): a witness fee for each day of required attendance at a proceeding initiated by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-105(8)(b): mileage in accordance with the fees and mileage allowed a witness appearing in a district court of this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-106 Suspension or revocation of license or registration -- Judicial review -- Attorney general to represent department.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-106(1): If the department has reason to believe that a licensee or registrant is or has engaged in conduct that violates this title, the department shall issue and serve a notice of agency action.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-106(2): The commissioner, or the hearing officer designated by the commissioner, may suspend or revoke a person's license or registration if the commissioner or hearing officer finds by a preponderance of the evidence that the person is engaging, or has engaged, in conduct that violates this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-106(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-106(3)(a): Any person whose registration or license is suspended or revoked under this section may obtain judicial review.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-106(3)(b): Venue for judicial review of informal adjudicative proceedings is in the district court in the county where the alleged acts giving rise to the suspension or revocation occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-106(4): The attorney general shall represent the department in any original action or appeal commenced under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-107 Fees and late charges.
----------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-107(2): If the renewal of the registration or license is conditioned upon the payment of a renewal fee on or before a specified date, the department shall charge and collect the renewal fee and a late fee on any license or registration that is renewed after the date specified for renewal in the applicable chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-107(3): 4-2-103(2) The renewal fee and late fee shall be determined by the department pursuant to Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-108 Severability clause.
--------------------------------------------------
If any provision of this title, or the application of any provision to any person or circumstance, is held invalid, the invalidity does not affect other provisions or applications of this title that can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of this title are declared to be severable.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-109 General definitions.
--------------------------------------------------
As used in this title:Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-109(1): 4-37-103 "Agricultural product" or "product of agriculture" means any product that is derived from agriculture, including any product derived from aquaculture as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-109(2): "Agriculture" means the science and art of the production of plants and animals useful to man, including the preparation of plants and animals for human use and disposal by marketing or otherwise.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-109(3): "Commissioner" means the commissioner of agriculture and food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-109(4): "Department" means the Department of Agriculture and Food created in Chapter 2, Administration.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-109(5): "Dietary supplement" means the same as that term is defined in the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 301 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-109(6): 4-39-102 "Livestock" means cattle, sheep, goats, swine, horses, mules, poultry, domesticated elk as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-109(7): "Local food" means an agricultural product or livestock that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-109(7)(a): produced, processed, and distributed for sale or consumption within the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-109(7)(b): sold to an end consumer within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-109(8): "Organization" means a corporation, government or governmental subdivision or agency, business trust, estate, trust, partnership, association, two or more persons having a joint or common interest, or any other legal entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-109(9): "Person" means a natural person or individual, corporation, organization, or other legal entity.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110 Growing or storing food for personal or family use.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(1): As used in this section, "family food" means food owned by an individual that is intended for the individual's consumption, or for consumption by members of the individual's immediate family, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(1)(a): is legal for human consumption;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(1)(b): is lawfully possessed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(1)(c): poses no risk:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(1)(c)(i): to health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(1)(c)(ii): of spreading plant pest infestation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(1)(c)(iii): of spreading agricultural disease.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(2): Family food that is grown by an individual on the individual's property is not subject to local or federal regulation if growth of the family food:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(2)(a): does not negatively impact the rights of adjoining property owners; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(2)(b): complies with the food safety requirements of this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(3): (2) A government entity may not confiscate family food described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(4)(a): If any provision of this section or the application of any provision of this section to any person or circumstance is held invalid by a final decision of a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this section shall be given effect without the invalid provision or application.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-110(4)(b): The provisions of this section are severable.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-111 Exemptions from licensure.
--------------------------------------------------------
Except as otherwise provided by statute or rule, the following individuals may engage in the practice of an occupation or profession regulated by this title, subject to the stated circumstances and limitations, without being licensed under this title:Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-111(1): an individual licensed under the laws of this state, other than under this title, to practice or engage in an occupation or profession, while engaged in the lawful, professional, and competent practice of that occupation or profession;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-111(2): an individual serving in the armed forces of the United States, the United States Public Health Service, the United States Department of Veterans Affairs, or any other federal agency while engaged in activities regulated under this title as a part of employment with that federal agency if the individual holds a valid license to practice the regulated occupation or profession issued by any other state or jurisdiction recognized by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-111(3): the spouse of an individual serving in the armed forces of the United States while the individual is stationed within this state, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-111(3)(a): the spouse holds a valid license to practice the regulated occupation or profession issued by any other state or jurisdiction recognized by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-111(3)(b): the license is current and the spouse is in good standing in the state or jurisdiction of licensure.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112 License by endorsement.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(1): As used in this section, "license" means an authorization that permits the holder to engage in the practice of a profession regulated under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(2): Subject to Subsections (4) through (7), the department shall issue a license to an applicant who has been licensed in another state, district, or territory of the United States if:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(2)(a): the department determines that the license issued by the other state, district, or territory encompasses a similar scope of practice as the license sought in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(2)(b): the applicant has at least one year of experience practicing under the license issued in the other state, district, or territory; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(2)(c): the applicant's license is in good standing in the other state, district, or territory.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(3): Subject to Subsections (4) through (7), the department may issue a license to an applicant who:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(3)(a): has been licensed in another state, district, or territory of the United States, or in a jurisdiction outside of the United States, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(3)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(3)(a)(i)(A): the department determines that the applicant's education, experience, and skills demonstrate competency in the profession for which licensure is sought in this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(3)(a)(i)(B): under the license issued in the other state, district, territory, or jurisdiction, the applicant has at least one year of experience or a lesser minimum amount of experience established by the department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(3)(a)(ii): the department determines that the licensure requirements of the other state, district, territory, or jurisdiction at the time the license was issued were substantially similar to the requirements for the license sought in this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(3)(b): has never been licensed in a state, district, or territory of the United States, or in a jurisdiction outside of the United States, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(3)(b)(i): the applicant was educated in or obtained relevant experience in a state, district, or territory of the United States, or a jurisdiction outside of the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(3)(b)(ii): the department determines that the education or experience was substantially similar to the education or experience requirements for the license sought in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(4): The department may refuse to issue a license to an applicant under this section if:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(4)(a): the department determines that there is reasonable cause to believe that the applicant is not qualified to receive the license in this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(4)(b): the applicant has a previous or pending disciplinary action related to the applicant's other license.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(5): 63J-1-504 Before the department issues a license to an applicant under this section, the applicant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(5)(a): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(5)(b): produce satisfactory evidence of the applicant's identity, qualifications, and good standing in the profession for which licensure is sought in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(6): The department may make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, prescribing the administration and requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-1-112(7): This section is subject to and may be supplemented or altered by licensure endorsement provisions or multistate licensure compacts in specific chapters of this title.

**********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-101 Title.
------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Administration."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-102 Department created.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-102(1): There is created within state government the Department of Agriculture and Food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-102(2): (1) The department created in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103 Functions, powers, and duties of department -- Fees for services -- Marketing orders -- Procedure -- Purchasing and auditing.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Chapter 18, Conservation Commission Act; Chapter 46, Conservation Coordination Act; 63G-22-102; Title 63G, Chapter 22, State Training and Certification Requirements; 56-1-12; Title 73, Chapter 3d, Part 4, Compensation The department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(a): inquire into and promote the interests and products of agriculture and allied industries;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(b): promote methods for increasing the production and facilitating the distribution of the agricultural products of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(c)(i): inquire into the cause of contagious, infectious, and communicable diseases among livestock and the means for their prevention and cure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(c)(ii): initiate, implement, and administer plans and programs to prevent the spread of diseases among livestock;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(d): encourage experiments designed to determine the best means and methods for the control of diseases among domestic and wild animals;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(e): issue marketing orders for any designated agricultural product to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(e)(i): promote orderly market conditions for any product;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(e)(ii): give the producer a fair return on the producer's investment at the marketplace; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(e)(iii): only promote and not restrict or restrain the marketing of Utah agricultural commodities;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(f): administer and enforce all laws assigned to the department by the Legislature;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(g): establish standards and grades for agricultural products and fix and collect reasonable fees for services performed by the department in conjunction with the grading of agricultural products;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(h): establish operational standards for any establishment that manufactures, processes, produces, distributes, stores, sells, or offers for sale any agricultural product;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(i): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act adopt, according to
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(j): when necessary, make investigations, subpoena witnesses and records, conduct hearings, issue orders, and make recommendations concerning matters related to agriculture;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(k): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(k)(i): inspect any nursery, orchard, farm, garden, park, cemetery, greenhouse, or any private or public place that may become infested or infected with harmful insects, plant diseases, noxious or poisonous weeds, or other agricultural pests;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(k)(ii): establish and enforce quarantines;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(k)(iii): issue and enforce orders and rules for the control and eradication of pests, wherever they may exist within the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(k)(iv): perform other duties relating to plants and plant products considered advisable and not contrary to law;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(l): inspect apiaries for diseases inimical to bees and beekeeping;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(m): take charge of any agricultural exhibit within the state, if considered necessary by the department, and award premiums at that exhibit;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(n): Chapter 18, Conservation Commission Act; Chapter 46, Conservation Coordination Act provide for the coordination of state conservation efforts, including by:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(n)(i): Chapter 18, Conservation Commission Act assisting the Conservation Commission in the administration of
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(n)(ii): Chapter 46, Conservation Coordination Act implementing
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(n)(iii): administering and disbursing money available to assist conservation districts in the state in the conservation of the state's soil and water resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(o): participate in the United States Department of Agriculture certified agricultural mediation program, in accordance with 7 U.S.C. Sec. 5101 and 7 C.F.R.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(p): promote and support the multiple use of public lands;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(q): 63G-22-102; Title 63G, Chapter 22, State Training and Certification Requirements ensure that any training or certification required of a public official or public employee, as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(q)(i): under this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(q)(ii): by the department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(q)(iii): by an entity within the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(r): 56-1-12 administer the requirements described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(s): Title 73, Chapter 3d, Part 4, Compensation in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(s)(i): conduct mediation or arbitration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(s)(ii): assist in the issuance of loans by the Conservation Commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(1)(t): perform any additional functions, powers, and duties provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(2): 63J-1-504 The department, by following the procedures and requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(3): (1)(e)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(3)(a): (1)(e) A marketing order issued under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(3)(a)(i): the department gives notice of the proposed order to the producers and handlers of the affected product;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(3)(a)(ii): the commissioner conducts a hearing on the proposed order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(3)(a)(iii): at least 50% of the registered producers and handlers of the affected products vote in favor of the proposed order.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(3)(b):

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(5)(b): take necessary steps, including legal action, to recover money or the monetary value of services provided to a recipient who is not eligible;

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-103(5)(e): fund grants using money appropriated by the Legislature or money received from any other source.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-104 Administration by commissioner.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-104(1): Administration of the department is under the direction, control, and management of a commissioner appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-104(2): The commissioner shall serve at the pleasure of the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-104(3): Title 67, Chapter 22, State Officer Compensation The governor shall establish the commissioner's compensation within the salary range fixed by the Legislature in


Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-105 Organization of divisions within department.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
The commissioner shall organize the department into divisions, as necessary, for the efficient administration of the department's business.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-106 Submission of department's budget.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-106(1): The commissioner, upon request of the governor, shall submit an itemized budget for the department to the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-106(2): (1) The proposed budget described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-106(2)(a): contain a complete plan of proposed expenditures and estimated revenues for the ensuing fiscal year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-106(2)(b): be accompanied by a statement setting forth the revenues and expenditures for the fiscal year next preceding and the current assets and liabilities of the department, including restricted revenue accounts and dedicated credits.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-107 Official seal -- Authentication of records.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-107(1): The department shall adopt and use an official seal, a description and impression of which shall be filed with the Division of Archives.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-107(2): Copies of official department records, documents, and proceedings may be authenticated with the seal attested by the commissioner.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108 Agricultural Advisory Board created -- Composition -- Responsibility -- Terms of office -- Compensation -- Executive committee.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1): There is created the Agricultural Advisory Board composed of the following 21 members:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(a): the dean of the College of Agriculture and Applied Science from Utah State University; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b): the following appointed by the commissioner:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(i): two representatives of associations representing interests of farmers, selected from a list of nominees submitted by at least two associations representing farmers;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(ii): a representative of an association representing cattlemen, selected from a list of nominees submitted by at least one association representing cattlemen;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(iii): one representative of an association representing wool growers, selected from a list of nominees submitted by at least one association representing wool growers;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(iv): one representative of an association representing dairies, selected from a list of nominees submitted by at least one association representing dairies;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(v): one representative of an association representing pork producers, selected from a list of nominees submitted by at least one association representing pork producers;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(vi): one representative of egg and poultry producers;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(vii): one representative of an association representing veterinarians, selected from a list of nominees submitted by at least one association representing veterinarians;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(viii): one representative of an association representing livestock auctions, selected from a list of nominees submitted by at least one association representing livestock auctions;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(ix): one representative of an association representing conservation districts, selected from a list of nominees submitted by at least one association representing conservation districts;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(x): one representative of the Utah horse industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(xi): one representative of the food processing industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(xii): one representative of the fruit and vegetable industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(xiii): one representative of the turkey industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(xiv): one representative of manufacturers of food supplements;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(xv): one representative of a consumer affairs group;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(xvi): one representative of urban and small farmers;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(xvii): one representative of an association representing elk breeders, selected from a list of nominees submitted by at least one association representing elk breeders;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(xviii): one representative of an association representing beekeepers, selected from a list of nominees submitted by at least one association representing beekeepers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(1)(b)(xix): one representative of fur breeders, selected from a list of nominees submitted by at least one association representing fur breeders.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(2): The Agricultural Advisory Board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(2)(a): advise the commissioner regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(2)(a)(i): the planning, implementation, and administration of the department's programs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(2)(a)(ii): the establishment of standards governing the care of livestock and poultry, including consideration of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(2)(a)(ii)(A): food safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(2)(a)(ii)(B): local availability and affordability of food; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(2)(a)(ii)(C): acceptable practices for livestock and farm management; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(2)(b): adopt best management practices for sheep, swine, cattle, and poultry industries in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-108(3): The Agricultural Advisory Board may adopt best management practices for domesticated elk, mink, apiaries, and other agricultural industries in the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-201 Appointment of the state chemist.
---------------------------------------------------------------
The commissioner shall appoint a state chemist.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-202 State chemist responsibilities.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-202(1): The state chemist shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-202(1)(a): serve as the chief administrative officer of the Division of Laboratories; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-202(1)(b): supervise and administer all analytical tests required to be performed under this title or under any rule adopted under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-202(2): The state chemist may perform analytical tests for other state agencies, federal agencies, units of local government, and private persons if:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-202(2)(a): the tests and analytical work do not interfere with, or impede, the work required by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-202(2)(b): a charge commensurate with the work involved is made and collected.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-202(3): The state chemist shall perform any other official duties assigned by the commissioner.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203 Department of Agriculture and Food Laboratory Equipment Fund.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(1): There is created an expendable special revenue fund known as the "Department of Agriculture and Food Laboratory Equipment Fund," which is referred to in this section as the "fund."
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(2): The fund consists of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(2)(a): collections the Division of Laboratories within the department receives under this title that are not expended during the previous fiscal year;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(2)(b): appropriations from the Legislature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(2)(c): interest and earnings on the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(3): Title 51, Chapter 7, State Money Management Act The state treasurer shall invest the money in the fund according to
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(4)(a): The department may use money in the fund only to pay for the repair, replacement, or upgrade of laboratory equipment in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(5): The state chemist or the commissioner shall approve expenditures from the fund for laboratory equipment repair, replacement, or upgrade as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(5)(a): the state chemist may approve using money in the fund to repair, replace, or upgrade laboratory equipment if the amount to be expended is less than $10,000; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(5)(b): the state chemist shall obtain the approval of the commissioner for using money in the fund to repair, replace, or upgrade laboratory equipment if the amount to be expended equals or exceeds $10,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(6): (6)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(6)(a): (6) Subject to the other provisions of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(6)(b): The fund may not exceed $500,000 at the end of a fiscal year.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-203(6)(c): If the fund exceeds $500,000 at the end of the fiscal year, the Division of Finance shall deposit into the General Fund the money in excess of the amount necessary to maintain the fund balance at $500,000.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-302(1): Whenever the department determines that any person, or any officer or employee of any person, is violating any requirement of this title or rules adopted under this title, the department shall serve written notice upon the alleged violator that specifies the violation and alleges the facts constituting the violation.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-303 Violations unlawful.
--------------------------------------------------
It is unlawful for a person, or the officer or employee of a person, to willfully violate, disobey, or disregard this title, a rule made under this title, or any notice or order issued under this title.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-304 Civil and criminal penalties -- Costs -- Civil liability.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-304(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-304(1)(a): Except as otherwise provided by this title, any person, or the officer or employee of any person, who violates this title or any lawful notice or order issued pursuant to this title shall be assessed a penalty not to exceed $5,000 per violation in a civil proceeding, and is guilty of a class B misdemeanor in a criminal proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-304(1)(b): A subsequent criminal violation within two years is a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-304(2): Any person, or the officer or employee of any person, shall be liable for any expenses incurred by the department in abating any violation of this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-304(3): A penalty assessment or criminal conviction under this title does not relieve the person assessed or convicted from civil liability for claims arising out of any act that was also a violation.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-501 Title.
------------------------------------
This part is known as "Horse Tripping Awareness."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-502 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-502(1): 4-2-108 "Board executive committee" means the executive committee of the Agricultural Advisory Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-502(2): "Horse event" means an event in which horses are roped or tripped for the purpose of a specific event or contest.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-502(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-502(3)(a): "Horse tripping" means the lassoing or roping of the legs of an equine, or otherwise tripping or causing an equine to fall by any means, for the purpose of entertainment, sport, or contest, or practice for entertainment, sport, or contest.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-502(3)(b): "Horse tripping" does not include accepted animal husbandry practices, customary farming practices, or commonly accepted practices occurring in conjunction with a sanctioned rodeo, animal race, or pulling contest.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-503 Event reporting requirements.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-503(1): The owner of a venue holding a horse event shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-503(1)(a): at least 30 days before the day on which the horse event is to be held, notify the board executive committee of the date, time, and name of the horse event; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-503(1)(b): no later than 30 days after the day on which the horse event is held, notify the board executive committee of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-503(1)(b)(i): the number and type of competitions held at the horse event;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-503(1)(b)(ii): the number of horses used;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-503(1)(b)(iii): whether horse tripping occurred, and if so how many horses were used in horse tripping and how many times each horse was tripped; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-503(1)(b)(iv): whether a veterinarian was called during the horse event, and if so:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-503(1)(b)(iv)(A): the name and contact information of the veterinarian;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-503(1)(b)(iv)(B): the outcome of the veterinarian's examination of a horse; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-503(1)(b)(iv)(C): the veterinarian charges incurred.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-701 Pollinator pilot program.
-------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-701(1)(a): public education efforts that include workshops, planting guides, or a public education campaign to raise awareness about creating pollinator habitats;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-701(1)(b): distribution of pollinator-friendly native flowering plants or seeds for native flowering plants for planting within the state to protect a diversity of pollinators;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-701(1)(c): pollinator programs run by local governments and nonprofit organizations with support from the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-701(1)(d): grants that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-701(1)(d)(i): are provided on a first-come-first-serve basis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-701(1)(d)(ii): cover up to 25% of the costs for the planting of pollinator-friendly native flowering plants or seeds for native flowering plants on private or public land.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902 Veterinarian Education Loan Repayment Program.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902(1): There is created within the department the Veterinarian Education Loan Repayment Program.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902(2)(a): Beginning July 1, 2024, the program shall on a first-come, first-served basis make payments toward a qualified veterinarian's education loan balances.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902(2)(b): A veterinarian is eligible for payments under Subsection (2)(a) if the veterinarian:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902(2)(b)(i): applies as a qualified veterinarian for payment from the program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902(2)(b)(ii): registers with the program at least one year before the day the veterinarian applies under Subsection (2)(b)(i) for payment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902(2)(c): Payments made under Subsection (2)(a) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902(2)(c)(i): be made directly to one or more of the qualified veterinarian's lenders;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902(2)(c)(ii): as funding for the program permits, each year equal the maximum payment value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902(2)(c)(iii): extend for a period no longer than five years for the qualified veterinarian.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902(3): The department may use 2% or less of the amount appropriated for the program to pay for actual costs of administering the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902(4): On or before October 1 each year, the department shall submit a report of the program's revenues, expenditures, and outcomes to the Natural Resources, Agriculture, and Environment Interim Committee and the Natural Resources, Agriculture, and Environmental Quality Appropriations Subcommittee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-902(5): The department may make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to administer the program, including rules specifying how a veterinarian may register intent to apply for payment from the program.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1001 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1001(1): 78B-4-512 "Agricultural enterprise" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1001(2): 78B-4-512 "Agritourism activity" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1001(3): 4-2-1002 "Registry" means the voluntary agritourism registry described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1002 Agritourism registry.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1002(1): The department shall maintain a voluntary agritourism registry.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1002(2): The purpose of the registry is to provide public notice of locations where individuals may participate in an agritourism activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1002(3): The owner of an agricultural enterprise that provides an agritourism activity in Utah may voluntarily place the agritourism activity on the registry by providing the following information to the department:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1002(3)(a): the name and location of the agricultural enterprise;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1002(3)(b): a description of the agritourism activity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1002(3)(c): details relating to participation in the agritourism activity, including cost, hours of operation, and other relevant information.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1002(4): The owner of an agricultural enterprise with an agritourism activity on the registry shall notify the department of any changes to the information described in Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1002(5): The department:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1002(5)(a): shall post the information on the registry to the department's website in a location where the public may conveniently access the information;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1002(5)(b): may publicize the availability of the registry to the public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1002(5)(c): may not charge a fee to be listed on, or to use, the registry.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-2-1002(6): A registration under this section is in effect for five years, unless the owner requests removal at an earlier time.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 3 - Utah Dairy Act
**********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-101 Title.
------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Dairy Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1): "Adulterated" means any dairy product that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(a): contains any poisonous or deleterious substance that may render it injurious to health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(b): has been produced, prepared, packaged, or held:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(b)(i): under unsanitary conditions;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(b)(ii): where it may have become contaminated; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(b)(iii): where it may have become diseased or injurious to health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(c): contains any food additive that is unsafe within the meaning of 21 U.S.C. Sec. 348;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(d): contains:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(d)(i): any filthy, putrid, or decomposed substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(d)(ii): fresh fluid milk with a lactic acid level at or above .0018; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(d)(iii): cream with a lactic acid level at or above .008 or that is otherwise unfit for human food;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(e): is the product of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(e)(i): a diseased animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(e)(ii): an animal that died otherwise than by slaughter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(e)(iii): an animal fed upon uncooked offal;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(f): has intentionally been subjected to radiation, unless the use of the radiation is in conformity with a rule or exemption promulgated by the department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(g): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(g)(i): has any valuable constituent omitted or abstracted;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(g)(ii): has any substance substituted in whole or in part;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(g)(iii): has damage or inferiority concealed in any manner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(g)(iv): has any substance added, mixed, or packed with the product to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(g)(iv)(A): increase its bulk or weight;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(g)(iv)(B): reduce its quality or strength; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(1)(g)(iv)(C): make it appear better or of greater value.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(2): "Certificate" means a document allowing a person to market milk.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(3): "Cow-share program" means a program in which a person acquires an undivided interest in a milk producing hoofed mammal through an agreement with a producer that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(3)(a): a bill of sale for an interest in the mammal;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(3)(b): a boarding arrangement under which the person boards the mammal with the producer for the care and milking of the mammal and the boarding arrangement and bill of sale documents remain with the program operator;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(3)(c): an arrangement under which the person receives raw milk for personal use not to be sold or distributed in a retail environment or for profit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(3)(d): no more than two cows, 10 goats, and 10 sheep per farm in the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(4): "Dairy product" means any product derived from raw or pasteurized milk.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(5): "Distributor" means any person who distributes a dairy product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(6)(a): "Filled milk" means any milk, cream, or skimmed milk, whether condensed, evaporated, concentrated, powdered, dried, or desiccated, that has fat or oil other than milk fat added, blended, or compounded with it so that the resultant product is an imitation or semblance of milk, cream, or skimmed milk.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(6)(b): "Filled milk" does not include any distinctive proprietary food compound:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(6)(b)(i): that is prepared and designated for feeding infants and young children, which is customarily used upon the order of a licensed physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(6)(b)(ii): whose product name and label does not contain the word "milk"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(6)(b)(iii): whose label conforms with the food labeling requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(7): "Frozen dairy products" mean dairy products normally served to the consumer in a frozen or semifrozen state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(8): "Grade A milk," "grade A milk products," and "milk" have the same meaning that is accorded the terms in the federal standards for grade A milk and grade A milk products unless modified by rules of the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(9): "Manufacturer" means any person who processes milk in a way that changes the milk's character.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(10): "Manufacturing milk" means milk used in the production of non-grade A dairy products.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(11): "Misbranded" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(11)(a): any dairy product whose label is false or misleading in any particular, or whose label or package fails to conform to any federal regulation adopted by the department that pertains to packaging and labeling;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(11)(b): any dairy product in final packaged form manufactured in this state that does not bear:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(11)(b)(i): the manufacturer's, packer's, or distributor's name, address, and plant number, if applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(11)(b)(ii): a clear statement of the product's common or usual name, quantity, and ingredients, if applicable; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(11)(b)(iii): any other information required by rule of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(11)(c): any butter in consumer package form that is not at least B grade, or that does not meet the grade claimed on the package, measured by U.S.D.A. butter grade standards;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(11)(d): any imitation butter made in whole or in part from material other than wholesome milk or cream, except clearly labeled "margarine";
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(11)(e): renovated butter unless the words "renovated butter," in letters not less than 1/2-inch in height appear on each package, roll, square, or container of such butter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(11)(f): any dairy product in final packaged form that makes nutritional claims or adds or adjusts nutrients that are not so labeled.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(12): "Pasteurization" means any process that renders dairy products practically free of disease organisms and is accepted by federal standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(13): (13)(a) "Permit" means a document allowing a person or plant, as designated in the permit, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(13)(a): process, manufacture, supply, test, haul, or pasteurize milk or milk products; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(13)(b): (13)(a) repair equipment used to conduct the activities described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(14): "Plant" means any facility where milk is processed or manufactured.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(15): "Processor" means any person who subjects milk to a process.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(16): "Producer" means a person who owns a cow or other milk producing hoofed mammal that produces milk for consumption by persons other than the producer's family, employees, or nonpaying guests.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(17): "Raw milk" means unpasteurized milk.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(18): "Renovated butter" means butter that is reduced to a liquid state by melting and drawing off such liquid or butter oil and churning or otherwise manipulating it in connection with milk or any product of milk.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-102(19): "Retailer" means any person who sells or distributes dairy products directly to the consumer.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-201 Authority to make and enforce rules.
------------------------------------------------------------------
The department is authorized and directed, subject to

Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-202 Authority in local jurisdictions to regulate dairy products -- Department standards to govern -- Department evaluation permitted -- Local notice to cease inspection.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-202(1): While nothing in this chapter shall impair the authority of any town, city, or county to regulate the production, handling, storage, distribution, or sale of dairy products, frozen dairy products, grade A milk, grade A milk products, or milk, within their respective jurisdictions, a common standard as prescribed by the department shall be followed in such jurisdictions.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-202(2): If a town, city, or county elects to enforce this chapter, the department shall accept its findings relative to inspections in lieu of making its own inspections, but the department may evaluate the effectiveness of any local inspection program.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-202(3): If a town, city, or county intends to cease making inspections under this chapter, it shall notify the department of its intent to cease inspection at least one year in advance of the actual cessation of inspection.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-202(4): Upon request, the commissioner shall cooperate with other state agencies, towns, cities, counties, and federal authorities in the administration and enforcement of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-203 Authority to inspect premises.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-203(1): The department may inspect any premises where dairy products are produced, manufactured, processed, stored, or held for distribution, at reasonable times and places, to determine whether the premises are in compliance with this chapter and the rules adopted according to it.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-203(2): If the department is denied access, it may proceed immediately to the nearest court of competent jurisdiction to seek an ex parte warrant or its equivalent to permit inspection of the premises.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-204 Authority to collect samples -- Receipt -- Names of distributors.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-204(1): Samples of dairy products from each dairy farm or processing plant may be secured and examined as often as deemed necessary by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-204(2): Samples of dairy products from stores, cafes, soda fountains, restaurants, and other places where dairy products are sold may be secured and examined as often as deemed necessary by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-204(3): Samples of milk or dairy products may be taken by the department at any time before final delivery to the consumer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-204(4): The department shall provide a signed receipt for all samples taken showing the date of sampling and the amount and kind of sample taken; provided, that the department is not liable to any person for the cost of any sample taken.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-204(5): All proprietors of stores, cafes, restaurants, soda fountains, and other similar places shall furnish the department, upon request, with the names of all distributors from whom dairy products are obtained.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-205 Condemnation, embargo, denaturization of unfit milk or dairy products -- Unfit equipment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-205(1): The department may condemn or embargo any milk or dairy product which is adulterated, misbranded, or not produced or processed in accordance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-205(2): The department may condemn the use of any equipment, tank, or container used to produce, process, manufacture, or transport milk or dairy products that it finds, upon inspection, to be unclean or contaminated.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-205(3): The department may mark or tag any condemned equipment, tank, or container with the words "this (equipment, tank, or container) is unfit to contain human food."
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-205(4): Condemned milk shall be decharacterized or denatured with harmless coloring or rennet by the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-206 Testing and measuring milk -- Standards prescribed -- Milk quality work in accordance with rules.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-206(1): Milk shall be tested and measured in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-206(1)(a): the latest edition of "Association of Official Analytical Chemists";
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-206(1)(b): the latest edition of "Standard Methods for Examination of Dairy Products";
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-206(1)(c): other publications accepted by the department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-206(1)(d): methods prescribed by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-206(2): A processor or manufacturer shall perform quality work in accordance with the rules adopted by the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-301 Permits or certificates -- Application -- Fee -- Expiration -- Renewal.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-301(1): Application for a permit to operate a plant, manufacture butter or cheese, pasteurize milk, test milk for payment, haul milk in bulk, or for the wholesale distribution of dairy products shall be made to the department upon forms prescribed and furnished by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-301(2): 4-2-103(2) Upon receipt of a proper application, compliance with the applicable rules, and payment of a permit fee determined by the department according to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-301(3): A permit issued under this section expires at midnight on December 31 of each year.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-301(4): 4-2-103(2) A permit to operate a plant, manufacture butter or cheese, pasteurize milk, test milk for payment, haul milk in bulk, or for the wholesale distribution of dairy products, is renewable for a period of one year upon the payment of an annual permit renewal fee determined by the department according to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-301(5): (1); 4-3-503 Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-301(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-301(6)(a): Upon receipt of a proper application and compliance with applicable rules, the commissioner shall issue a permit entitling the applicant to engage in the business of producer, subject to suspension or revocation for cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-301(6)(b): A fee may not be charged by the department for issuance of a certificate.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-302 Permits and certificates -- Suspension or revocation -- Grounds.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-302(1): The department may revoke or suspend the permit or  certificate of any person who violates this chapter or any rule enacted under the authority of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-302(2): All or part of any permit or  certificate may be suspended immediately if an emergency exists that presents a clear and present danger to the public health, or if inspection or sampling is refused.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401 Unlawful acts specified.
------------------------------------------------------
It is unlawful for any person in this state to:Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(1): operate a plant without a permit issued by the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(2): market milk without a certificate issued by the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(3): (3); (3) manufacture butter or cheese, pasteurize milk, test milk for payment, or haul milk in bulk without a special permit to perform the particular activity designated in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(4): manufacture, distribute, sell, deliver, hold, store, or offer for sale any adulterated or misbranded dairy product;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(5): manufacture, distribute, sell, deliver, hold, store, or offer for sale any dairy product without a permit or certificate required by this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(6): sell or offer for sale any milk not intended for human consumption unless it is denatured or decharacterized in accordance with the rules of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(7): manufacture, distribute, sell, or offer for sale any filled milk labeled as milk or as a dairy product;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(8): keep any animals with brucellosis, tuberculosis, or other infectious or contagious diseases communicable to humans in any place where they may come in contact with cows or other milking animals;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(9): draw milk for human food from cows or other milking animals that are infected with tuberculosis, running sores, communicable diseases, or from animals that are fed feed that will produce milk that is adulterated;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(10): accept or process milk from any producer without verification that the producer holds a valid permit or certification or, if milk is accepted from out of the state, without verification that the producer holds a permit or certification from the appropriate regulatory agency of that state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(11): use any contaminated or unclean equipment or container to process, manufacture, distribute, deliver, or sell a dairy product;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(12): remove, change, conceal, erase, or obliterate any mark or tag placed upon any equipment, tank, or container by the department except to clean and sanitize it;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(13): use any tank or container used for the transportation of milk or other dairy products that is unclean or contaminated;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(14): refuse to allow the department to take samples for testing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-401(15): prohibit adding vitamin compounds in the processing of milk and dairy products in accordance with rules of the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402 Processors, manufacturers, or distributors -- Unlawful to give money, equipment, or fixtures to retailer or consumer -- Exceptions -- Shelf space for dairy products.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(1)(a): "liquid dairy product" means a milk container which contains a pint of milk or less; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(1)(b): "novelty ice cream" means a package or container of ice cream which contains eight fluid ounces or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(2): (3); (4) Except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(2)(a): money;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(2)(b): equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(2)(c): fixtures, including ice cream cabinets or bulk milk dispensers;

Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(2)(e): other things having a real or substantial value.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(3)(a): Ice cream cabinets may be loaned or sold to a retailer if the ice cream cabinet:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(3)(a)(i): is portable;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(3)(a)(ii): has a storage capacity not exceeding 12 cubic feet; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(3)(a)(iii): is used solely for retail display sales of novelty ice cream.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(3)(b)(ii): has a storage capacity not exceeding 12 cubic feet; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(3)(b)(iii): is used solely for retail display sales of liquid dairy products.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(4): The leasing or renting of cabinets, dispensers, or coolers for dairy products for civic affairs, demonstrations, or exhibits is prohibited unless it is for a period of 10 days or less in any one period of three consecutive months.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-402(5): (5)(b); (5)(c); (5)(a); (3)

Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-403 Injunctions -- Bond not required -- Standing to maintain private action -- Damages authorized.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-403(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-403(1)(a): The commissioner is authorized to apply to any court of competent jurisdiction for a temporary restraining order or injunction restraining any person from violating this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-501 Cow share program notification.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-501(1): 4-3-102 A producer who is in a cow-share program, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-501(1)(a): the producer's name; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-501(1)(b): a valid, current address of the farm on which the milk producing hoofed mammal in the cow-share program is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-501(2): (1) Upon receipt, the department shall keep a notification of a cow-share program described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-502 Exemption.
----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-502(1): This chapter does not apply to milk or milk products produced on the farm if such milk or milk products are used by:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-502(1)(a): the owner of the farm;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-502(1)(b): a member of the owner's immediate family;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-502(1)(c): a participant in a cow-share program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-502(1)(d): a member of a participant in a cow-share program's immediate family.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-502(2): The department may not adopt a rule that restricts, limits, or imposes additional requirements on an individual obtaining:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-502(2)(a): raw milk in accordance with the terms of a cow-share program agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-502(2)(b): an interest in a cow-share program in accordance with the terms of the cow-share program agreement.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503 Sale of raw milk products -- Suspension of producer's permit -- Severability not permitted.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(1)(a): "Batch" means all the milk emptied from one bulk tank and bottled in a single day.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(1)(b): "Raw milk product" means any product produced from raw milk.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(1)(c): "Self-owned retail store" means a retail store:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(1)(c)(i): of which the producer owns at least 51% of the value of the real property and tangible personal property used in the operations of the retail store; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(1)(c)(ii): for which the producer has the power to vote at least 51% of any class of voting shares or ownership interest in the business entity that operates the retail store.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2): (5); 4-3-301(6); (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(a): 4-3-301(6) the producer obtains a permit from the department to produce the raw milk product under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(b): (3) the sale and delivery of the raw milk product is made upon the premises where the raw milk product is produced, except as provided by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(c): the raw milk product is sold to consumers for household use and not for resale;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(d): the raw milk product is bottled or packaged under sanitary conditions and in sanitary containers on the premises where the raw milk product is produced;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(e): the raw milk product is labeled "raw milk product" and meets the labeling requirements under 21 C.F.R.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(f): the raw milk used to produce the raw milk product is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(f)(i): cooled to 50 degrees Fahrenheit or a lower temperature within one hour after being drawn from the animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(f)(ii): further cooled to 41 degrees Fahrenheit within two hours of being drawn from the animal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(f)(iii): maintained at 41 degrees Fahrenheit or a lower temperature until the raw milk is delivered to the consumer or used to produce the raw milk product;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(g): the bacterial count of the raw milk used to produce the raw milk product does not exceed 20,000 colony forming units per milliliter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(h): the coliform count of the raw milk used to produce the raw milk product does not exceed 10 colony forming units per milliliter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(i): the production of the raw milk product conforms to departmental rules for the production of grade A milk products;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(j): the dairy animals on the premises are:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(j)(i): permanently and individually identifiable; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(j)(ii): free of tuberculosis, brucellosis, and other diseases carried through milk; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(2)(k): any person on the premises performing any work in connection with the production, bottling, packaging, handling, or sale of the raw milk product is free from communicable disease.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(3): (2); Chapter 5, Utah Wholesome Food Act; 4-5-301 A producer may distribute, sell, deliver, hold, store, or offer for sale a raw milk product at a self-owned retail store, that is properly staffed, or from a mobile unit where the raw milk product is maintained through mechanical refrigeration at 41 degrees Fahrenheit or a lower temperature, if, in addition to the requirements of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 4-3-503(3)(g):
