Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 4 - Eggs
************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-101 Title.
------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Eggs."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-102 Department to establish egg grades and standards -- Authority to make and enforce rules.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-102(1): The department may establish grades and standards of quality, size, and weight governing the sale of eggs.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-102(2): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The department shall, subject to


Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(1): "Addled" or "white rot" means putrid or rotten.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(2): "Adherent yolk" means the yolk has settled to one side and become fastened to the shell.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(3): "Albumen" means the white of an egg.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(4): "Black rot" means the egg has deteriorated to such an extent that the whole interior presents a blackened appearance.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(5): "Black spot" means mold or bacteria have developed in isolated areas inside the shell.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(6): "Blood ring" means bacteria have developed to such an extent that blood is formed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(7): "Candling" means the act of determining the condition of an egg by holding it before a strong light in such a way that the light shines through the egg and reveals the egg's contents.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(8): "End consumer" means a household consumer, restaurant, institution, or any other person who has purchased or received shell eggs for consumption.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(9): "Moldy" means mold spores have formed within the shell.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(10): "Shell egg" means an egg in the shell as distinguished from a dried or powdered egg.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(11): "Small producer" means a producer of shell eggs:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(11)(a): having less than 3,000 layers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(11)(b): who is exempt from 21 C.F.R. Chapter 1, Part 118, Production, Storage, and Transportation of Shell Eggs.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-103(12): "Wholesale" means, with respect to the sale of an egg by an egg producer, the transfer for sale or sale of an egg to a person other than the end consumer, including a retailer or an industrial or business purchaser.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-104 Unlawful acts specified.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-104(1): It is unlawful for any person to sell, offer, or expose for sale for human consumption any egg:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-104(1)(a): that is addled or moldy or that contains black spot, black rot, white rot, blood ring, adherent yolk, or a bloody or green albumen; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-104(1)(b): without a sign or label that conforms to the standards for display and grade adopted by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-104(2): For the purpose of bulk wholesale, it is unlawful for a small producer to commingle or combine eggs from a source other than the small producer's operation.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-104(3): Nothing in this section prohibits the sale of a denatured egg.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-105 Maintenance of candling records -- Inspection of records.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-105(1): A person who sells, offers, or exposes eggs for sale or exchange shall maintain candling records as prescribed by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-105(2): All candling records shall be open for examination by accredited inspectors or representatives of the department at reasonable times.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-106 Retailers exempt from prosecution -- Conditions for exemption.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-106(1): (2) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-106(1)(a): at the time an egg was purchased the seller guaranteed that the egg conformed to the grade, quality, size, and weight stated in the purchase invoice; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-106(1)(b): the egg was labeled for sale by the retailer in accordance with the purchase invoice.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-106(2): (1)(a) The guaranty by the seller described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107 Exemptions from regulation.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(1): Except as provided in this section, a small producer and the shell eggs produced by a small producer are exempt from regulation by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(2): The Department of Health and Human Services has the authority to investigate foodborne illness.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(3): The department may assist, consult, or inspect shell eggs and a small producer's operation when requested by a small producer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(4): Nothing in this section affects the authority of the Department of Health and Human Services or the department to certify, license, regulate, or inspect food or food products that are not exempt from certification, licensing regulation, or inspection under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(5): The Department of Health and Human Services, or a local health department, may not prevent the sale of shell eggs from a small producer to an end consumer unless the Department of Health and Human Services, or the county health department, establishes that the shell eggs:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(5)(a): are addled or moldy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(5)(b): contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(5)(b)(i): black spot;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(5)(b)(ii): black rot;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(5)(b)(iii): white rot;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(5)(b)(iv): blood ring;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(5)(b)(v): adherent yolk; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(5)(b)(vi): a bloody or green albumen.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(6): A small producer that sells eggs wholesale shall notify the department about the small egg producer's operation, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(6)(a): the operator's name;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(6)(b): the operator's contact information;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(6)(c): the species of egg products offered for sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(6)(d): other information required by department rule regarding notification.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(7): The department may make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(7)(a): govern the temperature, cleaning, and sanitization of shell eggs under this chapter that are sold by a small producer to a restaurant or wholesale;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(7)(b): establish notification requirements in accordance with Subsection (6); and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(7)(c): establish inspection requirements for small producers that request an inspection under Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-107(8): Eggs sold by a small producer in accordance with this chapter are exempt from the restricted egg tolerances for United States Consumer Grade B as specified in the United States Standards, Grades, and Weight Classes for Shell Eggs, AMS 56.200 et seq., administered by the Agricultural Marketing Service of United States Agriculture Department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108 Packaging for small producer -- Display in grocery store.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(1): A small producer shall package the small producer's eggs in clean packaging that bears a label with the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(1)(a): the common name of the food, "eggs";
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(1)(b): the quantity or number of eggs;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(1)(c): the name and address of the small producer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(1)(d): the statement "Keep Refrigerated"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(1)(e): the statement "SAFE HANDLING INSTRUCTIONS: To prevent illness from bacteria: Keep eggs refrigerated, cook eggs until yolks are firm, and cook foods containing eggs thoroughly."
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(2)(a): A small producer shall label the small producer's eggs that are sold in a grocery store with a statement that the eggs:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(2)(a)(i): are exempt from 21 C.F.R. Chapter 1, Part 118, Production, Storage, and Transportation of Shell Eggs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(2)(a)(ii): are not from an inspected source.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(2)(b): The requirements described in Subsection (2)(a) are in addition to the labeling requirements described in Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(3)(a): A small producer may state a "pull date" or "best by" date.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(3)(b): The "pull date" or "best by" date may be hand written on the end of the packaging or in a conspicuous location that is clearly discernible.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(3)(c): A "pull date" or "best by" date shall first show the month then the day of the month.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(3)(d): A recommended "pull date" or "best by" date is 30 days after production, but the date may not exceed 45 days after production.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(4): If the eggs of a small producer are ungraded and not weighed, the packaging for the eggs may not be labeled with a grade or size.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4-108(5): Any egg produced by a small egg producer and sold in a grocery store shall be displayed separately in the grocery store from eggs not from a small producer.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 4a - Confinement of Egg-laying Hens
***************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Confinement of Egg-Laying Hens."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(1): (1)(a); (1)(c); (1)(a); (1)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(1)(a): "Cage-free housing system" means an indoor or outdoor controlled environment for egg-laying hens where:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(1)(a)(i): for an indoor environment, the egg-laying hens are free to roam unrestricted except by the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(1)(a)(i)(A): exterior walls; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(1)(a)(i)(B): interior fencing used to contain the entire egg-laying hen flock within the building or subdivide flocks into smaller groups if farm employees can walk through each contained or subdivided area to provide care to egg-laying hens and if each egg-laying hen has at least the amount of usable floor space per hen required by the 2017 edition of the United Egg Producers' Animal Husbandry Guidelines for U.S. Egg-Laying Flocks: Guidelines for Cage-Free Housing;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(1)(a)(ii): egg-laying hens are provided enrichments that allow them to exhibit natural behaviors including, at a minimum, scratch areas, perches, nest boxes, and dust bathing areas; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(1)(a)(iii): farm employees can provide care while standing within the egg-laying hens' usable floor space.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(1)(b): (1)(a); (1)(c); (1)(a); (1)(c) "Cage-free housing system" includes, to the extent the system is a system described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(1)(c): "Cage-free housing system" does not include systems commonly described as battery cages, colony cages, enriched cages, enriched colony cages, modified cages, convertible cages, furnished cages, or similar cage systems.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(2): "Egg-laying hen" means a female domesticated chicken kept for the purpose of commercial egg production.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(3): "Enclosure" means a structure used to confine an egg-laying hen.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(4)(a): "Farm" means the land, buildings, support facilities, and other equipment that are wholly or partially used for the commercial production of animals or animal products used for food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(4)(b): "Farm" does not include live animal markets or official plants at which mandatory inspection is maintained under the federal Egg Products Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 1031 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(5): "Farm owner or operator" means a person that owns a controlling interest in a farm or controls the operations of a farm.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(6): "Multi-tiered aviary" means a cage-free housing system where egg-laying hens have unfettered access to multiple elevated flat platforms that provide the egg-laying hens with usable floor space both on top of and underneath the platforms.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(7): "Partially slatted system" means a cage-free housing system where egg-laying hens have unfettered access to elevated flat platforms under which manure drops through the flooring to a pit or litter removal belt below.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(8): "Shell egg" means a whole egg of an egg-laying hen in the egg's shell form, intended for use as human food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(9): "Single-level all-litter floor system" means a cage-free housing system bedded with litter where egg-laying hens have limited or no access to elevated flat platforms.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(10)(a): "Usable floor space" means the total square footage of floor space provided to each egg-laying hen, as calculated by dividing the total square footage of floor space provided to egg-laying hens in an enclosure by the total number of egg-laying hens in that enclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-102(10)(b): "Usable floor space" includes both ground space and elevated level or nearly level flat platforms upon which hens can roost, but does not include perches or ramps.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-103 Prohibitions.
--------------------------------------------
Beginning on January 1, 2030, a farm owner or operator may not knowingly confine an egg-laying hen in an enclosure:Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-103(1): that is not a cage-free housing system; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-103(2): that has less than the amount of usable floor space per hen as required by the 2017 edition of the United Egg Producers' Animal Husbandry Guidelines for U.S. Egg-Laying Flocks: Guidelines for Cage-Free Housing.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-104 Confinement exemptions.
------------------------------------------------------
SectionUtah Code Annotated § 4-4a-104(1): used for medical research;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-104(2): during examination, testing, individual treatment, or operation for veterinary purposes, but only if performed by or under the direct supervision of a licensed veterinarian;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-104(3): during transportation;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-104(4): at state or county fair exhibitions, 4-H programs, and similar exhibitions;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-104(5): during slaughter conducted in accordance with applicable laws, rules, and regulations; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-104(6): kept for temporary animal husbandry purposes of no more than six hours in any 24-hour period and no more than 24 hours total in any 30-day period.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-105 De minimis exemptions for shell eggs.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter does not apply to the production of shell eggs in the state by a farm with fewer than 3,000 egg-laying hens.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-106 Enforcement.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-106(1): The department shall enforce this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-106(2): A person subject to this chapter shall allow the department access during regular business hours to facilities and records pertinent to activities subject to this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-106(3): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The department shall, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-106(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-106(4)(a): The department may use an inspection provider or process verification provider to ensure compliance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-106(4)(b): To rely on an inspection provider or process verification provider, the department must approve the specific inspection provider or process verification provider as competent to ensure compliance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-106(5): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-106(5)(a): If the department determines that a person subject to this chapter is in violation of a provision of this chapter or a rule adopted under this chapter, the department shall provide the person with a written notice that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-106(5)(a)(i): describes each violation identified by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-106(5)(a)(ii): states a reasonable deadline by which the person is required to cure the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-106(5)(b): (5)(a) If a person who receives a notice issued under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-106(5)(c): If a violation is not cured after the department provides a person with written notice of the violation and a reasonable opportunity to cure, the department may seek a temporary restraining order or permanent injunction to prevent further violation of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-107 Report.
--------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-107(1): The department shall provide a report on this chapter to the Business and Labor Interim Committee at an interim meeting in 2027 that occurs before October 31.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-107(2): 4-4a-103 The report described in Subsection (1) shall include an update on:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-107(2)(a): 4-4a-103 the progress by farm owners and operators to comply with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-4a-107(2)(b): the retail demand for and conditions related to the sale of cage-free eggs.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 5 - Utah Wholesome Food Act
*******************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-101 Title.
------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Wholesome Food Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(1): "Advertisement" means a representation, other than by labeling, made to induce the purchase of food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(2)(a): "Color additive":
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(2)(a)(i): means a dye, pigment, or other substance not exempted under the federal act that, when added or applied to a food, is capable of imparting color; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(2)(a)(ii): includes black, white, and intermediate grays.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(2)(b): "Color additive" does not include a pesticide chemical, soil or plant nutrient, or other agricultural chemical that imparts color solely because of the chemical's effect, before or after harvest, in aiding, retarding, or otherwise affecting, directly or indirectly, the growth or other natural physiological process of any plant life.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(3): Chapter 16, Utah Seed Act
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(3)(a): "Consumer commodity" means a food, as defined by this chapter, or by the federal act.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(3)(b): Chapter 16, Utah Seed Act "Consumer commodity" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(3)(b)(i): a commodity subject to packaging or labeling requirements imposed under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act, 7 U.S.C. Sec. 136 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(3)(b)(ii): Chapter 16, Utah Seed Act a commodity subject to
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(3)(b)(iii): a meat or meat product subject to the Federal Meat Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 601 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(3)(b)(iv): a poultry or poultry product subject to the Poultry Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 451 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(3)(b)(v): a tobacco or tobacco product; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(3)(b)(vi): a beverage subject to or complying with packaging or labeling requirements imposed under the Federal Alcohol Administration Act, 27 U.S.C. Sec. 201 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(4): "Contaminated" means not securely protected from dust, dirt, or foreign or injurious agents.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(5)(a): "Farm" means an agricultural operation, under management by one entity, that grows or harvests crops.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(5)(b): "Farm" does not include an entity that is exempt under 21 C.F.R. 112.4(a) or 21 C.F.R. 112.5.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(6): "Farmers market" means a market where a producer of a food product sells only a fresh, raw, whole, unprocessed, and unprepared food item directly to the final consumer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(7): "Federal act" means the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 301 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(8): "Food" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(8)(a): an article used for food or drink for human or animal consumption or the components of the article;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(8)(b): chewing gum or chewing gum components; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(8)(c): a food supplement for special dietary use that is necessitated because of a physical, physiological, pathological, or other condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(9)(a): "Food additive" means a substance, the intended use of which results in the substance becoming a component, or otherwise affecting the characteristics, of a food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(9)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(9)(b)(i): "Food additive" includes a substance or source of radiation intended for use in producing, manufacturing, packing, processing, preparing, treating, packaging, transporting, or holding food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(9)(b)(ii): "Food additive" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(9)(b)(ii)(A): a pesticide chemical in or on a raw agricultural commodity;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(9)(b)(ii)(B): a pesticide chemical that is intended for use or is used in the production, storage, or transportation of a raw agricultural commodity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(9)(b)(ii)(C): a substance used in accordance with a sanction or approval granted pursuant to the Poultry Products Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 451 et seq. or the Federal Meat Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 601 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(10): 26B-7-401
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(10)(a): "Food establishment" means a grocery store, bakery, candy factory, food processor, bottling plant, sugar factory, cannery, farm, rabbit processor, meat processor, flour mill, cold or dry warehouse storage, or other facility where food products are manufactured, canned, processed, packaged, stored, transported, prepared, sold, or offered for sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(10)(b): 26B-7-401 "Food establishment" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(10)(b)(i): a dairy farm, a dairy plant, or a meat establishment, that is subject to the Poultry Products Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 451 et seq., or the Federal Meat Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 601 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(10)(b)(ii): a farmers market; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(10)(b)(iii): 26B-7-401 a food service establishment, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(11): "Label" means a written, printed, or graphic display on the immediate container of an article of food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(12): "Labeling" means a label and other written, printed, or graphic display:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(12)(a): on an article of food or the article of food's container or wrapper; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(12)(b): accompanying the article of food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(13): "Official compendium" means the official documents or supplements to the:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(13)(a): United States Pharmacopoeia;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(13)(b): National Formulary; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(13)(c): Homeopathic Pharmacopoeia of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(14): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(14)(a): "Package" means a container or wrapping in which a consumer commodity is enclosed for use in the delivery or display of the consumer commodity to retail purchasers.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(14)(b): "Package" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(14)(b)(i): a package liner;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(14)(b)(ii): a shipping container or wrapping used solely for the transportation of a consumer commodity in bulk or in quantity to a manufacturer, packer, processor, or wholesale or retail distributor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(14)(b)(iii): a shipping container or outer wrapping used by a retailer to ship or deliver a consumer commodity to a retail customer, if the container and wrapping bear no printed information relating to the consumer commodity.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(15): 4-14-102
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(15)(a): 4-14-102 "Pesticide" means a substance intended:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(15)(a)(i): 4-14-102 to prevent, destroy, repel, or mitigate a pest, as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(15)(a)(ii): for use as a plant regulator, defoliant, or desiccant.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(15)(b): "Pesticide" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(15)(b)(i): a new animal drug, as defined by 21 U.S.C. Sec. 321, that has been determined by the United States Secretary of Health and Human Services not to be a new animal drug by federal regulation establishing conditions of use of the drug; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(15)(b)(ii): animal feed, as defined by 21 U.S.C. Sec. 321, bearing or containing a new animal drug.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(16): "Principal display panel" means that part of a label that is most likely to be displayed, presented, shown, or examined under normal and customary conditions of display for retail sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(17): "Produce" means a food that is a:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(17)(a): fruit, vegetable, mix of intact fruits and vegetables, mushroom, sprout from any seed source, peanut, tree nut, or herb; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(17)(b): raw agricultural commodity.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(18): "Raw agricultural commodity" means a food in the food's raw or natural state, including all fruits that are washed, colored, or otherwise treated in the fruit's unpeeled, natural form before marketing.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(19): "Registration" means the commissioner's issuance of a certificate to a qualified food establishment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-102(20): "Sprout" means the shoot of a plant generally harvested when cotyledons are undeveloped or underdeveloped and mature leaves have not emerged.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103 Adulterated food specified.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1): 4-5-204(1); (3); 4-5-204 A food is adulterated:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(a): if the food bears or contains a poisonous or deleterious substance in a quantity that may ordinarily render the food injurious to health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(b): 4-5-204(1) if the food bears or contains an added poisonous or added deleterious substance that is unsafe within the meaning of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(c): (3) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(c)(i): is a raw agricultural commodity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(c)(ii): bears or contains a pesticide chemical that is unsafe within the meaning of 21 U.S.C. Sec. 346a;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(d): if the food is, bears, or contains a food additive that is unsafe within the meaning of 21 U.S.C. Sec. 348;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(e): if the food consists in whole or in part of a diseased, contaminated, filthy, putrid, or decomposed substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(f): if the food is otherwise unfit for food;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(g): if the food has been produced, prepared, packed, or held under unsanitary conditions whereby the food may have:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(g)(i): become contaminated with filth; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(g)(ii): been rendered diseased, unwholesome, or injurious to health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(h): if the food is, in whole or in part, the product of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(h)(i): a diseased animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(h)(ii): an animal that has died other than by slaughter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(h)(iii): an animal that has fed upon the uncooked offal from a slaughterhouse;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(i): if the food's container is composed, in whole or in part, of a poisonous or deleterious substance that may render the contents injurious to health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(j): 4-5-204 if the food is intentionally subjected to radiation, unless the use of the radiation was in conformity with a rule or exemption in effect pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(k): if the food:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(k)(i): is a meat or meat product; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(k)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(k)(ii)(A): is in a casing, package, or wrapper:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(k)(ii)(A)(I): through which a part of the casing, package, or wrapper's contents can be seen; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(k)(ii)(A)(II): that is colored or has markings that are colored, so as to be misleading or deceptive with respect to the color, quality, or kind of food to which the color is applied; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(k)(ii)(B): contains or bears a color additive;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(l): if the food is produce and is in violation of 21 C.F.R.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(m): if a valuable constituent is, in whole or in part, omitted or abstracted from a product and a substance is substituted wholly or in part;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(n): if damage or inferiority is concealed;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(o): if a substance is added, mixed, or packed with a product so as to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(o)(i): increase the product's bulk or weight;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(o)(ii): reduce the product's quality or strength; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(o)(iii): make the product appear better or of greater value; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(p): if the food:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(p)(i): is confectionery; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(p)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(p)(ii)(A): has partially or completely imbedded in the food a nonnutritive object, unless the department determines that the nonnutritive object:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(p)(ii)(A)(I): is of practical functional value to the confectionery product; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(p)(ii)(A)(II): would not render the product injurious or hazardous to health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(p)(ii)(B): bears or contains alcohol, other than alcohol derived solely from the use of flavoring extracts, that does not exceed .05% by volume; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(p)(ii)(C): bears or contains a nonnutritive substance, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(p)(ii)(C)(I): the nonnutritive substance is a safe nonnutritive substance that is in or on the confectionery for a practical functional purpose in the manufacture, packaging, or storing of the confectionery; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(1)(p)(ii)(C)(II): the use of the nonnutritive substance does not promote deception of the consumer or otherwise result in adulteration or misbranding in violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(2): (1)(p)(ii)(C) The department may, for the purpose of avoiding or resolving uncertainty as to the application of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(3): 4-5-204 Notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(3)(a): the pesticide chemical is used in or on a raw agricultural commodity in conformity with an exemption granted or tolerance prescribed under 21 U.S.C. Sec. 346a;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(3)(b): the residue of the pesticide chemical in or on the raw agricultural commodity is removed to the extent possible in good manufacturing practice;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(3)(c): the raw agricultural commodity is subjected to processing such as canning, cooking, freezing, dehydrating, or milling; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-103(3)(d): the concentration of the residue in the processed food when ready to eat is no greater than the tolerance prescribed for the raw agricultural commodity.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104 Authority to make and enforce rules.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(1): The department may adopt rules to efficiently enforce this chapter, and if practicable, adopt rules that conform to the regulations adopted under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 301 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(2): The department or an officer, agent, or employee designated by the department shall conduct a hearing authorized or required by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(3): (3)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(3)(a): (3)(b) Except as provided by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(3)(b): The department may adopt a rule that prescribes tolerance for pesticides in finished foods in this state whether or not in accordance with regulations made under the federal act.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(4): (4)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(4)(a): (4)(b) Except as provided by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(4)(b): The department may adopt a rule that prescribes conditions under which a food additive may be used in this state whether or not in accordance with regulations made under the federal act.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(5): Color additive regulations adopted under authority of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 301 et seq., are the color additive rules in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(6): (6)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(6)(a): (6)(b) Except as provided by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(6)(b): The department may, if the department finds it necessary to inform purchasers of the value of a food for special dietary use, prescribe special dietary use rules whether or not in accordance with regulations made under the federal act.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(7): (7)(b); (7)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(7)(a): (7)(b) Except as provided by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(7)(b): (7)(c) Except as provided by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(7)(c): The department may not adopt rules that are contrary to the labeling requirements for the net quantity of contents required according to 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1453(a)(4).
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(8): (8)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(8)(a): (8)(b) Except as provided by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(8)(b): The department may adopt a rule that prescribes preventive controls in this state whether or not in accordance with regulations made under the federal act except that the rule may not be more stringent than the federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(9): (9)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(9)(a): (9)(b) Except as provided by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(9)(b): The department may adopt a rule that prescribes standards for the growing, harvesting, packaging, and holding of produce for human consumption in this state whether or not in accordance with regulations made under the federal act except that the rule may not be more stringent than the federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(a): A federal regulation automatically adopted according to this chapter takes effect in this state on the date the federal regulation becomes effective as a federal regulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(b): The department shall publish all other proposed rules in publications prescribed by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(c)(i): A person who may be adversely affected by a rule may, within 30 days after a federal regulation is automatically adopted, or within 30 days after publication of any other rule, file with the department, in writing, objections and a request for a hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(c)(ii): The timely filing of substantial objections to a federal regulation automatically adopted stays the effect of the rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(d)(i): If no substantial objections are received and no hearing is requested within 30 days after publication of a proposed rule, it shall take effect on a date set by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(d)(ii): The effective date shall be at least 60 days after the time for filing objections has expired.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(e)(i): If timely substantial objections are made to a federal regulation within 30 days after the federal regulation is automatically adopted or to a proposed rule within 30 days after the proposed rule is published, the department, after notice, shall conduct a public hearing to receive evidence on the issues raised by the objections.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(e)(ii): An interested person or the person's representative may be heard.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(f): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(f)(i): The department shall act upon objections by order and shall mail the order to objectors by certified mail as soon after the hearing as practicable.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(f)(ii): The order shall be based on substantial evidence in the record of the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(g): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(g)(i): If the order concerns a proposed rule, the department may withdraw the proposed rule or set an effective date for the rule as published or as modified by the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(10)(g)(ii): The effective date shall be at least 60 days after publication of the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-104(11): Whenever a regulation is made under authority of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 301 et seq., establishing standards for food, the tolerances established by the department under this chapter shall immediately conform to the standards established by the Federal Food and Drug Administration as herein provided and shall remain the same until the department determines that for reasons peculiar to Utah a different rule should apply.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105 Inspection of premises and records -- Authority to take samples -- Inspection results reported.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(1): An authorized agent of the department, upon presenting appropriate credentials to the owner, operator, or agent in charge, may:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(1)(a): enter at reasonable times a factory, farm, warehouse, or establishment in which food is manufactured, processed, packed, or held for introduction into commerce or after introduction into commerce;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(1)(b): enter a vehicle being used to transport or hold food in commerce;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(1)(c): inspect at reasonable times and within reasonable limits and in a reasonable manner a factory, warehouse, establishment, or vehicle and all pertinent equipment, finished and unfinished materials, containers, and labeling located within the factory, warehouse, establishment, or vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(1)(d): obtain samples necessary for the enforcement of this chapter if the department:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(1)(d)(i): pays the posted price for the sample if requested to do so; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(1)(d)(ii): receives a signed receipt from the person from whom the sample is taken; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(1)(e): have access to and copy all records of carriers in commerce showing:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(1)(e)(i): the movement in commerce of food;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(1)(e)(ii): the holding of food during or after movement in commerce; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(1)(e)(iii): the quantity, shipper, and consignee of food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(2): Evidence obtained under this section may not be used in a criminal prosecution of the person from whom the evidence was obtained.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(3): A carrier is subject to the other provisions of this chapter by reason of the carrier's receipt, carriage, holding, or delivery of food in the usual course of business as a carrier.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(4): After the inspection of a factory, warehouse, consulting laboratory, or other establishment and before leaving the premises, the authorized agent making the inspection shall give the owner, operator, or agent in charge a written report describing any conditions or practices observed by the agent during the inspection which, in the agent's judgment, indicate that a food in the establishment:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(4)(a): consists in whole or in part of a filthy, putrid, or decomposed substance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(4)(b): has been prepared, packed, or held under unsanitary conditions whereby the food may have become contaminated with filth or been rendered injurious to health.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(5): (4) A copy of the report required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(6): If the authorized agent making the inspection of a factory, warehouse, or other establishment has obtained a sample in the course of the inspection, the agent shall give to the owner, operator, or agent in charge:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(6)(a): a receipt describing the samples obtained; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-105(6)(b): if an analysis is made of the sample for the purpose of ascertaining whether the food consists in whole or in part of a filthy, putrid, or decomposed substance or is otherwise unfit for food, a copy of the results of the analysis.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-106 Publication of reports and information.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-106(1): The department shall publish reports summarizing all judgments, decrees, and court orders which have been rendered under this chapter, including the nature of the charge and its disposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-106(2): The department shall  disseminate information regarding food which it considers necessary in the interest of public health and for the protection of consumers against fraud.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-106(3): Nothing in this section prohibits the department from collecting, reporting, and illustrating the results of investigations made by the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201 Labeling requirements -- Misbranded food specified.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(1): The department may require that a label contain specific written, printed, or graphic information which is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(1)(a): displayed on the outside container or wrapper of a retail package of an article; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(1)(b): easily legible through the outside container or wrapper.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(2): 4-5-205 Food is misbranded if:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(2)(a): its label is false or misleading in any way;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(2)(b): 4-5-205 its labeling or packaging fails to conform with the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(2)(c): it is offered for sale under the name of another food;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(2)(d): its container is so made, formed, or filled with packing material or air as to be misleading; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(2)(e): it fails to conform with any requirement specified in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(3): A food that is an imitation of another food shall bear a label, in type of uniform size and prominence, stating the word "imitation," and, immediately thereafter, the name of the food imitated.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(4): (4)(a)(ii); (4)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(4)(a): A food in package form shall bear a label containing:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(4)(a)(i): the name and place of business of the manufacturer, packer, or distributor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(4)(a)(ii): an accurate statement of the quantity of the contents in terms of weight, measure, or numerical count.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(4)(b): (4)(a)(ii) The statement required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(4)(c): (4)(a)(i) A manufacturer or distributor of carbonated beverages who utilizes proprietary stock or a proprietary crown is exempt from Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(4)(c)(i): a sworn affidavit giving a full and complete description of each area within the state in which beverages of his manufacturing or distributing are to be distributed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(4)(c)(ii): the name and address of the person responsible for compliance with this chapter within each of those areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-201(5): Any word, statement, or other information required by this chapter to appear on the label or labeling shall be:

Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202 Adulterated or misbranded articles -- Tagging -- Detention or embargo -- Court proceedings for condemnation -- Perishable food.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(1): (1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(1)(a): (1)(b) When an authorized agent of the department finds or has probable cause to believe that any food is adulterated, or so misbranded as to be dangerous or fraudulent within the meaning of this chapter, the agents shall affix to the food a tag or other appropriate marking, giving notice that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(1)(a)(i): the food is, or is suspected of being, adulterated or misbranded;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(1)(a)(ii): the food has been detained or embargoed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(1)(a)(iii): (1)(b) removal of the food is prohibited as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(1)(b): No person may remove or dispose of detained or embargoed food by sale or otherwise until permission for removal or disposal is given by an agent of the department or the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(2)(a): (1) When food detained or embargoed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(2)(b): When the agent has found that food so detained or embargoed is not adulterated or misbranded, the department shall remove the tag or other marking.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(3)(a): If the court finds that detained or embargoed food is adulterated or misbranded, the food shall, after entry of the decree, be destroyed under the supervision of the agent.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(3)(b): If the adulteration or misbranding can be corrected by proper labeling or processing of the food, the court may by order direct that the food be delivered to the claimant for labeling or processing after:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(3)(b)(i): entry of the decree;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(3)(b)(ii): all costs, fees, and expenses have been paid; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(3)(b)(iii): a sufficient bond, conditioned that the food shall be properly labeled and processed, has been executed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(3)(c): An agent of the department shall supervise, at the claimant's expense, the labeling or processing of the food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(3)(d): The bond shall be returned to the claimant of the food upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(3)(d)(i): representation to the court by the department that the food is no longer in violation of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(3)(d)(ii): the expenses of supervision have been paid.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-202(4): If an authorized agent of the department finds in any building or vehicle any perishable food which is unsound, contains any filthy, decomposed, or putrid substance, or may be poisonous, deleterious to health, or otherwise unsafe, the commissioner or his authorized agent shall condemn or destroy the food or render it unsalable as human food.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-203 Food processed, labeled, or repacked at another location -- Exemption from labeling requirements by rule.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-203(1): The department shall adopt rules exempting food from any labeling requirement of this chapter that is, in accordance with the practice of the trade, to be processed, labeled or repacked in substantial quantities at establishments other than those where originally processed or packed, on condition that the food is not adulterated or misbranded under this chapter upon removal from such processing, labeling or repacking establishment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-203(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-203(2)(a): (1) Regulations now or hereafter adopted under authority of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 301 et seq., relating to the exemptions described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-203(2)(b): The department may adopt additional rules or amendments to existing rules concerning exemptions.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204 Substances considered unsafe -- Authority in department to regulate quantity and use.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(1): 4-5-103(1)(b); 4-5-104; 4-5-103(1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(1)(a): 4-5-103(1)(b); 4-5-104 Any added poisonous or deleterious substance, any food additive, any pesticide chemical in or on a raw agricultural commodity or any color additive, with respect to any particular use or intended use, is considered to be unsafe for the purpose of application of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(1)(a)(i): 4-5-104 there is in effect a rule adopted pursuant to this section or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(1)(a)(ii): the use or intended use of the substance conforms to the terms prescribed by the rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(1)(b): 4-5-103(1)(a) While the rules relating to  the substance are in effect, a food may not, by reason of bearing or containing the substance in accordance with the rules, be considered adulterated within the meaning of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(2): The department may make rules, which may or may not be in accordance with regulations  made under the federal act, prescribing:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(2)(a): tolerances, including zero tolerances, for:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(2)(a)(i): added poisonous or deleterious substances;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(2)(a)(ii): food additives;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(2)(a)(iii): pesticide chemicals in or on raw agricultural commodities; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(2)(a)(iv): color additives;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(2)(b): exemptions from tolerances in the case of pesticide chemicals in or on raw agricultural commodities; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(2)(c): conditions under which a food additive or a color additive may be safely used and exemptions when a food additive or color additive may be used solely for investigational or experimental purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(3)(a): The department may make these rules upon its own initiative or upon the petition of any interested party.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(3)(b): It is incumbent upon the petitioner to establish by data submitted to the department that the rule is necessary to protect the public health.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(3)(c): If the data furnished by the petitioner is not sufficient to allow the department to determine whether the rule should be made, the department may require additional data to be submitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(3)(d): Failure to comply with the request is sufficient grounds to deny the request.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4): In making the rules, the department shall consider, among other relevant factors, the following which the petitioner, if any, shall furnish:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(a): the name and all pertinent information concerning the substance including:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(a)(i): where available;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(a)(ii): its chemical identity and composition;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(a)(iii): a statement of the conditions of the proposed use, including directions, recommendations, and suggestions;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(a)(iv): specimens of proposed labeling; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(a)(v): all relevant data bearing on the physical or other technical effect and the quantity required to produce such effect;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(b): the probable composition of any substance formed in or on a food resulting from the use of the substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(c): the probable consumption of the substance in the diet of man and animals, taking into account any chemically or pharmacologically related substance in the diet;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(d): safety factors which, in the opinion of experts qualified by scientific training and experience to evaluate the safety of  the substances for the uses for which they are proposed to be used, are generally recognized as appropriate for the use of animal experimentation data;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(e): the availability of any needed practicable methods of analysis for determining the identity and quantity of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(e)(i): the substance in or on food;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(e)(ii): any substance formed in or on food because of the use of the substance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(e)(iii): the pure substance and all intermediates and impurities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-204(4)(f): facts supporting a contention that the proposed use of  the substance will serve a useful purpose.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-205(3): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-205(3)(a): (1) No person shall distribute or cause to be distributed in commerce any packaged consumer commodity if any qualifying words or phrases appear in conjunction with the separate statement of the net quantity of contents required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-205(3)(b): Supplemental statements of net quantity of contents may not include any term qualifying a unit of weight, measure, or count that tends to exaggerate the amount of the commodity contained in the package.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-205(4): (1); (4); (4); (4)(a)(iv)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-205(4)(a): (1); (4); (4) Whenever the department determines that rules other than those prescribed by Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-205(4)(a)(ii): regulate the placement upon any package containing any commodity, or upon any label affixed to a commodity, of any printed matter stating or representing by implication that the commodity is offered for retail sale at a price lower than the ordinary and customary retail sale price or that a retail sale price advantage is accorded to purchasers by reason of the size of that package or the quantity of its contents;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-205(4)(a)(iii): (4) require that the label on each package of a consumer commodity bear:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-205(4)(a)(iii)(A): the common or usual name of such consumer commodity, if any; and

Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-206 Food advertisement false or misleading.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
An advertisement of a food is considered to be false if it is false or misleading in any way.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-207 Definitions and standards of identity, quality, and fill of container -- Rules -- Temporary and special permits.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-207(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-207(1)(a): Definitions and standards of identity, quality and fill of container, now or hereafter adopted under authority of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 301 et seq., are the definitions and standards of identity, quality and fill of container in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-207(1)(b): The department may adopt rules establishing definitions and standards of identity, quality and fill of container for foods where no federal regulations exist and may promulgate amendments to any federal regulations or state rules that set definitions and standards of identity, quality and fill of container for foods.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-207(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-207(2)(a): Temporary permits granted for interstate shipment of experimental packs of food varying from the requirements of federal definitions and standards of identity are automatically effective in this state under the conditions provided in the permits.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-207(2)(b): The department may issue additional permits where they are necessary for the completion or conclusiveness of an otherwise adequate investigation and where the interests of consumers are safeguarded.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-207(2)(c): Permits are subject to the terms and conditions the department may prescribe by rule.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-402 Defenses.
---------------------------------------
No publisher, radio-broadcast licensee, or agency or medium for the dissemination of an advertisement, except the manufacturer, packer, distributor, or seller of the article to which a false advertisement relates, shall be liable under this section by reason of the dissemination of such false advertisement, unless he has refused, on the request of the department to furnish it, the name and post-office address of the manufacturer, packer, distributor, seller, or advertising agency, residing in the state of Utah who caused him to disseminate such advertisement.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501 Cottage food operations.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(1): For purposes of this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(1)(a): "Cottage food operation" means a person  who produces a cottage food product in a home kitchen .
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(1)(b): "Cottage food product" means a nonpotentially hazardous baked good, jam, jelly, or other nonpotentially hazardous food produced in a home kitchen.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(1)(c): "Home kitchen" means a kitchen:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(1)(c)(i): designed and intended for use by the residents of a home; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(1)(c)(ii): used by a resident of the home for the production of a cottage food product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(1)(d): "Potentially hazardous food" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(1)(d)(i): a food of animal origin;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(1)(d)(ii): raw seed sprouts; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(1)(d)(iii): a food that requires time or temperature control, or both, for safety to limit pathogenic microorganism growth or toxin formation, as identified by the department in rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(2): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The department shall adopt rules pursuant to
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(3): (2) Rules adopted pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(3)(a): the use of a commercial surface such as a stainless steel counter or cabinet;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(3)(b): the use of a commercial grade:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(3)(b)(i): sink;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(3)(b)(ii): dishwasher; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(3)(b)(iii): oven;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(3)(c): a separate kitchen for the cottage food operation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(3)(d): the submission of plans and specifications before construction of, or remodel of, a cottage food production operation.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(4): The operator of a cottage food operation shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(4)(a): register with the department as a cottage food operation before operating as a cottage food operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(4)(b): hold a valid food handler's permit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(4)(c): package a cottage food product with a label, as specified by the department in rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(5): 4-5-301(1)(a); (c) Notwithstanding the provisions of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(5)(a): pays the fees required by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(5)(b): meets the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(6): 26A-1-114 Notwithstanding the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(6)(a): does not have jurisdiction to regulate the production of food at a cottage food operation operating in compliance with this section, as long as the products are not offered to the public for consumption on the premises; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-501(6)(b): does have jurisdiction to investigate a cottage food operation in an investigation into the cause of a foodborne illness outbreak.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-502 Food designated as raw honey.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-502(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-502(1)(a): "Honey" means the natural sweet substance produced by honeybees from nectar of plants or from secretions of living parts of plants that the bees collect, transform by combining with specific substances of their own, then deposit, dehydrate, store, and leave in the honeycomb to ripen and mature.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-502(1)(b): "Raw honey" means honey:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-502(1)(b)(i): as it exists in the beehive or as obtained by extraction, settling, or straining;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-502(1)(b)(ii): that is minimally processed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-502(1)(b)(iii): that is not pasteurized.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-502(2): Honey that is produced, packed, repacked, distributed, or sold in this state may only be labeled and designated as raw honey if it meets:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-502(2)(a): the definition of raw honey in this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5-502(2)(b): any additional requirements imposed by the department by rule.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 5a - Home Consumption and Homemade Food Act
***********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Home Consumption and Homemade Food Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
For purposes of this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(1)(a): "Commercial establishment" means a wholesale or retail business that displays, sells, manufactures, processes, packs, holds, or stores food, drugs, devices, or cosmetics.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(1)(b): "Commercial establishment" does not include a:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(1)(b)(i): direct-to-sale location; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(1)(b)(ii): direct-to-sale farmers market.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(2): "Direct-to-sale farmers market" means a public or private facility or area where producers gather on a regular basis to sell directly to an informed final consumer fresh food, locally grown products, and other food items that have not been certified, licensed, regulated, or inspected by state or local authorities.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(3): "Direct-to-sale location" means a farm, ranch, direct-to-sale farmers market, home, office, or any location agreed upon by both a producer and the informed final consumer where a producer sells a food or food product to an informed final consumer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(4): "Home consumption" means the use or ingestion of homemade food or a homemade food product within a private home by a family member, an employee, or a nonpaying guest.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(5): 4-5a-105(1) "Homemade food product" means a food product that is prepared in a private home kitchen that can be used, or prepared for use, as food or nonalcoholic drink, subject to the limitation described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(6): "Informed final consumer" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(6)(a): purchases the product directly from the producer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(6)(b): does not resell the product; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(6)(c): has been informed that the product is not certified, licensed, regulated, or inspected by the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(7): "Minor-operated business" means a business that is operated by an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(7)(a): under 18 years old; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(7)(b): not regularly engaged in selling items.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(8): "Minor producer" means a producer that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(8)(a): an individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(8)(b): under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-102(9): "Producer" means a person who harvests or produces homemade food or a homemade food product.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105 Limitations.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105(1): This chapter does not apply to the sale of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105(1)(a): raw dairy or raw dairy products; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105(1)(b): meat products, with the following exceptions:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105(1)(b)(i): the sale of poultry and poultry products if the producer:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105(1)(b)(i)(A): slaughters no more than 1,000 birds per year in accordance with the United States Department of Agriculture 1,000 bird exemption; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105(1)(b)(i)(B): follows the United States Department of Agriculture's, Food Safety and Inspection Service document titled "Guidance for Determining Whether A Poultry Slaughter or Processing Operation is Exempt from Inspection Requirements of the Poultry Products Inspection Act"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105(1)(b)(ii): the sale of domesticated rabbit meat, pending approval from the United States Department of Agriculture that the state's role in meat inspection is preserved.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105(2): Nothing in this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105(2)(a): means that the department relinquishes its authority to administer the state's program at a standard level at least equal to the standards imposed under the Federal Meat and Poultry Products Inspection Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105(2)(b): shall be construed to impede the Department of Health in an investigation of foodborne illness;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105(2)(c): prohibits a state agency from providing assistance, consulting, or inspecting when requested by a producer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105(2)(d): affects the authority of the Department of Health or the Department of Agriculture and Food to certify, license, regulate, or inspect food or food products that are not exempt from certification, licensing, regulation, or inspection as described in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-5a-105(3): The department may not, by rule, impose an additional limit, requirement, or restriction on a producer selling food or a food product under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 7 - Livestock Dealers' Act
******************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-101 Title.
------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Livestock Dealers' Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-102 Purpose declaration.
--------------------------------------------------
The Legislature finds that the public interest requires regulation of the sale of livestock between the producer and a person who purchases livestock for resale to protect the producer from unwarranted hazard and loss in the sale of livestock.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(1): 4-30-102 "Agent" means a person who, on behalf of a dealer, purchaser, or livestock market, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(2): "Consignor" means a person who ships or delivers livestock to a dealer for handling or sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(3)(a): "Dealer" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(3)(a)(i): receives livestock from a person for sale on commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(3)(a)(ii): is entrusted with the possession, management, control, or disposal of livestock for the account of that person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(3)(a)(iii): negotiates price, determines a delivery date, and receives money on behalf of a livestock producer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(3)(b): "Dealer" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(3)(b)(i): a livestock dealer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(3)(b)(ii): a person who owns or leases a feedlot.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(4)(a): "Immediate resale" means the resale of livestock within 60 days of purchase.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(4)(b): "Immediate resale" does not include the resale of livestock culled within 60 days that were purchased for feeding or replacement.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(5): 4-39-102 "Livestock" means cattle, swine, equines, sheep, camelidae, ratites, bison, goats, and domesticated elk as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(6): "Livestock dealer" means a person engaged in the business of purchasing livestock for immediate resale or interstate shipment for immediate resale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-103(7): "Producer" means a person who is primarily engaged in the business of raising livestock for profit.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-104 Unlawful to act as an agent or dealer without license -- Exception.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except as exempted by Section

Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-105 Exemptions.
-----------------------------------------
The surety and licensing requirements of this chapter do not apply to:Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-105(1): Title 4, Chapter 30, Livestock Markets a livestock market that is bonded as required by laws of the United States and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-105(2): a cooperative incorporated under the laws of this state or another state, except as to the receipt of livestock from a nonmember producer.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-106 Licenses -- Applications.
-------------------------------------------------------
Application for an agent's or dealer's license shall be made to the department upon forms prescribed and furnished by the department, and the application shall state:Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-106(1): the applicant's name, principal address in this state, and age;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-106(2): the applicant's principal address in any location outside Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-106(3): the name and principal address of the person authorized by the applicant to accept service of process in this state on behalf of the applicant during the licensure period;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-106(4): the name and principal address of the applicant's surety if the application is for a dealer's license;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-106(5): a schedule of the commissions, fees, and other charges the applicant intends to collect for services during the period of licensure;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-106(6): the name and address of each principal the applicant intends to represent during the period of licensure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-106(7): any other information that the department may require by rule.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107 Issuance of dealer and agent licenses -- Fees -- Deposit of bond or trust agreement -- Renewal -- Refusal to issue or renew license.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(1): 4-2-103(2); 4-7-108 The commissioner, if satisfied that the convenience and necessity of the industry and the public will be served, shall issue a license to a dealer within 30 days after:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(1)(a): receipt of a proper application and financial statement;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(1)(b): 4-2-103(2) payment of a license fee determined by the department pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(1)(c): 4-7-108 the posting of a corporate surety bond, an irrevocable letter of credit, a trust fund agreement, or other security required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(2): 4-2-103(2) Upon proper application and payment of the license fee determined by the department pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(3): 4-2-103(2) A license issued under this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(3)(a): entitles the applicant to conduct the business described in the application through December 31 of the year in which the license is issued, subject to suspension or revocation for cause; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(3)(b): 4-2-103(2) is renewable for a period of one year upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(3)(b)(i): receipt of a proper renewal application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(3)(b)(ii): 4-2-103(2) payment of an annual license renewal fee determined by the department pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(4): A license issued under this chapter shall at all times remain the property of the state, and the licensee is entitled to the license only for the duration of the license.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(5): The department shall refuse to issue or renew a license if the applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(5)(a): cannot produce a financial statement with sufficient assets to justify the amount of business the applicant contemplates, unless the application is for an agent's license;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(5)(b): is in violation of this chapter or rules adopted under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(5)(c): has made a false or misleading statement as to the health or physical condition of livestock in connection with the buying, receiving, selling, exchanging, soliciting or negotiating the sale of, or the weighing of livestock;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(5)(d): has failed to keep records of purchases and sales or refused to grant inspection of those records by authorized agents of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(5)(e): has failed to comply with a lawful order of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(5)(f): has been found by the department to have failed to pay, without reasonable cause, obligations incurred in connection with the livestock transaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(5)(g): has been suspended by order of the secretary of agriculture of the United States Department of Agriculture under provisions of the Packers and Stockyards Act, 1921, 7 U.S.C. Sec. 181 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(5)(h): employs a person required to be licensed whose license cannot be renewed or whose license is under suspension or revocation by the department or the United States Department of Agriculture; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(5)(i): has any unsatisfied civil judgments related to an activity for which licensing is required by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-107(6): An applicant who has been refused a license or license renewal may not apply again for one year following refusal unless the department determines that the applicant is in compliance with this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108 Applicant for dealer's license to post security -- Increase in amount of security posted -- Action on security authorized -- Duties of commissioner -- Option to require posting new security if action filed -- Effect of failure to post new security -- Commissioner's authority to call bond if not renewed.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(1)(a): Before a license is issued to a dealer, the applicant shall post a corporate surety bond, irrevocable letter of credit, trust fund agreement, or any other security agreement considered reasonable in an amount not less than $10,000, as determined by the commissioner or as required by the Packers and Stockyards Act, 1921, 7 U.S.C. Sec. 181 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(1)(b): Any bond shall be written by a surety licensed under the laws of Utah and name the state, as obligee, for the use and benefit of producers.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(1)(c): The bond or other security posted shall be conditioned upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(1)(c)(i): the faithful performance of contracts and the faithful accounting for and handling of livestock consigned to the dealer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(1)(c)(ii): the performance of the obligations imposed under this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(1)(c)(iii): the payment of court costs and attorney fees to the prevailing party incident to any suit upon the bond or other security posted.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(2): (1)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a)
