Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(2)(c): (2)(a) The commissioner may suspend a dealer's license for failure to comply with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(3): A consignor claiming damages, as a result of fraud, deceit, or willful negligence by a dealer or as a result of the dealer's failure to comply with this chapter, may bring an action upon the bond or other security posted for damages against both the principal and surety.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(4)(a): If it is reported to the department by a consignor that a dealer has failed to pay in a timely manner for livestock received for sale, the commissioner shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(4)(a)(i): ascertain the name and address of each consignor who is a creditor of the dealer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(4)(a)(ii): request a verified written statement setting forth the amount claimed due from the dealer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(4)(b): Upon receipt of the verified statements, the commissioner shall bring an action upon the bond or other security posted on behalf of the consignors who claim amounts due from the dealer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(5): (5)(a); (5)(c)(i)

Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(5)(c): (5)(c)(i)

Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(5)(c)(ii): (5)(c)(i) A suspension described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-108(5)(d): If the bond or other security posted under this section is not renewed within 10 days of its expiration date, unless the commissioner states in writing that this is unnecessary, the commissioner may obtain, after a hearing, the full amount of the bond or other security before it expires.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109 Dealers -- Records mandated -- Records subject to inspection.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(1): A dealer who receives livestock for sale or consignment shall promptly record:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(1)(a): the name and address of the consignor;

Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(1)(f): an itemized statement of the charges to be paid by the producer-consignor;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(1)(g): the individual or group identification of the livestock;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(1)(h): the nature and amount of any claims the dealer has against third persons for overcharges or damages; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(1)(i): if the dealer has a direct or indirect financial interest in the business of the purchaser, or, if the purchaser has a similar financial interest in the business of the dealer, the name and address of the purchaser.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(2)(a): The dealer shall provide a copy of the livestock receipt to the producer immediately upon delivery of the product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(2)(b): The records required by this section shall be retained for a period of one year following the date of consignment and shall be available during business hours for inspection by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(2)(c): A consignor involved in a consignment subject to inquiry may inspect relevant records.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(3): (1); (3)(b); (3); (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(3)(a): (1) A dealer shall file an annual report of the records required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(3)(b): The dealer shall file the report by April 15 following the end of a calendar year, or if the records are kept on a fiscal year basis, by 90 days after the close of the fiscal year.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(3)(c): (3)(b) The commissioner may, for good cause shown or by the commissioner's own motion, grant an extension to the filing deadline under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-109(3)(d): (3) For purposes of this Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-110 Livestock purchases.
--------------------------------------------------
Livestock purchases shall be paid for as provided in the Packers and Stockyards Act, 1921, 7 U.S.C. Sec. 181, et seq.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201 Department authority -- Examination and investigation of transactions -- Notice of agency action upon probable cause -- Settlement of disputes -- Cease and desist order -- Enforcement -- Review.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(1): For the purpose of enforcing this chapter the department may, upon the department's own motion, or shall, upon the verified complaint of an interested consignor, investigate, examine, or inspect any transaction involving:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(1)(a): the solicitation, receipt, sale, or attempted sale of livestock by a dealer or person assuming to act as a dealer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(1)(b): the failure to make a correct account of sales;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(1)(c): the intentional making of a false statement about market conditions or the condition or quantity of livestock consigned;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(1)(d): the failure to remit payment in a timely manner to the consignor as required by contract or by this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(1)(e): any other consignment transaction alleged to have resulted in damage to the consignor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(1)(f): any dealer or agent with an unsatisfied judgment by a civil court related to an activity for which licensing is required by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(2)(a): After investigation upon the department's own motion, if the department determines that probable cause exists to believe that a dealer has engaged, or is engaging, in acts that violate this chapter, the department shall issue a notice of agency action.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(2)(b)(i): Upon the receipt of a verified complaint, the department shall undertake to effect a settlement between the consignor and the dealer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(2)(b)(ii): If a settlement cannot be effected, the department shall treat the verified complaint as a request for agency action.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(3)(a): In a hearing upon a verified complaint, if the commissioner, or hearing officer designated by the commissioner, determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the person complained of has violated this chapter and that the violation has resulted in damage to the complainant, the commissioner or officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(3)(a)(i): prepare written findings of fact detailing the findings and fixing the amount of damage suffered; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(3)(a)(ii): order the defendant to pay damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(3)(b): In a hearing initiated upon the department's own motion, if the commissioner or hearing officer determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the person complained of by the department has engaged, or is engaging, in acts that violate this chapter, the commissioner or officer shall prepare written findings of fact and an order requiring the person to cease and desist from the activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(4): The department may petition any court having jurisdiction in the county where the action complained of occurred to enforce the department's order.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(5): Any dealer aggrieved by an order issued under this section may obtain judicial review of the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(6)(a): The department may not act upon a verified complaint submitted to the department more than six months after the consignor allegedly suffered damage.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-201(6)(b): A livestock claim shall be made in writing within 120 days from the date of the transaction.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-202 Sale of livestock -- Prima facie evidence of fraud.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The following constitutes prima facie evidence of fraud in the sale of livestock:Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-202(1): any sale of livestock at less than market price by a dealer to a person with whom the dealer has a financial interest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-202(2): any sale out of which the dealer receives part of the sale price other than the agreed commission or other agreed charges.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-203 Suspension or revocation -- Grounds -- Notice to producers.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-203(1): The department may suspend or revoke the license of and suspend or refuse all department services to a person licensed under this chapter if the department finds that the licensee has:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-203(1)(a): provided false information when making an application for a license;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-203(1)(b): failed to comply with this chapter or rules adopted under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-203(1)(c): engaged in any willful conduct that is detrimental to a producer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-203(2): If a license is revoked pursuant to a hearing and the decision is final, or an injunction is imposed by a civil court, the department shall, by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the area, notify producers of livestock in the area in which the licensee operated that the license has been revoked or a department action has been taken.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-204 Suspension of license -- Opportunity for hearing.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-204(1): The department may suspend a license immediately if:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-204(1)(a): an emergency exists that presents a clear and present danger to the public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-204(1)(b): an inspection or sampling is refused; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-204(1)(c): the licensee's bond has been revoked or cancelled.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-204(2): The department shall immediately notify the person of the suspension in writing and provide an opportunity for hearing without delay.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-205 Prohibited acts.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-205(1): 4-7-109; 4-7-110 A person licensed under this chapter may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-205(1)(a): make false charges incident to the sale of livestock;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-205(1)(b): 4-7-109; 4-7-110 willfully fail to comply with the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-205(1)(c): fail to file a schedule of commissions and charges;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-205(1)(d): reconsign livestock without the consent of the producer-consignor for the purpose of charging more than one commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-205(1)(e): make any false statement to the detriment of the producer regarding current market conditions for livestock or about the condition or quantity of the livestock consigned for the account of the producer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-205(1)(f): engage in fraud or misrepresentation in the procurement or attempted procurement of a license; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-205(1)(g): act as a dealer or agent and, with intent to defraud, make, draw, utter, or deliver any check, draft, or order for the payment of money from any bank or other depository to the owner for the purchase price of livestock, when at the time of the making, drawing, uttering, or delivery the maker or drawer does not have sufficient funds in or credit with the bank or other depository for the payment of the check, draft, or order in full upon its presentation.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-205(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-205(2)(a): The making, drawing, uttering, or delivery of a check, draft, or order in the circumstances specified in this section shall be evidence of an intent to defraud.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-7-205(2)(b): As used in this section, "credit" means an arrangement or understanding with the bank or depository for the payment of the check, draft, or order.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 8 - Agricultural Fair Trade Act
***********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-101 Title.
------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Agricultural Fair Trade Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-102 Purpose declaration.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-102(1): The Legislature finds and declares that in order to preserve the agricultural industry of this state it is necessary to protect and improve the economic status of persons engaged in the production of products of agriculture.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-102(2): (1) To carry out the policy described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-102(3): This chapter shall be liberally construed.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-103 Definition.
-----------------------------------------
As used in this chapter, "products of agriculture" means any product useful to the human species that results from the application of the science and art of the production of plants, minerals, and animals.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-104 Department functions, powers, and duties.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall exercise the following functions, powers, and duties, in addition to those specified inUtah Code Annotated § 4-8-104(1): perform general supervision over the marketing, sale, trade, advertising, storage, and transportation practices, used in buying and selling products of agriculture in Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-104(2): conduct and publish surveys and statistical analyses with the department's own resources or with the resources of others through contract, regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-104(2)(a): the cost of production for products of agriculture, including transportation, processing, storage, advertising, and marketing costs;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-104(2)(b): market locations, demands, and prices for such products; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-104(2)(c): market forecasts;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-104(3): assist and encourage producers of products of agriculture in controlling current and prospective production and market deliveries in order to stabilize product prices at prices that assure reasonable profits for producers and at the same time ensure adequate market supplies;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-104(4): actively solicit input from the public and from interested groups or associations, through public hearings or otherwise, to assist in making fair determinations with respect to the production, marketing, and consumption of products of agriculture;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-104(5): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act make rules, in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-105 Unlawful acts specified.
------------------------------------------------------
A person engaged in the production, processing, handling, marketing, sale or distribution of products of agriculture may not:Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-105(1): discriminate in price between two or more producers with respect to products of agriculture of like grade and quality;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-105(2): use any brand, label, container, or designation on products of agriculture not authorized by the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-105(3): promote or advertise the price of any product of agriculture that is required to be graded without displaying the grade of such product with prominence equal to that of the price; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-105(4): make or permit the use of any false or misleading statement on any label or stencil affixed to a container or package containing products of agriculture or in any promotion or advertisement of such products.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-106 Procedure for enforcement -- Notice of agency action -- Cease and desist order -- Enforcement -- Judicial review.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-106(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-106(1)(a): Whenever the department has reason to believe that a person has, or is, engaged in the violation of this chapter, it shall issue a notice of agency action.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-106(1)(b): If the commissioner, or a hearing officer designated by the commissioner, determines by a preponderance of the evidence that any person named in the complaint has engaged, or is engaging, in an act that violates this chapter, the officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-106(1)(b)(i): prepare written findings of fact; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-106(1)(b)(ii): issue an order requiring the person to cease and desist from the illegal activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-106(2): The department may petition any court of competent jurisdiction for enforcement of its cease and desist order.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-106(3): Any person who is subject to a cease and desist order may obtain judicial review.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-106(4): The attorney general's office shall represent the department in any original action or appeal begun under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-8-107 Defense to claim of illegal activity.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
No person who acts in compliance with any rule adopted under authority of this chapter shall be considered to be engaged in any illegal conspiracy or combination in restraint of trade or to be acting in furtherance of any illegal purpose.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 9 - Weights and Measures
****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-101 Title.
------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Weights and Measures."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-102 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-102(1): "Correct" means conformance to applicable requirements of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-102(2): "Package" means a commodity put up or packaged before sale in either wholesale or retail saleunits.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-102(3): 4-9-105 "Primary standards" means the physical standards of the state, described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-102(4): "Sale from bulk" means the sale of commodities, when the quantity is determined at the time of sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-102(5): "Secondary standards" means a physical standard which is traceable to primary standards through comparisons, using acceptable laboratory procedures.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-102(6): "Weighing and measuring" means the use of weights and measures.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-102(7): "Weight" means net weight, unless the label declares that the product is sold by drained weight, in which case "weight" means net drained weight.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-102(8): "Weights and measures" means the instruments or devices used for weighing or measuring, including an appliance or accessory associated with the instrument or device.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-102(9): "Weights and measures registration" means the issuance of a certificate by the commissioner to a weights and measures user.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-102(10): "Weights and measures user" means a person who uses weights and measures in trade or commerce.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-103 Authority to make rules.
------------------------------------------------------
The department is authorized, subject to

Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-104 Weights and measures -- Systems used -- Basic units, tables, and equivalents as published by National Institute of Standards and Technology.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-104(1): The department shall use:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-104(1)(a): the same system of weights and measures that is customarily used in the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-104(1)(b): the metric system of weights and measures.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-104(2): (1) Either system under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-104(3): The definitions of basic units of weight and measure, the tables of weight and measure, and the weights and measures equivalents published by the National Institute of Standards and Technology shall determine the weights and measures systems used within the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-105 Weights and measures -- Primary state standards -- Secondary state standards -- Verification.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-105(1): Weights and measures that are traceable to the United States prototype standards supplied by the federal government, or approved as being satisfactory by the National Institute of Standards and Technology, shall be the state primary standards, and shall be maintained in the calibration prescribed by the National Institute of Standards and Technology.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-105(2): Secondary standards may be prescribed by the department and shall be verified upon their initial receipt, and as often after initial receipt as is considered necessary by the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-106 Weights and measures -- Specifications, tolerances, and technical data published in National Institute of Standards and Technology Handbook govern.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Unless modified by the department, Handbook 44, Specifications, Tolerances, and Other Technical Requirements for Weighing and Measuring Devices, National Institute of Standards and Technology, adopted by the National Conference on Weights and Measures, including supplements or revisions to Handbook 44, shall determine the specifications, tolerances, and other technical requirements for devices used for:Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-106(1): commercial weighing and measuring;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-106(2): law enforcement;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-106(3): data gathering; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-106(4): other weighing and measuring purposes.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-107 Adopting uniform packaging and labeling regulation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Unless modified by the department, the Uniform Packaging and Labeling Regulation, adopted by the National Conference on Weights and Measures in Handbook 130, Uniform Laws and Regulations in the Areas of Legal Metrology and Engine Fuel Quality, National Institute of Standards and Technology, shall apply to packaging and labeling in the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-108 Adopting uniform regulation for the method of sale of commodities.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Unless modified by the department, the Uniform Regulation for the Method of Sale of Commodities, adopted by the National Conference on Weights and Measures, in Handbook 130, Uniform Laws and Regulations in the Areas of Legal Metrology and Engine Fuel Quality, National Institute of Standards and Technology, shall apply to the method of sale of commodities in the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-109 Adopting uniform regulation for the voluntary registration of servicepersons and service agencies for commercial weighing and measuring devices.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Unless modified by the department, the Uniform Regulation for the Voluntary Registration of Servicepersons and Service Agencies for Commercial Weighing and Measuring Devices, adopted by the National Conference on Weights and Measures in Handbook 130, Uniform Laws and Regulations in the Areas of Legal Metrology and Engine Fuel Quality, National Institute of Standards and Technology, shall apply to the registration of servicepersons and service agencies in the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110 Department duties -- Seizure of incorrect weights and measures.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1): 4-2-103(2) The department may:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(a): establish weights and measures standards, specifications, and tolerances for:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(a)(i): all commodities;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(a)(ii): the  fill for any commodity contained in a package;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(a)(iii): labels or labeling of a commodity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(a)(iv): weights and measures used commercially;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(b): inspect and test weights and measures kept, offered, or exposed for sale to determine if they are correct;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(c): inspect and test weights and measures commercially used to determine if they are correct;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(d): test all weights and measures used to check the receipt or disbursement of supplies used by a state agency or institution funded by the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(e): in accordance with sampling procedures recognized and designated in Handbook 133, Checking the Net Contents of Packaged Goods, National Institute of Standards and Technology, inspect and test any packaged commodity kept, offered, or exposed for sale, sold, or in the process of delivery, to determine if the package contains the amount represented;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(f): determine the appropriate term or unit of weight or measure to be used for container sizes, if the department determines that an existing practice of declaring the quantity by weight, measure, count, or any combination of these practices, hinders value comparisons by consumers;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(g): approve correct weights and measures and reject and mark as "rejected," weights and measures that are incorrect;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(h): allow reasonable variations from a stated weight or measure caused by loss or gain due to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(h)(i): moisture during the course of acceptable distribution practices; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(h)(ii): unavoidable deviations in acceptable manufacturing practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(i): grant an exemption from the requirements of this chapter or from any rule promulgated under this chapter, when the department determines that the exemption is necessary for the maintenance of acceptable commercial practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(j): maintain on file, for public inspection, a copy of each handbook prepared by the National Institute of Standards and Technology that is used to enforce this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(1)(k): 4-2-103(2) establish and charge fees as authorized under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(2): The department may seize weights and measures that are:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(2)(a): incorrect and are not corrected within a reasonable time specified by the department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-110(2)(b): used or disposed of in a manner not authorized by the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111 Enforcement powers of department.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111(1): For the purpose of enforcing this chapter, the department may:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111(1)(a): enter any commercial premises during normal working hours after the presentation of credentials;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111(1)(b): issue in writing a "stop-use, hold, or removal order" with respect to any weights or measures commercially used or a "stop sale, use, or removal order" with respect to any packaged commodity or bulk commodity offered for sale;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111(1)(c): seize as evidence, without formal warrant, any incorrect or unapproved weight, measure, package, or commodity offered for sale or sold in violation of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111(1)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111(1)(d)(i): seek an order of seizure or condemnation of any weight, measure, package, or sale from bulk that violates this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111(1)(d)(ii): upon proper grounds, obtain a temporary restraining order or permanent injunction to prevent a violation of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111(1)(e): stop any commercial vehicle and after presenting credentials:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111(1)(e)(i): inspect its contents;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111(1)(e)(ii): require the person in charge of the vehicle to produce any documents in his possession concerning the contents; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111(1)(e)(iii): require the person in charge of the vehicle to proceed with the vehicle to some specified place for inspection.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111(2): (1)(b) If an order has been issued under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-111(3): A bond may not be required of the department in any injunctive proceeding brought under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-112 Sale of commodities in liquid form -- Sale of commodities in nonliquid form -- Requirements.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-112(1): Commodities in liquid form shall be sold by liquid measure or by weight.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-112(2): Commodities not in liquid form shall be sold only by weight, measure, or by count, as long as the method of sale provides accurate quantity information.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-113 Bulk sales -- Information furnished to purchaser.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whenever the quantity is determined solely by the seller, in the absence of the buyer, all bulk sales of heating fuel and other bulk sales as determined by the department shall be accompanied by a delivery ticket containing the following information:Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-113(1): the name and address of the vendor and purchaser;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-113(2): the date delivered;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-113(3): the quantity delivered and the quantity upon which the price is based, if different from the delivered quantity;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-113(4): a description of the bulk material sold, including any quality representation made in connection with the sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-113(5): the number of individually wrapped packages.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-114 Packaged commodity sales -- Labeling information specified -- When price per single unit of weight to be displayed.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-114(1): Any packaged commodity offered for sale shall bear on the outside of the package a definite, plain, and conspicuous declaration of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-114(1)(a): the identity of the commodity in the package, unless the same can easily be identified through the wrapper or container;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-114(1)(b): the quantity of contents in terms of weight, measure, or count; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-114(1)(c): the name and place of business of the manufacturer, packer, or distributor, if the packaged commodity is offered for sale, or sold other than on the premises where packaged.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-114(2): (1) Any package that is one of a lot containing random weights of the same commodity and bearing the total sales price of the package shall, in addition to compliance with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-115 Advertisement of packaged commodity sales -- Requirements.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-115(1): An advertisement that promotes a packaged commodity with the retail price stated shall plainly and conspicuously advertise the quantity required to appear on the package.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-115(2): If a dual quantity declaration is required by law, only the declaration that sets forth the quantity in terms of the smaller unit of weight or measure shall appear in the advertisement.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-116 Unlawful acts specified.
------------------------------------------------------
A person may not:Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-116(1): sell, offer, or present for sale a commodity whose weight and measure is less than the weight and measure represented as being sold, offered, or exposed for sale;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-116(2): misrepresent the price of a commodity sold, advertised, exposed, or offered for sale by weight, measure, or count, or represent the price in a manner that misleads or deceives a person;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-116(3): use or possess an incorrect weight or measure in commerce;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-116(4): remove a tag, seal, or mark from a weight or measure without specific written authorization from the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-116(5): hinder or obstruct an agent of the department dealing with weights and measures in the performance of the agent's duties; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-116(6): operate weights and measures in trade or commerce for the purpose of determining the weight or measure of a commodity without a valid weights and measures registration issued by the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-117 Weighing and measuring devices -- Presumption.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a weighing or measuring device is in a place where buying or selling is commonly carried on, there is a rebuttable presumption that the weighing or measuring device is regularly used for the business purposes of that place.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-118 Registration of commercial establishments using weights and measures.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-118(1): determine whether weights and measures are correct through:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-118(1)(a): inspection and testing by a department employee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-118(1)(b): acceptance of an inspection and testing report prepared by a registered weights and measures service person;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-118(2): establish standards and qualifications for a registered weights and measures service person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-9-118(3): determine the form and content of an inspection and testing report.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 10 - Bedding, Upholstered Furniture, and Quilted Clothing Inspection Act
****************************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Bedding, Upholstered Furniture, and Quilted Clothing Inspection Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(1): "Article" means bedding, upholstered furniture, quilted clothing, or filling material.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(2): "Bedding" means a:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(2)(a): quilted, packing, mattress, or hammock pad; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(2)(b): mattress, boxspring, comforter, quilt, sleeping bag, studio couch, pillow, or cushion made with a filling material that can be used for sleeping or reclining.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(3): "Consumer" means a person who purchases, rents, or leases an article for the article's intended, everyday use.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(4): "Filling material" means cotton, wool, kapok, feathers, down, shoddy, hair, or other material, or a combination of materials, whether loose or in bags, bales, batting, pads, or other prefabricated form that is, or can be, used in bedding, upholstered furniture, or quilted clothing.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(5): "Label" means the display of written, printed, or graphic matter upon a tag or upon the immediate container of a bedding, upholstered furniture, quilted clothing, or filling material.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(6): (6)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(6)(a): "Manufacture" means to make, process, or prepare from new or secondhand material, in whole or in part, a bedding, upholstered furniture, quilted clothing, or filling material for sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(6)(b): (6)(a) "Manufacture" does not include making, processing, or preparing an article described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(6)(b)(i): a person sells three or fewer of the articles per year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(6)(b)(ii): the articles are sold by persons who are not primarily engaged in the making, processing, or preparation of the articles.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(7): 4-10-103; 4-10-113
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(7)(a): "New material" means material that has not previously been used in the manufacture of another article used for any purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(7)(b): 4-10-103; 4-10-113 "New material" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(7)(b)(i): by-products from a textile mill using only new raw material synthesized from a product that has been melted, liquified, and re-extruded; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(7)(b)(ii): 4-10-103; 4-10-113 down and feather that has been sterilized in accordance with the department's rules made under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(8): "Owner's own material" means an article owned or in the possession of a person for the person's own or a tenant's use that is sent to another person for manufacture or repair.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(9): "Quilted clothing" means a filled garment or apparel, exclusive of trim used for aesthetic effect, or a stiffener, shoulder pad, interfacing, or other material that is made in whole or in part from filling material and sold or offered for sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(10): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act "Reclaimed" or "reclaimed material" means material that would have otherwise been disposed of as waste or used for energy recovery, but instead is collected and used as a material input, in lieu of new primary material, as defined by rule by the department in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(11): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act "Recycled" or "recycled material" means material that has been reprocessed from reclaimed material by means of an accepted manufacturing process and made into a final product or into a component for incorporation into a product as defined by rule by the department in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(12): "Repair" means to restore, recover, alter, or renew bedding or upholstered furniture for a consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(13): "Retailer" means a person who sells bedding, upholstered furniture, quilted clothing, or filling material to a consumer for use primarily for personal, family, household, or business purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(14): (14)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(14)(a): "Sale" or "sell" means to offer or expose for sale, barter, trade, deliver, consign, lease, or give away any bedding, upholstered furniture, quilted clothing, or filling material.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(14)(b): (14) "Sale" or "sell" does not include a judicial, executor's, administrator's, or guardian's sale of an item described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(15): "Secondhand" means an article or filling material, or portion of an article or filling material, that has previously been used.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(16): 4-10-113 "Sterilize" means to disinfect, decontaminate, sanitize, cleanse, or purify as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(17): "Tag" means a card, flap, or strip attached to an article for the purpose of displaying information required by this chapter or under rule made pursuant to it.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(18): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(18)(a): "Used" means an article that has been sold to a consumer and has left the store.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(18)(b): "Used" does not include an article returned to the store:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(18)(b)(i): with the article's original tags; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(18)(b)(ii): in the article's original packaging.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(19): "Upholstered furniture" means portable or fixed furniture, except fixed seats in motor vehicles, boats, or aircraft, that is made in whole or in part with filling material, exclusive of trim used for aesthetic effect.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-102(20): "Wholesaler" means a person who offers an article for resale to a retailer or institution rather than a final consumer.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-104 Manufacture, repair, or wholesale sale of bedding, upholstered furniture, quilted clothing, or filling material -- Permit required.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-104(1): It is unlawful for a person to engage in the manufacture, repair, or wholesale sale of bedding, upholstered furniture, quilted clothing, or filling material without a permit issued by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-104(2): (1) Notwithstanding Subsection

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-105(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-105(1)(a): A person may register with the department, on a form prescribed and furnished by the department, for a permit to manufacture, repair, sterilize, or engage in the wholesale sale of bedding, upholstered furniture, quilted clothing, or filling material.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-105(1)(b): Upon receipt of a proper registration form and payment of the appropriate registration fee, the commissioner, if satisfied that the convenience and necessity of the industry and the public will be served, shall issue to the applicant a permit to engage in the particular activity through December 31 of the year in which the permit is issued, subject to suspension or revocation of the permit for cause.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-106 Unlawful acts specified.
-------------------------------------------------------
It is unlawful for a person to:Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-106(1): sell bedding, upholstered furniture, quilted clothing, or filling material as new unless it is made from new material and properly tagged;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-106(2): sell bedding, upholstered furniture, quilted clothing or filling material made from secondhand material that is not properly tagged;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-106(3): label or sell a used or secondhand article as if it were a new article;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-106(4): use burlap or other material that has been used for packing or baling, or to use any unsanitary, filthy, or vermin or insect infested filling material in the manufacture or repair of an article;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-106(5): sell bedding, upholstered furniture, quilted clothing or filling material that is not properly tagged regardless of point of origin;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-106(6): use a false or misleading statement, term, or designation on a tag;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-106(7): use a false or misleading label;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-106(8): sell new bedding, upholstered furniture, or quilted clothing with filling material made of down, feather, wool, or hair that has not been properly sterilized; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-106(9): 4-10-104 engage in the manufacture, repair, sterilization, or wholesale sale of bedding, upholstered furniture, quilted clothing, or filling material without a permit issued by the department as required by this chapter, unless otherwise exempt under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 4-10-107 Tagging requirements for bedding, upholstered furniture, and filling material.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 11 - Utah Bee Inspection Act
********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Bee Inspection Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(1): "Abandoned apiary" means any apiary to which the owner or operator fails to give reasonable and adequate attention during a given year as determined by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(2): "Apiary" means any place where one or more colonies of bees are located.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(3): "Apiary equipment" means hives, supers, frames, veils, gloves, or other equipment used to handle or manipulate bees, honey, wax, or hives.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(4): "Appliance" means any apparatus, tool, machine, or other device used to handle or manipulate bees, wax, honey, or hives.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(5): "Bee" means the common honey bee, Apis mellifera, at any stage of development.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(6)(a): "Beekeeper" means a person who keeps bees.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(6)(b): "Beekeeper" includes an apiarist.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(7): "Colony" means an aggregation of bees in any type of hive that includes queens, workers, drones, or brood.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(8): "Disease" means any infectious or contagious disease affecting bees, as specified by the department, including American foulbrood.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(9): "Hive" means a frame hive, box hive, box, barrel, log, gum skep, or other artificial or natural receptacle that may be used to house bees.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(10): "Package" means any number of bees in a bee-tight container, with or without a queen, and without comb.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(11): "Parasite" means an organism that parasitizes any developmental stage of a bee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(12): "Pest" means an organism that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(12)(a): inflicts damage to a bee or bee colony directly or indirectly; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(12)(b): may damage apiary equipment in a manner that is likely to have an adverse effect on the health of the colony or an adjacent colony.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(13): "Raise" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(13)(a): to hold a colony of bees in a hive for the purpose of pollination, honey production, or study, or a similar purpose; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(13)(b): when the person holding a colony holds the colony or a package of bees in the state for a period of time exceeding 30 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-102(14): "Terminal disease" means a pest, parasite, or pathogen that will kill an occupant colony or subsequent colony on the same equipment.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-103 Department authorized to make and enforce rules.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-103(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The department is authorized, subject to
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-103(2): (1) The rules described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-104 Bee raising -- Registration required -- Application -- Fees -- Renewal -- License required -- Application -- Fees -- Renewal.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-104(1): A person may not raise bees in this state without being registered with the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-104(2): Application for registration to raise bees shall be made to the department upon tangible or electronic forms prescribed and furnished by the department, within 30 days after the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-104(2)(a): takes possession of the bees; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-104(2)(b): moves the bees into the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-104(3): (2); 4-11-111 Nothing in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-104(4): An application in accordance with this chapter shall specify:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-104(4)(a): the name and address of the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-104(4)(b): the number of bee colonies owned by the applicant at the time of the application that will be present in the state for a period exceeding 30 days; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-104(4)(c): any other relevant information the department considers appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-104(5): 4-2-103(2) Upon receipt of a proper application and payment of an annual registration fee determined by the department pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-104(6): 4-2-103(2) A bee registration is renewable for a period of one year upon the payment of an annual registration renewal fee as determined by the department pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-104(7): Registration shall be renewed on or before December 31 of each year.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-105 County bee inspector -- Appointment -- Termination -- Compensation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-105(1): The county executive upon the petition of five or more persons who raise bees within the respective county shall, with the approval of the commissioner, appoint a qualified person to act as a bee inspector within the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-105(2): A county bee inspector shall be employed at the pleasure of the county executive and the commissioner and is subject to termination of employment, with or without cause, at the instance of either.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-105(3): Compensation for the county bee inspector shall be fixed by the county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-105(4): To be appointed a county bee inspector, a person shall demonstrate adequate training and knowledge related to this chapter, bee diseases, and pests.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-105(5): A record concerning bee inspection shall be kept by the county executive or commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-105(6): The county executive and the commissioner shall investigate a formal, written complaint against a county bee inspector.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-106 Hives to have removable frames -- Consent of county bee inspector to sell or transport diseased bees.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-106(1): A person may not house or keep bees in a hive unless the hive is equipped with movable frames to all the hive's parts so that access to the hive can be had without difficulty.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-106(2): No person who owns or has possession of bees (whether queens or workers) with knowledge that they are infected with terminal disease, parasites, or pests, or with knowledge that they have been exposed to terminal disease, parasites, or pests, shall sell, barter, give away, or move the bees, colonies, or apiary equipment without the consent of the county bee inspector or the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-107 Inspector -- Duties -- Diseased apiaries -- Examination of diseased bees by department -- Election to transport bees to wax-salvage plant.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-107(1): The county bee inspector or the department may inspect:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-107(1)(a): all apiaries within the county at least once each year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-107(1)(b): immediately any apiary within the county that is alleged in a complaint to be severely diseased, parasitized, or abandoned.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-107(2): If, upon inspection, the inspector determines that an apiary is diseased or parasitized, the inspector may take the following action based on the severity of the disease or parasite present:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-107(2)(a): prescribe the course of treatment that the owner or caretaker of the bees shall follow to eliminate the disease or parasite;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-107(2)(b): personally, for the purpose of treatment approved by the department, take control of the afflicted bees, hives, combs, broods, honey, and equipment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-107(2)(c): destroy the afflicted bees and, if necessary, their hives, combs, broods, honey, and all appliances that may have become infected.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-107(3): (2); (2)(b); (c) If, upon reinspection, the inspector determines that the responsible party has not executed the course of treatment prescribed by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-107(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-107(4)(a): The owner of an apiary who is dissatisfied with the diagnosis or course of action proposed by an inspector under this section may, at the owner's expense, have the department examine the alleged diseased bees.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-107(4)(b): The decision of the commissioner with respect to the condition of bees at the time of the examination is final and conclusive upon the owner and the inspector involved.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-108 County bee inspector -- Disinfection required before leaving apiary with diseased bees.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-108(1): Before inspecting the premises of any apiary, an inspector and any assistant of an inspector shall disinfect any equipment that will be used in the inspection.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-108(2): Before leaving the premises of any apiary, the bee inspector, or any assistant, shall thoroughly disinfect any part of the inspector's own person, clothing, or any appliance that has come in contact with infected material.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-108(3): (2) The method of disinfection required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-108(3)(a): may be determined by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-108(3)(b): shall be sufficient to destroy disease, parasites, and pathogens encountered.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-108(4): A county bee inspector shall maintain a record of each inspection, including disinfection practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-108(5): (4) The county executive or the commissioner may review a county bee inspector's records kept in accordance with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-109 Inspection of apiaries where queen bees raised for sale -- Honey from apiaries where queen bees raised for sale not to be used for candy for mailing cages unless boiled.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-109(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-109(1)(a): At least twice each summer the county bee inspector may inspect each apiary in which queen bees are raised for sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-109(1)(b): A person may not sell or transport any queen bee from an apiary that is found to be infected with disease without the consent of the county bee inspector or the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-109(2): No person engaged in raising queen bees for sale shall use any honey for making candy for mailing cages that has not been boiled for at least 30 minutes.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-109(3): A person rearing queens shall follow standard methods for minimizing or eliminating unmanageably aggressive stock.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-110 Enforcement -- Inspections authorized -- Warrants.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-110(1): The department and all bee inspectors shall have access to all apiaries or places where bees, hives, and appliances are kept for the purpose of enforcing this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-110(2): If admittance is refused, the department, or the bee inspector involved, may proceed immediately to obtain an ex parte warrant from the nearest court of competent jurisdiction to allow entry upon the premises for the purpose of making an inspection.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-111 Importation of bees or appliances into state -- Certification required -- Inspection discretionary -- Authority to require destruction or removal of diseased bees and appliances.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-111(1)(a)(i): the bees, apiary equipment, or appliances have been inspected within the current production season; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-111(1)(a)(ii): all diseased colonies in the apiary at the time of the inspection were destroyed or treated.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-111(1)(b): A person bringing or importing bees into the state shall advise the department of the address of the bees' destination and furnish the department with a copy of the certificate of inspection upon entry into the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-111(1)(c): 4-11-104 A person intending to hold bees in the state for a period of time exceeding 30 days shall comply with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-111(2)(b): A person bringing or importing used apiary equipment shall advise the department of the address of the destination in the state and furnish the department with a copy of the certificate of inspection upon entry into the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-112 Quarantine authorized.
-----------------------------------------------------
The commissioner, in order to protect the bee industry of the state against bee health or management issues, may quarantine the entire state, an entire county, or any apiary or specific hive within the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-113 Unlawful acts specified.
-------------------------------------------------------
It is unlawful for a person to:Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-113(1): extract honey in any place where bees can gain access either during or after the extraction process;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-113(2): maintain any neglected or abandoned hives, apiary equipment, or appliances other than in an enclosure that prohibits the entrance of bees;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-113(3): raise bees without being registered with the department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-113(4): knowingly sell a colony, apiary equipment, or appliance that is inoculated with terminal disease pathogens.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-114 Maintenance of abandoned apiary, equipment, or appliance -- Nuisance.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-114(1): It is a public nuisance to keep an abandoned or diseased apiary, apiary equipment, or appliance anywhere other than in an enclosure that prohibits the entry of bees.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-114(2): (1) Items listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-114(3): Upon discovery of, or receipt of a written complaint concerning, an abandoned apiary site, apiary equipment, or appliance, the bee inspector shall attempt to notify the registered owner, if any.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-114(4): (3); (4)(a); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-114(4)(a): (3) A registered owner notified under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-114(4)(b): (4)(a) The bee inspector or the department shall verify the removal or protection in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-114(4)(c): (4)(a) If a registered owner does not comply with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-114(5): A bee inspector or the department may seize and destroy an abandoned apiary, apiary equipment, or appliances if the abandoned apiary, apiary equipment, or appliances do not indicate a registered owner.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-115 Maintaining gentle stock.
--------------------------------------------------------
A beekeeper may not intentionally maintain an aggressive or unmanageable stock, whether African or European in origin.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-116 Regulation of beekeeping reserved to state -- Exceptions -- Rulemaking authorized.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-116(1): 11-13a-102 As used in this section, "governmental entity" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-116(2): Except as authorized by Subsection (3), a governmental entity may not adopt or enforce any restriction related to the raising of bees on private property that is more restrictive than the restrictions in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-116(3): A governmental entity may adopt and enforce a restriction related to the number and location of hives on property within the governmental entity's jurisdiction if the restriction complies with the department's rules described in Subsection (4).
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-116(4): The department may make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, for governmental entities to follow when adopting beekeeping restrictions in the governmental entity's jurisdiction related to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-116(4)(a): the number of hives permitted on a property;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-116(4)(b): the location of hives on a property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-116(4)(c): any locations unsuitable for beekeeping.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-116(5): This section does not restrict or expand private property rights.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117 Beekeeping working group -- Development of standards.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(1): 10-1-104 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(1)(a): 10-1-104 "Municipality" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(1)(b): "Urban county" means a county of the first or second class.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(1)(c): "Urban municipality" means a municipality located within the boundaries of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(1)(c)(i): an urban county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(1)(c)(ii): a county of the third class, if the municipality has a population of 10,000 or more.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(2): On or before November 30, 2024, the department shall convene a working group to develop recommendations for standards related to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(2)(a): the number and characteristics of hives appropriate for properties in urban and nonurban counties or municipalities, considering lot size and neighborhood population density;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(2)(b): the location and barrier guidance for hives appropriate for properties in urban and nonurban counties or municipalities, to minimize the impact on a neighboring property;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(2)(c): any locations in urban and nonurban counties or municipalities unsuitable for beekeeping;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(2)(d): swarm prevention;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(2)(e): water sources related to beekeeping; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(2)(f): open feeding related to beekeeping.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(3): 4-11-105
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(3)(a): 4-11-105 The working group described in Subsection (2) shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(3)(a)(i): department staff as determined by the commissioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(3)(a)(ii): 4-11-105 a majority of the county bee inspectors, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(3)(a)(iii): one member representing county government, as determined by the commissioner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(3)(a)(iv): one member representing municipal government, as determined by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(3)(b): A member of the working group may not receive compensation for membership on or participation in the working group.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(4): On or before December 31, 2024, the working group described in Subsection (2) shall report the working group's recommendations to the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-11-117(5): On or before April 30, 2025, the department shall make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to implement the recommendations from the working group's report described in Subsection (4).


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 12 - Utah Commercial Feed Act
*********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Commercial Feed Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(1): "Adulterated commercial feed" means any commercial feed that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(1)(a)(i): contains any poisonous or deleterious substance that may render it injurious to health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(1)(a)(ii): contains any added poisonous, added deleterious, or added nonnutritive substance that is unsafe within the meaning of 21 U.S.C. Sec. 346, other than a pesticide chemical in or on a raw agricultural commodity or a food additive;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(1)(a)(iii): contains any food additive or color additive that is unsafe within the meaning of 21 U.S.C. Sec. 348 or 379e;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(1)(a)(iv): contains a pesticide chemical in or on a raw agricultural commodity that is unsafe within the meaning of 21 U.S.C. Sec. 346a unless it is used in or on the raw agricultural commodity in conformity with an exemption or tolerance prescribed under 21 U.S.C. Sec. 346a and is subjected to processing such as canning, cooking, freezing, dehydrating, or milling, so that the residue, if any, of the pesticide chemical in or on the processed feed is removed to the extent possible through good manufacturing practices as prescribed by rules of the department so that the concentration of the residue in the processed feed is not greater than the tolerance prescribed for the raw agricultural commodity in 21 U.S.C. Sec. 346a;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(1)(a)(v): contains viable weed seeds in amounts exceeding limits established by rule of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(1)(a)(vi): contains a drug that does not conform to good manufacturing practice as prescribed by federal regulations promulgated under authority of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 301 et seq., for medicated feed premixes and for medicated feeds unless the department determines that the regulations are not appropriate to the conditions that exist in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(1)(a)(vii): contains any filthy, putrid, or decomposed substance, or is otherwise unfit for feed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(1)(a)(viii): has been prepared, packed, or held under unsanitary conditions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(1)(b): has a valuable constituent omitted or abstracted from it, in whole or in part, or its composition or quality falls below or differs from that represented on its label or in labeling.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(2)(a): "Animal remedy" means a remedy that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(2)(a)(i): is not used for food or cosmetic purposes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(2)(a)(ii): is prepared or compounded for animal use.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(2)(b): "Animal remedy" does not mean:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(2)(b)(i): a material, other than food, that is intended to affect the structure or function of the body of a human; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(2)(b)(ii): a product produced primarily as feed, to which medication is added at the time of manufacture as an additional ingredient.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(3): "Brand name" means one or more words, names, symbols, or devices that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(3)(a): identify a distributor or registrant's commercial feed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(3)(b): distinguish the distributor or registrant's commercial feed from the commercial feed of others.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(4): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(4)(a): "Commercial feed" means all materials that are distributed for use as feed or for mixing in feed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(4)(b): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act "Commercial feed" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(4)(b)(i): unadulterated, whole, unmixed seeds;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(4)(b)(ii): unadulterated, physically altered, entire, unmixed seeds;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(4)(b)(iii): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act any unadulterated commodity that the department specifies by rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(4)(b)(iv): a live, whole, or unprocessed animal that is not:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(4)(b)(iv)(A): adulterated; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(4)(b)(iv)(B): misbranded; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(4)(b)(v): an animal remedy that is not:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(4)(b)(v)(A): adulterated; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(4)(b)(v)(B): misbranded.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(5): "Contract feeder" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(5)(a): is an independent contractor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(5)(b): in accordance with the terms of a contract:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(5)(b)(i): is provided commercial feed;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(5)(b)(ii): feeds the commercial feed to an animal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(5)(b)(iii): receives remuneration that is calculated in whole or in part by feed consumption, mortality, profit, product amount, or product quality.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(6): "Customer-formula feed" means commercial feed that consists of a mixture of commercial feeds or feed ingredients, each batch of which is manufactured according to the specific instructions of the final purchaser.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(7): "Distribute" means to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(7)(a): offer for sale, sell, exchange, or barter commercial feed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(7)(b): supply, furnish, or otherwise provide commercial feed to a contract feeder.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(8): "Drug" means any article intended:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(8)(a): for use in the diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease in animals other than humans; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(8)(b): to affect the structure or any function of the animal body, unless the article is feed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(9): "Feed ingredient" means each constituent material in a commercial feed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(10): "Home-produced" means a pet treat produced in a private home kitchen in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(11): "Label" means any written, printed, or graphic matter upon or accompanying a commercial feed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(12): "Manufacture" means to grind, mix, blend, or otherwise process a commercial feed for distribution.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(13): "Mineral feed" means a commercial feed intended to supply primarily mineral elements or inorganic nutrients.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(14): 4-12-105
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(14)(a): 4-12-105 "Misbranded" means any commercial feed, whether in a container or in bulk, that bears a label that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(14)(a)(i): is false or misleading in any particular; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(14)(a)(ii): 4-12-105 does not strictly conform to the labeling requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(14)(b): "Misbranded" includes commercial feed that is distributed under the name of another commercial feed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(15): "Official sample" means a sample of commercial feed taken by the department in accordance with this chapter and designated as "official."
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(16): "Percent" or "percentage" means percentage by weight.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(17): "Pet" means a domesticated dog or cat.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(18): "Pet food" means a commercial feed prepared and distributed for consumption by a pet.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(19): "Pet treat" means commercial feed intended for pets that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(19)(a): is not intended to provide complete and balanced nutrition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(19)(b): is fed intermittently for training, reward, enjoyment, or other purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(20): "Pharmaceutical" means a product prescribed for the treatment or prevention of disease for veterinary purposes, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(20)(a): a vaccine;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(20)(b): a synthetic or natural hormone;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(20)(c): an anesthetic;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(20)(d): a stimulant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(20)(e): a depressant.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(21): "Product name" means the name of the commercial feed that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(21)(a): identifies the kind, class, or specific use of the commercial feed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(21)(b): distinguishes the commercial feed from all other products bearing the same brand name.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(22): "Quantity statement" means the net weight in mass, liquid measurement, or count.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(23): "Remedy" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(23)(a): a drug;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(23)(b): a combination of drugs;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(23)(c): a pharmaceutical;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(23)(d): a proprietary medicine;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(23)(e): a veterinary biologic; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(23)(f): a combination of drugs and other ingredients.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(24): "Specialty pet" means any animal normally maintained in a household for nonproduction purposes, including rodents, ornamental birds, ornamental fish, reptiles, amphibians, ferrets, hedgehogs, marsupials, and rabbits.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(25): "Specialty pet food" means a commercial feed prepared and distributed for consumption by a specialty pet.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(26): "Ton" means a net weight of 2,000 pounds avoirdupois.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(27): "Veterinary biologic" means a biologic product used for veterinary purposes, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(27)(a): an antibiotic;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(27)(b): an antiparasiticide;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(27)(c): a growth promotant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-102(27)(d): a bioculture product.
