Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106 Enforcement -- Inspection and samples authorized -- Methods for sampling and analysis prescribed -- Results to be forwarded to registrant or licensee -- Warrants.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(1): In order to determine compliance with this chapter, the department:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(1)(a): shall periodically sample, inspect, analyze, and test commercial feeds distributed within this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(1)(b): may enter during normal business hours, within reasonable limits, and in a reasonable manner, any:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(1)(b)(i): factory;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(1)(b)(ii): warehouse; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(1)(b)(iii): establishment in which commercial feed is manufactured, processed, packed, or held for distribution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(1)(c): may enter any vehicle used to transport or hold commercial feed in order to inspect:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(1)(c)(i): equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(1)(c)(ii): finished and unfinished materials;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(1)(c)(iii): containers;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(1)(c)(iv): records; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(1)(c)(v): labels.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(2): The department's methods for sampling and for analyses of feed ingredients, mineral ingredients, or other ingredients, or for analyses of customer-formula feeds, shall be in accordance with methods published by the Association of Official Analytical Chemists or other generally recognized methods.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(3): The official sample shall guide the department in determining whether a commercial feed is misbranded, adulterated, or otherwise deficient.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(4): The department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(4)(a): forward the results of all tests of official samples to the manufacturer, distributer, licensee, or registrant using the address specified on the container, label, or on the written statement or invoice; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(4)(b): furnish to the manufacturer, distributer, licensee, or registrant part of any official sample that the department determines is misbranded or adulterated upon written request to the department by the manufacturer, distributer, licensee, or registrant within 30 days after receipt of the unsatisfactory test results.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-106(5): (1)(b); (1)(c) If the department is refused admittance authorized by Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107 Suspension or revocation authorized -- Refusal to register or issue license authorized -- Grounds -- Stop sale, use, or removal order authorized -- Court action -- Procedure -- Costs.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(1): Upon satisfactory evidence that a manufacturer, distributer, licensee, or registrant has used fraudulent or deceptive practices in the registration, licensing, or distribution of a commercial feed or customer-formula feed, the department may:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(1)(a): suspend or revoke the registration or license of any brand name of commercial feed or customer-formula feed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(1)(b): refuse to register or license any brand name or product of commercial feed or customer-formula feed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(2)(a): The department may issue a "stop sale, use, or removal order" to the distributor or owner of any commercial feed or lot of commercial feed that it finds or has reason to believe is misbranded, adulterated, or otherwise in violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(2)(b): (2)(a) The order described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(2)(c): Before an order release is issued, the department may require the distributor or owner of the "stopped" commercial feed or lot of commercial feed to pay the expense incurred by the department in connection with the withdrawal of the product from the market.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(3)(a): The department is authorized in a court of competent jurisdiction to seek:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(3)(a)(i): an order of seizure or condemnation of a commercial feed;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(3)(a)(ii): a temporary restraining order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(3)(a)(iii): a permanent injunction to prevent the violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(3)(b): No bond shall be required of the department in an injunctive proceeding brought under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(4): If the court orders condemnation of a commercial feed, the commercial feed shall be disposed of as the court directs, provided the order gives the manufacturer, distributor, licensee, or registrant an opportunity to apply to the court for permission to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(4)(a): relabel, reprocess, or otherwise bring the commercial feed into conformance with this chapter and administrative rules; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(4)(b): remove the commercial feed from the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-107(5): If the court orders condemnation, court costs, fees, storage, and other costs shall be awarded against the claimant of the commercial feed.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-108 Unlawful acts specified.
-------------------------------------------------------
A person in this state may not:Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-108(1): manufacture or distribute adulterated or misbranded commercial feed;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-108(2): adulterate or misbrand any commercial feed;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-108(3): distribute agricultural products such as whole seed, hay, straw, stover, silage, cobs, husks, or bulbs that are adulterated;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-108(4): remove or dispose of any commercial feed in violation of a "stop sale, use, or removal order";
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-108(5): distribute any commercial feed that is not registered or any customer-formula feed that is not licensed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-108(6): reuse a bag or tote previously used for commercial feed, including customer-formula feed, unless the user:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-108(6)(a): appropriately cleans the bag or tote; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-12-108(6)(b): documents the clean-out procedure used on the bag or tote.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 13 - Utah Fertilizer Act
****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Fertilizer Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(1): "Adulterated fertilizer" means a fertilizer or soil amendment that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(1)(a): contains a deleterious or harmful substance in sufficient amount to render it injurious to beneficial plant life, animals, humans, aquatic life, soil, or water when applied in accordance with the directions for use on the label;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(1)(b): has a composition that falls below or differs from that which the composition is purported to possess by the composition's labeling;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(1)(c): contains unwanted crop or weed seed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(1)(d): exceeds levels of metals permitted by the United States Environmental Protection Agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(2): "Beneficial substances or compounds" means a substance or compound other than primary, secondary, and micro plant nutrients that can be demonstrated by scientific research to be beneficial to one or more species of plants when applied exogenously.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(3): "Biostimulant" means a product containing naturally-occurring substances and microbes that are used to stimulate plant growth, enhance resistance to plant pests, and reduce abiotic stress.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(4): "Blender" means a person engaged in the business of blending or mixing fertilizer, soil amendments, or both.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(5): "Brand" means a term, design, or trade mark used in connection with one or several grades of fertilizer or soil amendment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(6): "Bulk fertilizer" means fertilizer delivered to the purchaser either in solid or liquid state in a non-packaged form to which a label cannot be attached.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(7): "Custom blend" means a fertilizer blended according to specification provided to a blender in a soil test nutrient recommendation or to meet the specific consumer request before blending.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(8): "Deficiency" means the amount of nutrient found by analysis to be less than that guaranteed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(9): "Derivation" means the source from which the guaranteed nutrients are derived.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(10): "Distribute" means to import, consign, manufacture, produce, compound, mix, blend, or to offer for sale, sell, barter, or supply fertilizer or soil amendments in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(11): "Distributor" means a person who distributes.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(12): "Fertilizer" means a substance that contains one or more recognized plant nutrients that is used for the substance's plant nutrient content and is designed for use or claimed to have value in promoting plant growth, exclusive of unmanipulated animal and vegetable manures, marl, lime, limestone, wood ashes, gypsum, and other products exempted by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(13): "Fertilizer material" means a fertilizer that contains:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(13)(a): quantities of no more than one of the primary plant nutrients, nitrogen (N), phosphate (P2O5), Potash (K2O);
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(13)(b): 85% plant nutrients in the form of a single chemical compound; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(13)(c): plant or animal residues or by-products, or a natural material deposit that is processed so that its primary plant nutrients have not been materially changed, except through purification and concentration.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(14): "Grade" means the percentage of total nitrogen, available phosphate and soluble potash stated in the same terms, order, and percentages as in the guaranteed analysis.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(15): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(15)(a): "Guaranteed analysis" means the minimum percentage by weight of plant nutrients claimed in the following order and form:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(15)(b): For unacidulated mineral phosphatic material and basic slag, bone, tankage, and other organic phosphate or degree of fineness may also be guaranteed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(15)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(15)(c)(i): Guarantees for plant nutrients other than nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium may be permitted or required by rule of the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(15)(c)(ii): The guarantees for such other nutrients shall be expressed in the form of the element.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(15)(c)(iii): The sources of such other nutrients, such as oxides, salt, chelates, may be required to be stated on the application for registration and may be included as a parenthetical statement on the label.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(15)(c)(iv): Other beneficial substances or compounds, determinable by laboratory methods, also may be guaranteed by permission of the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(15)(c)(v): Any plant nutrients or other substances or compounds guaranteed are subject to inspection and analysis in accord with the methods and rules prescribed by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(16): "Investigational allowance" means an allowance for variations inherent in the taking, preparation, and analysis of an official sample of fertilizer or soil amendment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(17): "Label" means the display of the written, printed, or graphic matter upon the immediate container or statement accompanying a fertilizer or soil amendment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(18): "Labeling" means the written, printed, or graphic matter upon or accompanying fertilizer or soil amendment, or advertisements, brochures, posters, television and radio announcements used in promoting the sale of fertilizers or soil amendments.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(19): "Lot" means a definite quantity identified by a combination of numbers, letters, characters, or amount represented by a weight certificate from which every part is uniform within recognized tolerances from which the distributor can be determined.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(20): "Micro plant nutrient" means boron, chlorine, colbalt, copper, iron, manganese, molybdenum, nickel, sodium, and zinc.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(21): "Mixed fertilizer" means a fertilizer containing any combination or mixture of fertilizer materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(22): "Nonplant food ingredient" means a substance or compound other than the primary, secondary, or micro nutrients.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(23): "Official sample" means a sample of fertilizer or soil amendment taken by the department and designated as "official."
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(24): "Other ingredients" means the non-soil amending ingredients present in soil amendments.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(25): "Percent" or "percentage" means the percentage by weight.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(26): "Plant amendment" means a substance applied to plants or seeds that is intended to improve growth, yield, product quality, reproduction, flavor, or other favorable characteristics of plants except fertilizer, soil amendments, agricultural liming materials, animal and vegetable manure, pesticides, or plant regulators.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(27): "Primary nutrient" includes total nitrogen, available phosphate, and soluble potash.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(28): "Registrant" means a person who registers a fertilizer or a soil amendment under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(29): "Secondary nutrient" includes calcium, magnesium, and sulfur.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(30): "Slow release fertilizer" means a fertilizer in a form that releases, or converts to a plant-available form, plant nutrients at a slower rate relative to an appropriate reference soluble product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(31): "Soil amending ingredient" means a substance that will improve the physical, chemical, biochemical, biological, or other characteristics of the soil.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(32): "Soil amendment" means a substance or a mixture of substances that is intended to improve the physical, chemical, biochemical, biological, or other characteristics of the soil, except fertilizers, agricultural liming materials, unmanipulated animal manures, unmanipulated vegetable manures, or pesticides.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(33): "Specialty fertilizer" means fertilizer distributed primarily for non-farm use, such as home gardens, lawns, shrubbery, flowers, golf courses, municipal parks, cemeteries, greenhouses, and nurseries.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-102(34): "Ton" means a net weight of 2,000 pounds avoirdupois.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103 Distribution of fertilizer or soil amendment -- Registration required -- Application -- Fees -- Expiration -- Renewal -- Exemptions specified -- Blenders and mixers.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(1): 4-2-103(2)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(1)(a): A brand and grade of fertilizer or soil amendment shall be registered in the name of the person whose name appears upon the label before being distributed in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(1)(b): 4-2-103(2) The application for registration shall be submitted to the department on a form prescribed and furnished by the department, and shall be accompanied by a fee determined by the department pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(1)(c): Upon approval by the department, a copy of the registration shall be furnished to the applicant.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(1)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(1)(d)(i): A registration expires at midnight on December 31 of the year in which issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(1)(d)(ii): A registration is renewable for a period of one year upon the payment of an annual registration renewal fee in an amount equal to the current applicable original registration fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(1)(d)(iii): A renewal fee shall be paid on or before December 31 of each year.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(2): A distributor is not required to register fertilizer that has been registered by another person under this chapter if the label does not differ in any respect.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(3): 4-2-103(2); 4-13-104
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(3)(a): 4-2-103(2); 4-13-104 A blender is not required to register each grade of fertilizer or soil amendment formulated according to specifications provided by a consumer before mixing, but is required to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(3)(a)(i): license the name under which the business of blending or mixing is conducted;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(3)(a)(ii): 4-2-103(2) pay an annual blenders license fee determined by the department pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(3)(a)(iii): 4-13-104 label the fertilizer or soil amendment as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(3)(b)(i): A blenders license expires at midnight on December 31 of the year in which the license is issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(3)(b)(ii): A blenders license is renewable for a period of one year upon the payment of an annual license renewal fee in an amount equal to the current applicable original blenders license fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(3)(b)(iii): A renewal fee shall be paid on or before December 31 of each year.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(4): 4-2-103(2)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(4)(a): A tonnage fee shall be assessed on fertilizer and soil amendment products sold in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(4)(b): 4-2-103(2) The fee shall be determined by the department pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(4)(c): When more than one person is involved in the distribution of a fertilizer or soil amendment, the final person who has the fertilizer or soil amendment registered and distributed to a non-registrant or consumer is responsible for reporting the tonnage and paying the tonnage fee, unless the report and payment is made by a prior distributor of the fertilizer or soil amendment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(4)(d): The tonnage report shall be submitted on a form provided by the department on or before December 31 annually covering shipments made during the preceding 12-month period from November 1 to October 31.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-103(4)(e): Revenue generated by the fee shall be deposited into the General Fund as dedicated credits to be used by the department for education and research about and promotion of proper fertilizer and soil amendment distribution, handling, and use.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104 Labeling requirements for fertilizer and soil amendments specified.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(1): A container of fertilizer distributed in this state shall bear a label in clearly legible and conspicuous form setting forth the:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(1)(a): brand name and grade;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(1)(b): guaranteed analysis, except that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(1)(b)(i): sources of nutrients, when shown on the label, shall be listed below the completed guaranteed analysis in order of predominance;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(1)(b)(ii): guarantees of zeros may not be made and may not appear in statement except in nutrient guarantee breakdowns; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(1)(b)(iii): if chemical forms of nitrogen are claimed or required, the form shall be shown, but no implied order of the forms of nitrogen is intended;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(1)(c): derivation statement of guaranteed nutrients, nonplant food ingredients, and beneficial substances or compounds if present;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(1)(d): directions for use when applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(1)(e): caution or warning statement when applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(1)(f): name and address of the registrant or the manufacturer, if different from the registrant;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(1)(g): net weight or volume; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(1)(h): lot number.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(2): (1)(a); (h) A container of specialty fertilizer distributed in this state shall bear a label in clear, legible, and conspicuous form setting forth the information specified in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(3): (1)(a); (c) A shipment of custom blend fertilizer shall be accompanied by a printed or written statement setting forth the:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(3)(a): (1)(a); (c) information specified in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(3)(b): name and address of the licensed blender;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(3)(c): net weight or volume; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(3)(d): lot number.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(4): (1)(a); (c) A shipment of fertilizer material shall be accompanied by a printed or written statement setting forth the:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(4)(a): (1)(a); (c) information specified in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(4)(b): name and address of the registrant if different from the supplier or shipper;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(4)(c): net weight or volume; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(4)(d): lot number.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(5): The grade is not required on a fertilizer label when no primary nutrients are claimed or are less than one percent.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(6): Additional nutrient guarantees may not be an extension of the grade statement and shall be a separate line or include terms such as "plus," "with," or "including."
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(7): A soil amendment distributed in the state shall bear a label in clearly legible and conspicuous form setting forth the:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(7)(a): brand name;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(7)(b): guaranteed analysis, which includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(7)(b)(i): nonplant food ingredients separated out by soil amending ingredients and other total ingredients, in that order, by percentages; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(7)(b)(ii): nonsoil amending ingredients separating out beneficial substances and beneficial compounds, in that order, by percentage or acceptable units;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(7)(c): purpose of product;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(7)(d): direction for application;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(7)(e): caution or warning statement when applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(7)(f): name and address of registrant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(7)(g): net weight or volume.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(8): The department may require proof of claims made, usefulness, and value of the soil amendments.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(9): For evidence of proof the department may rely on experimental data, evaluations, or advice supplied from such sources as the director of the Agricultural Experiment Station. The experimental design shall be related to state conditions for which the product is intended.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(10): Information or a statement may not appear on a package, label, delivery slip, or advertising matter that is false or misleading to the purchaser as to the use, value, quality, analysis, type, or composition of the soil amendment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(11): A fertilizer is misbranded if:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(11)(a): the fertilizer's labeling is false or misleading in any particular;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(11)(b): the fertilizer is distributed under the name of another fertilizer product;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(11)(c): the fertilizer is not labeled as required; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-104(11)(d): the fertilizer purports to be or is represented as fertilizer, or is represented as containing a plant nutrient fertilizer that does not conform with the definition of identity or any commonly accepted definitions of official fertilizer terms.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-105 Enforcement -- Inspection and samples authorized -- Methods for sampling and analysis prescribed -- Warrants.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-105(1): The department shall periodically sample, inspect, analyze, and test fertilizers and soil amendments distributed within this state to determine if they comply with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-105(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-105(2)(a): The methods of sampling and analysis shall be those adopted by the AOAC International.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-105(2)(b): (2)(a) In a case not covered by the methods adopted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-105(3): In determining whether a fertilizer or soil amendment is deficient, the department shall be guided solely by the official sample.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-105(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-105(4)(a): The department may enter any public or private premises or carriers during regular business hours to have access to fertilizers or soil amendments and records relating to the distribution of fertilizers and soil amendments subject to this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-105(4)(b): If admittance is refused, the department may proceed immediately to obtain an ex parte warrant from the nearest court of competent jurisdiction to allow entry upon the premises for the purpose of making inspections and obtaining samples.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-105(5): The department shall distribute the results of an official sample.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-105(6): The department shall retain an official sample for a minimum of 90 days from the issuance of a report.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-106 Distribution of fertilizers not complying with labeling requirements prohibited -- Penalty assessed -- Court action to vacate or amend finding authorized.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-106(1): A person may not distribute in this state a fertilizer, fertilizer material, soil amendment, or specialty fertilizer if the official sample thereof establishes that the fertilizer, fertilizer material, soil amendment, or specialty fertilizer is deficient in the nutrients or ingredients guaranteed on the label by an amount exceeding the values established by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-106(2): The department shall evaluate and take administrative action the department prescribes for a deficiency beyond the investigational allowances established by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-106(3): A registrant aggrieved by the finding of an official sample deficiency may file a complaint with a court of competent jurisdiction to vacate or amend the finding of the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-108 Denial, suspension, or revocation authorized -- Grounds -- Stop sale, use, or removal order authorized -- Court action -- Procedure -- Costs.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-108(1): The department may deny, revoke, or suspend the license for a blender or the registration of a brand of fertilizer or soil amendment upon satisfactory evidence that the licensee or registrant has used fraudulent or deceptive practices in licensure, registration, or distribution in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-108(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-108(2)(a): The department may issue a "stop sale, use, or removal order" to the owner or person in possession of any designated lot of fertilizer or soil amendment that the department finds or has reason to believe is being offered or exposed for sale in violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-108(2)(b): The order shall be in writing and fertilizer or soil amendment subject to the order may not be moved or offered or exposed for sale, except upon the subsequent written release of the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-108(2)(c): Before a release is issued, the department may require the owner or person in possession of the "stopped" lot to pay the expense incurred by the department in connection with the withdrawal of the product from the market.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-108(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-108(3)(a): The department may seek in a court of competent jurisdiction an order of seizure or condemnation of any fertilizer that violates this chapter or, upon proper grounds, to obtain a temporary restraining order or permanent injunction, to prevent violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-108(3)(b): A bond may not be required of the department in any injunctive proceeding under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-108(4): If condemnation is ordered, the fertilizer or soil amendment shall be disposed of as the court directs, except that the court may not order condemnation without giving the claimant of the fertilizer or soil amendment an opportunity to apply to the court for permission to relabel, reprocess, or otherwise bring the product into conformance, or to remove the fertilizer or soil amendment from the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-108(5): If the court orders condemnation of the fertilizer or soil amendment, court costs, fees, storage, and other expenses shall be awarded against the claimant of the fertilizer or soil amendment.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-109 Sales or exchanges of fertilizers or soil amendments between manufacturers, importers, or manipulators permitted.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter may not be construed to restrict or avoid sales or exchanges of fertilizers or soil amendments to each other by importers, manufacturers, or manipulators who mix fertilizer or soil amendment materials for sale or as preventing the free and unrestricted shipment of fertilizer or soil amendments to manufacturers or manipulators who have registered their brands as required by this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-110 Department may make and enforce rules -- Cooperation with state and federal agencies authorized.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-110(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-110(1)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The department may make rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-110(1)(b): The department shall by rule adopt the official terms, tables, definitions, and statements adopted by the Association of American Plant Food Control officials and published in the official publications of that organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-110(2): The department may enter into agreements with other agencies of the state, other states, and agencies of the federal government to administer and enforce this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-110(3): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (3) The department may use the following terms in rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-110(3)(a): biostimulant;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-110(3)(b): bulk fertilizer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-110(3)(c): plant amendment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-110(3)(d): secondary nutrient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-13-110(3)(e): slow release fertilizer.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 14 - Utah Pesticide Control Act
***********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Pesticide Control Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(1): "Active ingredient" means an ingredient that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(1)(a): prevents, destroys, repels, controls, or mitigates pests; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(1)(b): acts as a plant regulator, defoliant, or desiccant.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(2): "Adulterated pesticide" means a pesticide with a strength or purity that is below the standard of quality expressed on the label under which the pesticide is offered for sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(3): "Animal" means all vertebrate or invertebrate species.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(4): "Beneficial insect" means an insect that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(4)(a): an effective pollinator of plants;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(4)(b): a parasite or predator of pests; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(4)(c): otherwise beneficial.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(5): "Certified applicator" means an individual who is licensed by the department to apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(5)(a): a restricted use pesticide; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(5)(b): a general use pesticide for hire or in exchange for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(6): "Certified qualified applicator" means a certified applicator who is eligible to act as a qualifying party.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(7): "Defoliant" means a substance or mixture intended to cause leaves or foliage to drop from a plant, with or without causing abscission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(8): "Desiccant" means a substance or mixture intended to artificially accelerate the drying of plant or animal tissue.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(9): "Distribute" means to offer for sale, sell, barter, ship, deliver for shipment, receive, deliver, or offer to deliver pesticides in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(10): "Environment" means all living plants and animals, water, air, land, and the interrelationships that exist between them.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(11)(a): "Equipment" means any type of ground, water, or aerial equipment or contrivance using motorized, mechanical, or pressurized power to apply a pesticide.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(11)(b): "Equipment" does not mean any pressurized hand-sized household apparatus used to apply a pesticide or any equipment or contrivance used to apply a pesticide that is dependent solely upon energy expelled by the person making the pesticide application.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(12): "EPA" means the United States Environmental Protection Agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(13): "FIFRA" means the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(14): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(14)(a): "Fungus" means a nonchlorophyll-bearing thallophyte or a nonchlorophyll-bearing plant of an order lower than mosses and liverworts, including rust, smut, mildew, mold, yeast, and bacteria.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(14)(b): "Fungus" does not include fungus existing on or in:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(14)(b)(i): a living person or other animal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(14)(b)(ii): processed food, beverages, or pharmaceuticals.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(15): "Herbicide" means a substance that is toxic to plants and is used to control or eliminate unwanted vegetation.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(16): "Insect" means an invertebrate animal generally having a more or less obviously segmented body:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(16)(a): usually belonging to the Class Insecta, comprising six-legged, usually winged forms, including beetles, bugs, bees, and flies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(16)(b): allied classes of arthropods that are wingless usually having more than six legs, including spiders, mites, ticks, centipedes, and wood lice.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(17): "Label" means any written, printed, or graphic matter on, or attached to, a pesticide or a container or wrapper of a pesticide.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(18): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(18)(a): "Labeling" means all labels and all other written, printed, or graphic matter:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(18)(a)(i): accompanying a pesticide or equipment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(18)(a)(ii): to which reference is made on the label or in literature accompanying a pesticide or equipment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(18)(b): "Labeling" does not include any written, printed, or graphic matter created by the EPA, the United States Departments of Agriculture or Interior, the United States Department of Health, Education, and Welfare, state experimental stations, state agricultural colleges, and other federal or state institutions or agencies authorized by law to conduct research in the field of pesticides.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(19): "Land" means land, water, air, and plants, animals, structures, buildings, contrivances, and machinery appurtenant or situated thereon, whether fixed or mobile, including any used for transportation.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(20): 4-14-104 "Misbranded" means any label or labeling that is false or misleading or that does not strictly comport with the label and labeling requirements set forth in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(21): "Misuse" means use of any pesticide in a manner inconsistent with the pesticide's label or labeling.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(22): "Nematode" means invertebrate animals of the Phylum Nemathelminthes and Class Nematoda, including unsegmented round worms with elongated, fusiform, or saclike bodies covered with cuticle, also known as nemas or eelworms.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(23): "Ornamental and turf pest control" means the use of a pesticide to control ornamental and turf pests in the maintenance and protection of ornamental trees, shrubs, flowers, or turf.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(24): 23A-1-101; 23A-2-102; 23A-2-201; 23A-2-301; 23A-2-302; 23A-2-303
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(24)(a): "Pest" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(24)(a)(i): any insect, rodent, nematode, fungus, weed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(24)(a)(ii): any other form of terrestrial or aquatic plant or animal life, virus, bacteria, or other microorganism that is injurious to health or to the environment or that the department declares to be a pest.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(24)(b): 23A-1-101; 23A-2-102; 23A-2-201; 23A-2-301; 23A-2-302; 23A-2-303 "Pest" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(24)(b)(i): viruses, bacteria, or other microorganisms on or in a living person or other living animal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(24)(b)(ii): 23A-1-101; 23A-2-102; 23A-2-201; 23A-2-301; 23A-2-302; 23A-2-303 protected wildlife species identified in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(25): "Pesticide" means any:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(25)(a): substance or mixture of substances, including a living organism, that is intended to prevent, destroy, control, repel, attract, or mitigate any insect, rodent, nematode, snail, slug, fungus, weed, or other form of plant or animal life that is normally considered to be a pest or that the commissioner declares to be a pest;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(25)(b): any substance or mixture of substances intended to be used as a plant regulator, defoliant, or desiccant;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(25)(c): any spray adjuvant, such as a wetting agent, spreading agent, deposit builder, adhesive, or emulsifying agent with deflocculating properties of its own used with a pesticide to aid the pesticide's application or effect; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(25)(d): any other substance designated by the department by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(26): "Pesticide applicator" is a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(26)(a): applies or supervises the application of a pesticide; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(26)(b): is required by this chapter to have a license.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(27): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(27)(a): "Pesticide applicator business" means an entity that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(27)(a)(i): is authorized to do business in this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(27)(a)(ii): offers pesticide application services.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(27)(b): "Pesticide applicator business" does not include an individual licensed agricultural applicator who may work for hire.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(28): "Pesticide dealer" means any person who distributes restricted use pesticides.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(29): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(29)(a): "Plant regulator" means any substance or mixture intended, through physiological action, to accelerate or retard the rate of growth or rate of maturation, or otherwise alter the behavior of ornamental or crop plants.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(29)(b): "Plant regulator" does not include plant nutrients, trace elements, nutritional chemicals, plant inoculants, or soil amendments.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(30): "Qualifying party" means a certified qualified applicator who is the owner or employee of a pesticide applicator business and who is registered with the department as the individual responsible for ensuring the training, equipping, and supervision of all pesticide applicators who work for the pesticide applicator business.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(31): "Restricted use pesticide" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(31)(a): a pesticide, including a highly toxic pesticide, that is a serious hazard to beneficial insects, animals, or land; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(31)(b): any pesticide or pesticide use restricted by the administrator of EPA or by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(32): "Spot treatment" means the limited application of an herbicide to an area that is no more than 5% of the potential treatment area or one-twentieth of an acre, whichever is smaller, using equipment that is designed to contain no more than five gallons of mixture.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(33): "Weed" means any plant that grows where not wanted.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-102(34): "Wildlife" means all living things that are neither human, domesticated, nor pests.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104 Labeling requirement for pesticides specified.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(1): (2) Each container of pesticide distributed in this state shall bear a label setting forth:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(1)(a): the name, brand, or trademark under which the pesticide is distributed;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(1)(b): (2) subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(1)(b)(i): the part of the immediate container that is presented or displayed under customary conditions of purchase; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(1)(b)(ii): on the outside container and wrapper of the retail package, if there be one, through which the ingredient statement on the immediate container cannot be clearly read;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(1)(c): a warning or caution statement if necessary, which, if complied with together with any requirements imposed under Section 3(d) of FIFRA, is adequate to protect health and the environment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(1)(d): the net weight or measure of the content;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(1)(e): the name and address of the manufacturer, registrant, or person for whom manufactured;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(1)(f): the EPA registration number assigned to each establishment in which the pesticide was produced and the EPA registration number assigned to the pesticide, if required by regulations under FIFRA;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(1)(g): the federal use classification under which the pesticide is registered or designated for "experimental use only"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(1)(h): directions for use of the pesticide sufficient to carry out the purposes for which the product is intended and which, if complied with together with any requirements imposed under Section 3(d) of FIFRA, are adequate to protect health and the environment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(2): An ingredient statement may appear prominently on another part of a container, as permitted under Section 2(q)(2)(A) of FIFRA, if the size or form of the container makes it impractical to place the ingredient statement on the part of the retail package that is presented or displayed under customary conditions of purchase.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(3): If the pesticide is highly toxic the label shall, in addition to the other label requirements, display:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(3)(a): the skull and crossbones;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(3)(b): the word "POISON" in red prominently displayed on a background of distinctly contrasting color; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-104(3)(c): a statement of a practical treatment, first aid or otherwise, in case of poisoning by the pesticide.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-105 Issuance of experimental use permits -- Application -- Terms and conditions for issuance.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-105(1): 4-14-103 The department upon application may:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-105(1)(a): 4-14-103 issue an experimental use permit to any person if the department determines that the applicant needs such a permit in order to accumulate information necessary to register a pesticide under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-105(1)(b): refuse to issue an experimental permit if the department determines that issuance is not warranted or that the pesticide use to be made under the proposed terms and conditions may cause unreasonable adverse effects on the environment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-105(2): The department may also with respect to issuance of an experimental use permit:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-105(2)(a): prescribe the terms and conditions for the conduct of the experimental use that in all events shall be under the supervision of the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-105(2)(b): revoke or modify any experimental use permit if the department determines that the terms or conditions of the experimental use are being violated, or that the terms and conditions prescribed are inadequate to avoid unreasonable adverse effects to the environment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-105(3): Application for an experimental use permit may be made before, after, or simultaneously with an application for registration.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-106 Department authorized to make and enforce rules.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department may, by following the procedures and requirements ofUtah Code Annotated § 4-14-106(1): declare as a pest any form of plant or animal life that is injurious to health or the environment, except:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-106(1)(a): a human being; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-106(1)(b): a bacteria, virus, or other microorganism on or in a living person or animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-106(2): establish, in accordance with the regulations issued by the EPA under 7 U.S.C. Sec. 136w(c)(2), whether pesticides registered for special local needs under the authority of 7 U.S.C. Sec. 136v(c) are highly toxic to man;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-106(3): establish, consistent with EPA regulations, that certain pesticides or quantities of substances contained in these pesticides are injurious to the environment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-106(4): adopt a list of "restricted use pesticides" for the state or designated areas within the state if the department determines upon substantial evidence presented at a public hearing that restricted use is necessary to prevent damage to property or to the environment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-106(5): establish qualifications for a pesticide applicator business; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-106(6): adopt any rule, not inconsistent with federal regulations issued under FIFRA,  considered necessary to administer and enforce this chapter, including  rules relating to the sale, distribution, use, and disposition of pesticides if necessary to prevent damage and to protect the public health.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107 Enforcement -- Inspection and sampling authorized -- Notice of deficiency to be given registrant -- Objects of inspection delineated -- Warrants.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(1): The department, to determine compliance with this chapter, shall periodically:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(1)(a): sample, inspect, and analyze pesticides distributed within this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(1)(b): observe and investigate the use and application of pesticides within this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(1)(c): inspect equipment used to apply pesticides in this state to determine if the equipment complies with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(2)(a): If a pesticide sample, upon analysis, fails to comply with this chapter, the department shall give written notice to that effect to the registrant or owner of the pesticide.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(2)(b): Nothing in this chapter, however, shall be construed as requiring the department to refer minor violations for criminal prosecution or for the institution of condemnation proceedings if the department believes the public interest will best be served through informal action.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(3): The department, for the purpose of enforcing this section, is authorized at reasonable times to enter any private or public premises for the purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(3)(a): inspecting any equipment used in applying pesticides;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(3)(b): inspecting or sampling lands actually or reported to be exposed to pesticides;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(3)(c): inspecting storage or disposal areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(3)(d): investigating complaints of injury to animals or lands;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(3)(e): sampling pesticides wherever located, including in vehicles; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(3)(f): observing the use and application of a pesticide.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-107(4): (3) The department may proceed immediately, if admittance is refused, to obtain an ex parte warrant from the nearest court of competent jurisdiction to allow entry upon the premises for any purpose specified in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-109 Examination requirements for license to act as applicator may be waived through reciprocal agreement.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department may waive any or all examination requirements specified in rule for a noncommercial, commercial, or private pesticide applicator through a reciprocal agreement with another state whose examination requirements and standards for licensure are substantially similar to those of Utah.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-110 Defenses.
----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-110(1): As an affirmative defense to any action brought as a result of the alleged misuse or misapplication of a pesticide, a person may present evidence that as of the time of the alleged violation, the person was in compliance with label directions, this chapter, and any rules issued in accordance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-110(2): A person is not liable for injuries resulting from the misuse or misapplication of a pesticide unless the person was negligent.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-111(6): 4-14-103 A pesticide applicator business shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-111(6)(a): 4-14-103 only employ a pesticide applicator who has received a license from the department, as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-111(6)(b): ensure that all employees comply with this chapter and the rules authorized by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-111(7): An individual or entity applying for a business registration certificate does not have to meet the requirements of Subsection (3)(d) if the individual's or entity's sole use of pesticides is limited to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-111(7)(a): providing ornamental and turf pest control spot treatment services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-14-111(7)(b): herbicides with labels that contain the signal word "caution" or "warning."


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 15 - The Utah Nursery Act
*****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "The Utah Nursery Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-102 Background and purpose.
------------------------------------------------------
The Legislature finds that:Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-102(1): nursery stock can harbor and vector plant pests and diseases;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-102(2): unregulated production and shipping of nursery stock presents an unacceptable risk to the state's agricultural, forestry, and horticultural interests, and to the state's general environmental quality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-102(3): it is necessary to ensure that nurseries produce healthy plants and that nursery stock shipped to other nurseries, brokers, and out-of-state customers meets national nursery stock cleanliness standards.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(1): "Balled and burlapped stock" means nursery stock that is removed from the growing site with a ball of soil containing its root system intact and encased in burlap or other material to hold the soil in place.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(2): "Bare-root stock" means nursery stock that is removed from the growing site with the root system free of soil.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(3): "Compliance agreement" means any written agreement between a person and a regulatory agency to achieve compliance with any set of requirements being enforced by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(4): "Container stock" means nursery stock that is transplanted in soil or in a potting mixture contained within a metal, clay, plastic, or other rigid container for a period sufficient to allow newly developed fibrous roots to form, so that if the plant is removed from the container the plant's root-media ball will remain intact.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(5): "Etiolated growth" means bleached and unnatural growth resulting from the exclusion of sunlight.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(6): "Minimum indices of vitality" mean standards adopted by the department to determine the health and vigor of nursery stock offered for sale in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(7): "National nursery stock cleanliness standards" means nursery stock that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(7)(a): is free from quarantine pests and pests of concern;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(7)(b): has all nonquarantine plant pests under effective control;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(7)(c): meets the national nursery stock cleanliness standards; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(7)(d): is eligible for nursery stock certification and shipping permits.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(8): "Nonestablished container stock" means deciduous nursery stock that is transplanted in soil or in a potting mixture contained within a metal, clay, plastic, or other rigid container for a period insufficient to allow the formation of fibrous roots sufficient to form a root-media ball.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(9): "Nursery" means any place where nursery stock is propagated and grown for sale or distribution.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(10)(a): "Nursery agent" means a person who solicits or takes an order for the sale of nursery stock, other than on the premises of a nursery or nursery outlet.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(10)(b): "Nursery agent" includes a nursery landscaper.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(11): "Nursery outlet" means any place or location where nursery stock is offered for wholesale or retail sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(12)(a): "Nursery stock" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(12)(a)(i): all plants, whether field grown, container grown, or collected native plants;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(12)(a)(ii): trees, shrubs, vines, grass sod;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(12)(a)(iii): seedlings, perennials, biennials, annuals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(12)(a)(iv): buds, cuttings, grafts, or scions grown or collected or kept for propagation, sale, or distribution.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(12)(b): "Nursery stock" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(12)(b)(i): dormant bulbs, tubers, roots, corms, rhizomes, or pips;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(12)(b)(ii): field, vegetable, or flower seeds; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(12)(b)(iii): cut flowers, unless stems or other portions of the cut flowers are intended for propagation.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(13): "Packaged stock" means bare-root stock that is packed either in bundles or in single plants with the roots in some type of moisture-retaining material designed to retard evaporation and hold the moisture-retaining material in place.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(14): "Pests of concern" means a nonquarantine pest that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(14)(a): is not known to occur in the state, or that has a limited distribution within the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(14)(b): has the potential to negatively impact nursery stock health or pose an unacceptable economic or environmental risk.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(15): "Place of business" means each separate nursery, or nursery outlet, where nursery stock is offered for sale, sold, or distributed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(16): "Plant pests" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(16)(a): the egg, pupal, and larval stage, as well as any other living stage of any insect, mite, nematode, slug, snail, protozoa, or other invertebrate animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(16)(b): bacteria;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(16)(c): fungi;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(16)(d): parasitic plant or a reproductive part of a parasitic plant;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(16)(e): virus or viroid;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(16)(f): phytoplasma; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(16)(g): any infectious substance that can injure or cause disease or damage in any plant.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(17): "Quarantine pest" means a pest that poses potential negative economic or environmental impact to an area in which the pest currently:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(17)(a): does not exist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(17)(b): exists, but its presence is not widely distributed or is being officially controlled.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(18): "Shipping permit or certificate of inspection" means a sticker, stamp, imprint, or other document that accompanies nursery stock shipped intrastate and documents that the originating nursery:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(18)(a): is licensed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(18)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(18)(b)(i): has stock that has passed annual inspection; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-103(18)(b)(ii): produces stock that meets the National Nursery Stock Compliance Standard.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-104 Department authorized to make and enforce rules.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department is authorized, subject to

Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-105 Unlawful to offer nursery stock for sale or to solicit orders for nursery stock without license.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is unlawful for any person in this state to offer nursery stock for sale at a nursery or nursery outlet, or to solicit or receive orders for nursery stock for a person who regularly engages in the business of operating a nursery or nursery outlet, without a license issued by the department.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-107(1)(a): be sized and graded in accordance with the applicable rules of the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-107(1)(b): bear a tag or label with the name, grade, size, and variety of the stock.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-108(2):

Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-108(3): Nursery stock found to be infested with insect pests or infected with plant disease shall be destroyed or otherwise treated as determined by the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-109 Transport of out-of-state nursery stock to Utah -- Certificate of inspection to be filed with department by out-of-state nurseries -- Option in department to accept exchange list in lieu of certificate of inspection -- Imported stock to be tagged -- Treatment of stock not tagged.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-109(2): Nursery stock originating outside and imported into this state for customer delivery or for resale shall bear a tag:

Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-110 Nursery stock offered or advertised for sale -- Unlawful to misrepresent name, origin, grade, variety, quality, or vitality -- Information required in advertisements.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-110(1): A person shall not misrepresent the name, origin, grade, variety, quality, or indicia of vitality of any nursery stock advertised or offered for sale at a nursery or nursery outlet.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-110(2): All advertisements of nursery stock shall clearly state the name, size, and grade of the stock where applicable.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-111 Infested or diseased stock not to be offered for sale -- Identification of "nonestablished container stock" -- Requirements for container stock -- Inspected and certified stock only to be offered for sale -- Prohibition against coating aerial plant surfaces.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-111(1): Nursery stock that is infested with plant pests, including noxious weeds, or infected with disease or that does not meet minimum indices of vitality may not be offered for sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-111(2): All nonestablished container stock offered for sale shall be identified by the words "nonestablished container stock" legibly printed on a water resistant tag that states the length of time the stock has been planted or the date the stock was planted and may not be offered for sale in any manner that leads a purchaser to believe the stock is container stock.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-111(3): All container stock offered for sale shall be established with a root-media mass that will retain its shape and hold together when removed from the container.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-111(4): No nursery stock other than officially inspected and certified stock shall be offered for wholesale or retail sale in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-111(5): Colored waxes or other materials that coat the aerial parts of a plant and change the appearance of the plant surface are prohibited.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-112(2)(b): If access for the purpose of inspection is denied, the department may proceed immediately to the nearest court of competent jurisdiction and obtain an ex parte warrant or its equivalent to permit inspection of the nursery or nursery outlet.
