Utah Code Annotated § 4-15-114 Compliance agreements.
-----------------------------------------------------
The department may make compliance agreements with the responsible officials of other states and nursery establishments to achieve compliance with any set of requirements being enforced by the department.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 16 - Utah Seed Act
**********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-101 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Seed Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(1): "Advertisement" means any representation made relative to seeds, plants, bulbs, or ground stock other than those on the label of a seed container, disseminated in any manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(2): (2)(a); (2)(b); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act "Agricultural seed" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(2)(a): grass, forage, cereal, oil, fiber, and other kinds of crop seed commonly recognized within this state as agricultural seed;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(2)(b): lawn seed;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(2)(c): (2)(a); (2)(b) combinations of the seed described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(2)(d): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act noxious weed seed, if the department determines by rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(3): "Blend" means seed consisting of more than one variety of a kind, each in excess of 5% by weight of the whole.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(4): "Brand" means a word, name, symbol, number, or design used to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(4)(a): identify the seed of one person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(4)(b): distinguish the seed of one person from the seed of another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(5): "Certifying agency" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(5)(a): an agency authorized under the laws of a state, territory, or possession to officially certify seed and that has standards and procedures approved by the United States Secretary of Agriculture to assure the genetic purity and identity of the seed certified; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(5)(b): an agency of a foreign country determined by the United States Secretary of Agriculture to adhere to procedures and standards for seed certification.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(6): "Coated seed" means seed that has been covered by a layer of materials that obscure the original shape and size of the seed resulting in an increase of the weight of the seed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(7)(a): "Complete record" means all information that relates to the  origin, treatment, germination, purity, kind, and variety of each lot of agricultural seed sold in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(7)(b): "Complete record" includes seed samples and records of declarations, labels, purchases, sales, conditioning, bulking, treatment, handling, storage, analyses, tests, and examinations.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(8): "Conditioning" means drying, cleaning, scarifying, and other operations that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(8)(a): could change the purity or germination of a seed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(8)(b): require a seed lot to be retested to determine the label information.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(9): "Controlling the pollination" means to use a method of hybridization that will produce pure seed that is at least 75% hybrid seed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(10): "Dormant" means viable seed, excluding hard seed, that fail to germinate when provided the specified germination conditions for the kind of seed in question.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(11): "Flower seed" includes the seed of herbaceous plants that are:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(11)(a): grown for their blooms, ornamental foliage, or other ornamental parts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(11)(b): commonly known and sold under the name of flower or wildflower seed in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(12): "Foundation seed," "registered seed," or "certified seed" means seed that is produced and labeled in accordance with procedures officially recognized by a seed certifying agency approved and accredited in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(13): "Genuine grower declaration" means a statement signed by a grower which, for each lot of seed, provides the:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(13)(a): lot number;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(13)(b): kind;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(13)(c): variety, if known;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(13)(d): origin;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(13)(e): weight;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(13)(f): year of production;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(13)(g): date of shipment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(13)(h): name of the person to whom the shipment was made.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(14): "Germination" means the emergence and development from the seed embryo of those essential structures that are, for the kind of seed in question, indicative of the ability to produce a normal plant under favorable conditions expressed in whole numbers.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(15): "Hard seed" means seed that remains hard at the end of the prescribed germination test period because the seed has not absorbed water due to an impermeable seed coat.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(16): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(16)(a): "Hybrid," applied to kinds or varieties of seed, means the first generation seed of a cross produced by controlling the pollination and by combining:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(16)(a)(i): two or more inbred lines;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(16)(a)(ii): one inbred or a single cross with an open pollinated variety; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(16)(a)(iii): two selected clones, seed lines, varieties, or species.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(16)(b): The department shall treat hybrid designations as variety names.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(17): "Inert matter" means all matter that is not seed, including broken seeds, sterile florets, chaff, fungus bodies, and stones, as determined by methods defined by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(18): "Inoculant" means a commercial preparation containing nitrogen-fixing bacteria applied to seed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(19): "Kind" means one or more related species or subspecies of seed that singly or collectively are known by one common name, for example, corn, oats, alfalfa, and timothy.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(20): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(20)(a): "Label" means any written, printed, or graphic representation accompanying and pertaining to any seeds, plants, bulbs, or ground stock whether in bulk or in containers.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(20)(b): "Label" includes a representation on an invoice, bill, or letterhead.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(21): "Labeling" includes a tag or other device attached to, written, stamped, or printed on a container or accompanying a lot of bulk seeds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(21)(a): claims to specify the information required on the seed label by this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(21)(b): may include other information related to the labeled seed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(22): "Lot" means a definite quantity of seed identified by a number or other mark, every portion or bag of which is uniform within recognized tolerances for the factors that appear in the labeling.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(23): "Mixture" or "mix" or "mixed" means seed consisting of more than one kind, each in excess of 5% by weight of the whole.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(24): "Mulch" means a protective covering of a suitable substance placed with seed that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(24)(a): acts to retain sufficient moisture to support seed germination and sustain early seedling growth;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(24)(b): aids in the prevention of the evaporation of soil moisture;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(24)(c): aids in the control of weeds; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(24)(d): aids in the prevention of erosion.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(25): "Noxious weed seeds" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(25)(a): prohibited noxious weed seeds; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(25)(b): restricted noxious weed seeds.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(26): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(26)(a): "Off-type" means a seed or plant not part of the variety because the seed or plant deviates in one or more characteristics from the variety.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(26)(b): "Off-type" may include a seed or plant that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(26)(b)(i): is of another variety;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(26)(b)(ii): is not necessarily any variety;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(26)(b)(iii): results from cross-pollination by another kind or variety; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(26)(b)(iv): results from uncontrolled self-pollination during production of hybrid seeds.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(27): "Origin" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(27)(a): for an indigenous stand of trees, the area on which the trees are growing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(27)(b): for a nonindigenous stand of trees, the place from which the seeds or plants originated.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(28): "Other crop seed" means the seed of plants grown as crops other than the kind or variety included in the pure seed, as determined by methods defined by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(29): "Person" means an individual, partnership, corporation, company, association, receiver, trustee, or agent.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(30): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(30)(a): "Prohibited noxious weed seeds" means those weed seeds determined by the commissioner that are prohibited from being present in agricultural, vegetable, flower, tree, or shrub seed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(30)(b): "Prohibited noxious weed seeds" include the seeds of weeds that are highly destructive and difficult to control by good cultural practices and the use of herbicides.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(31): "Pure seed" means seed exclusive of inert matter and all other seed not of the seed being considered as determined by methods defined by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(32): "Restricted noxious weed seeds" means those weed seeds determined by the commissioner that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(32)(a): are objectionable in agricultural crops, lawns, and gardens of this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(32)(b): can be controlled by good cultural practices or the use of herbicides.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(33): "Seed for sprouting" means seed sold for sprouting for salad or culinary purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(34): "Sowing" means the placement of agricultural seed, vegetable seed, flower seed, tree and shrub seed, or seed for sprouting in a selected environment for the purpose of obtaining plant growth.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(35): "Tetrazolium test (TZ)" means a biochemical seed viability test using the compound 2, 3, 5 triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC), as specified in Part II, Tetrazolium Testing Handbook, Contribution Number 29, to the handbook on Seed Testing, prepared by the Tetrazolium subcommittee of the Association of Official Seed Analysts, 2008 Edition.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(36): "Total viable" is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(36)(a): equal to the sum of percentage germination, percentage dormant seed, and percentage hard seed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(36)(b): determined by a tetrazolium test for species identified in the rules for testing or for species for which there are no rules for testing.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(37): "Treated" means that a seed has received an application of a substance or been subjected to a process designed to reduce, control, or repel disease organisms, insects, or other pests that attack seeds or seedlings.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(38): "Tree and shrub seed" includes seed of woody plants commonly known and sold as tree and shrub seeds in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(39): "Type" means a group of varieties so nearly similar that the individual varieties cannot be clearly differentiated except under special conditions.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(40): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(40)(a): "Variant" means a seed or plant that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(40)(a)(i): is distinct within the variety but occurs naturally in the variety;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(40)(a)(ii): is stable and predictable with a degree of reliability comparable to other varieties of the same kind, within recognized tolerances, when the variety is reproduced or reconstituted; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(40)(a)(iii): was originally a part of the variety as released.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(40)(b): "Variant" does not include an off-type.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(41): "Variety" means a subdivision of a kind that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(41)(a): distinct, meaning a variety can be differentiated by one or more identifiable morphological, physiological, or other characteristics from all other varieties of public knowledge;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(41)(b): uniform, meaning that variations in essential and distinctive characteristics are describable; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(41)(c): stable, meaning a variety's essential and distinctive characteristics and uniformity will remain unchanged when reproduced or reconstituted as required by the category of variety.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(42): "Vegetable seed" includes the seed of those crops that are:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(42)(a): grown in gardens or on truck farms; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(42)(b): generally known and sold under the name of vegetable or herb seed in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(43): "Weed seed" means the seed of all plants generally recognized as weeds within this state, as determined by methods defined by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(44): "Weight" means the net weight of the commodity.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-102(45): "Wholesaler" is a person who predominantly supplies seed to a distributor rather than a customer.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-103 Department authorized to make and enforce rules -- Cooperation with state and federal agencies authorized.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-103(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The department is authorized, subject to
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-103(2): The department may cooperate with other state agencies, other states, and with the United States Department of Agriculture or other departments or agencies of the federal government.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201 Labeling requirements.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(1): A container of seed that is transported, sold, offered, or exposed for sale within this state shall bear on the container or have attached to the container a printed label that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(1)(a): is in a conspicuous place;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(1)(b): is plainly written in the English language;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(1)(c): is in type no smaller than eight point;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(1)(d): specifies the information required by this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(1)(e): does not modify or deny the information required by this chapter in the labeling or on another label attached to the container.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(2): (2)(a); (2)(d); (2)(e); (2)(f); (2)(a) A container of agricultural seed offered or exposed for sale or transported for sowing into this state shall be labeled with the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(2)(a): (2)(a); (2)(d); (2)(e); (2)(f) name of the kind and variety for each seed component in excess of 5% of the whole and the percentage by weight of each component in the order of its predominance in columnar form, provided that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(2)(a)(i): the label shall specify the name of the variety or state "Variety Not Stated" or "VNS," for any component that is required by rule of the department to be labeled as a variety;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(2)(a)(ii): a hybrid shall be labeled as a hybrid;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(2)(a)(iii): the word "mix," "mixture," or "blend" shall appear, if more than one component is required to be named; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(2)(a)(iv): (2)(a); (2)(d); (2)(e); (2)(f) the total of the percentages described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(2)(b): name and address of the person who labeled the seed, or the person who sells, offers, or exposes the seed for sale in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(2)(c): lot number or other lot identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-201(2)(d): percentage by weight of all weed seeds;

Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202 Distribution of seeds -- Germination tests required -- Date to appear on label -- Seed to be free of noxious weed seed -- Special requirements for treated seeds -- Prohibitions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(1): 4-16-201; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act A person in this state may not offer or expose for sale or sowing any seed for sprouting or any agricultural, vegetable, flower, or tree and shrub seed unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(1)(a)(i): for agricultural seed, including mixtures of agricultural seed:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(1)(a)(i)(A): a test to determine the percentage of germination has been performed within 18 months, exclusive of the month the seed is tested and the date the seed is offered for sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(1)(a)(i)(B): the date of the test appears on the label;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(1)(a)(ii): for vegetable, flower, or tree and shrub seed or seed for sprouting:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(1)(a)(ii)(A): a test to determine the percentage of germination has been performed within 12 months, exclusive of the month the seed is tested and the date the seed is offered for sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(1)(a)(ii)(B): the date of the test appears on the label;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(1)(a)(iii): for hermetically sealed agricultural, vegetable, flower, or tree and shrub seed:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(1)(a)(iii)(A): a test to determine the percentage of germination has been performed within 36 months, exclusive of the month the seed is tested and the date the seed is offered for sale, or the seed have been retested for germination within nine months, exclusive of the month the seed is retested and the date the seed are offered or exposed for sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(1)(a)(iii)(B): the date of the test appears on the label;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(1)(b): 4-16-201 the package or other container is truthfully labeled and in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(1)(c): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act the seed is free of noxious weed seed, subject to any tolerance as may be prescribed by the department through rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(2): 4-16-201; (2)(d)(i) The label on any package or container of an agricultural, vegetable, flower, lawn and turf, or tree and shrub seed or seed mixture that has been treated and for which a claim is made on account of the treatment, in addition to the labeling requirements specified in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(2)(a): state that the seed have been treated;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(2)(b): state the commonly accepted name, generic chemical name, or abbreviated chemical name of the substance used for treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(2)(c): state the date beyond which the inoculant is not considered effective, if the seed is treated with an inoculant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(2)(d): (2)(d)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(2)(d)(i): include a caution statement consistent with rules of the department if the treatment substance remains with the seed in an amount which is harmful to vertebrate animals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(2)(d)(ii): (2)(d)(i) subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(3): A person may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(3)(a): use the word "trace" as a substitute for a statement required under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(3)(b): disseminate any false or misleading advertisement about agricultural, vegetable, flower, or tree and shrub seed or seed for sprouting; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-202(3)(c): detach, alter, or destroy any label or substitute any seed in a manner that defeats the purpose of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-203 Inspection -- Samples -- Analysis -- Seed testing facilities to be maintained -- Rules to control offensive seeds -- Notice of offending seeds -- Warrants.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-203(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-203(1)(a): The department shall periodically enter public or private premises from which seeds are distributed, offered, or exposed for sale to sample, inspect, analyze, and test agricultural, vegetable, flower, or tree and shrub seeds or seeds for sprouting distributed within this state to determine compliance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-203(1)(b): (1)(a) To perform the duties specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-203(1)(b)(i): establish and maintain facilities for testing the purity and germination of seeds;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-203(1)(b)(ii): prescribe by rule uniform methods for sampling and testing seeds; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-203(1)(b)(iii): establish fees for rendering service.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-203(2): The department shall prescribe by rule weed seeds and noxious weed seeds and fix the tolerances permitted for those offensive seeds.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-203(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-203(3)(a): If a seed sample, upon analysis, fails to comply with this chapter, the department shall give written notice to that effect to any person who is distributing, offering, or exposing the seeds for sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-203(3)(b): (3)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-203(4): The department may proceed immediately, if admittance is refused, to obtain an ex parte warrant from the nearest court of competent jurisdiction to allow entry upon the premises for the purpose of making inspections and obtaining samples.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-301 Enforcement -- Stop sale, use, or removal authorized -- Court action -- Procedures -- Costs.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-301(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-301(1)(a): The department may issue a "stop sale, use, or removal order" to the distributor, owner, or person in possession of any designated agricultural, vegetable, flower, or tree and shrub seed or seeds for sprouting or lot of seed which it finds or has reason to believe violates this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-301(1)(b): The order shall be in writing and no seed subject to it shall be moved, offered, or exposed for sale, except upon subsequent written release by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-301(1)(c): Before a release is issued, the department may require the distributor or owner of the "stopped" seed or lot to pay the expense incurred by the department in connection with the withdrawal of the product from the market.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-301(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-301(2)(a): The department is authorized in a court of competent jurisdiction to seek an order of seizure or condemnation of any seed which violates this chapter or, upon proper grounds, to obtain a temporary restraining order or permanent injunction to prevent violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-301(2)(b): No bond may be required of the department in an injunctive proceeding brought under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-301(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-301(3)(a): If condemnation is ordered, the seed shall be disposed of as the court directs.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-301(3)(b): The court may not order condemnation without giving the claimant of the seed an opportunity to apply to the court for permission to relabel, reprocess, or otherwise bring the seed into conformance, or for permission to remove it from the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-301(3)(c): If the court orders condemnation, court costs, fees, storage, and other costs shall be awarded against the claimant of the seed.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-302 False or misleading advertising with respect to seed quality prohibited.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Unless agricultural, vegetable, flower, or tree and shrub seeds or seeds for sprouting sold, advertised, or exposed or offered for sale in this state for propagation or planting have been registered or certified by an officially recognized seed certifying agency approved and accredited in this state, a person may not:Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-302(1): use orally or in writing:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-302(1)(a): the term "foundation," "registered," or "certified" seed along with other words; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-302(1)(b): any other term or form of words which suggests that the seed has been certified or registered by an inspection agency duly authorized by any state, or that there has been registration or certification, or either; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-302(2): use any tags similar to registration or certification tags.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-303 Distributors of seed to keep record of each lot of seed distributed.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-303(1): Each person whose name appears on the label of agricultural, vegetable, flower, or tree and shrub seeds or seeds for sprouting shall keep:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-303(1)(a): a complete record of each lot of agricultural, vegetable, flower, tree and shrub seed or seeds for sprouting distributed in this state for a period of two years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-303(1)(b): a file sample of each lot of seed for a period of one year after final disposition of the lot.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-303(2): The records and samples pertaining to the distribution of the seeds shall be available to the department for inspection during regular business hours.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-401 Designation of official testing agency for certification of seed.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-401(1): The agricultural experiment station at Utah State University is designated as the official state agency responsible for the production, approval, and testing of foundation seeds in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-401(2): This agency shall perform all functions necessary for seed certification including the determination of the adaptability of established and new crop varieties for planting in this state, whether produced in this state or elsewhere, and the determination of eligibility of crop varieties for registration and certification in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-401(3): In performing its responsibility, the experiment station may contract, subject to available funds, upon such terms and conditions as it considers appropriate with a private seed certifying agency.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-501 Chapter does not apply to seed not intended for sowing, to seed at seed processing plant, or to seed transported or delivered for transportation in the ordinary course of business.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-501(1): (2) This chapter does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-501(1)(a): seed or grain not intended for sowing;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-501(1)(b): (2) subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-501(1)(c): to any carrier in respect to any seed transported or delivered for transportation in the ordinary course of its business as a carrier.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-16-501(3): (1)(c) A carrier described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 17 - Utah Noxious Weed Act
******************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Noxious Weed Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-102(1): "Commission" means the county legislative body of each county of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-102(2): "Commissioner" means the commissioner of agriculture and food or the commissioner's representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-102(3): "County noxious weed" means any plant that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-102(3)(a): not on the state noxious weed list;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-102(3)(b): especially troublesome in a particular county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-102(3)(c): declared by the county legislative body to be a noxious weed within the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-102(4): "Noxious weed" means any plant the commissioner determines to be especially injurious to public health, crops, livestock, land, or other property.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-103 Commissioner -- Functions, powers, and duties.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
The commissioner or the commissioner's designee shall:Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-103(1): investigate and designate noxious weeds on a statewide basis;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-103(2): compile and publish annually a list of statewide noxious weeds;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-103(3): coordinate and assist in inter-county noxious weed enforcement activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-103(4): determine whether each county complies with this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-103(5): assist a county that fails to carry out the provisions of this chapter in the county's implementation of a weed control program;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-103(6): prescribe the form and general substantive content of notices to the public and to individuals concerning the prevention and control of noxious weeds;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-103(7): compile and publish a list of articles capable of disseminating noxious weeds or seeds and designate treatment to prevent dissemination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-103(8): regulate the flow of contaminated articles into the state and between counties to prevent the dissemination of noxious weeds or seeds.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104 Creation of State Weed Committee -- Membership -- Powers and duties -- Expenses.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(1): There is created a State Weed Committee composed of eight members, with each member representing one of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(1)(a): the Department of Agriculture and Food;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(1)(b): the Department of Natural Resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(1)(c): the Utah State University Agricultural Experiment Station;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(1)(d): the Utah State University Extension Service;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(1)(e): the Utah Association of Counties;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(1)(f): private agricultural industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(1)(g): the Utah Weed Control Association; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(1)(h): the Utah Weed Supervisors Association.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(2): The commissioner shall select the members of the committee from those nominated by each of the respective groups or agencies following approval by the executive committee of the Agricultural Advisory Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(3): (3)(b); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(3)(a): (3)(b) Except as required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(3)(b): (3)(a) Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(4)(a): Members may be removed by the commissioner for cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(4)(b): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(5): The State Weed Committee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(5)(a): confer and advise on matters pertaining to the planning, implementation, and administration of the state noxious weed program;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(5)(b): recommend names for membership on the committee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(5)(c): serve as members of the executive committee of the Utah Weed Control Association.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(6): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(6)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(6)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-104(6)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-105 County weed control board -- Appointment -- Composition -- Terms -- Removal -- Compensation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-105(1): A county executive of a county may, with the advice and consent of the county legislative body, appoint a county weed control board comprised of not less than three nor more than five appointed members.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-105(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-105(2)(a): If the county legislative body is the county commission, the chair of the county legislative body shall appoint one member of the county legislative body who shall act as a coordinator between the county and the county weed control board.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-105(2)(b): If the county legislative body is a county council:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-105(2)(b)(i): for a county of the first class, the county executive or the county executive's designee shall serve on the county weed control board and act as coordinator between the county and the county weed control board; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-105(2)(b)(ii): for a county that is not a county of the first class, the county executive shall serve on the county weed control board and act as coordinator between the county and the county weed control board.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-105(3): Two members of the board shall be farmers or ranchers whose primary source of income is derived from production agriculture.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-105(4): Members are appointed to four year terms of office and serve with or without compensation as determined by each county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-105(5): Members may be removed for cause and any vacancy that occurs on a county weed control board shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term of the vacated member.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-106 Commissioner may require county weed control board to justify failure to enforce provisions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the commissioner determines that the weed control board of any county has failed to perform the board's duties under this chapter, the commissioner may require the board to justify, in writing, the board's failure to enforce these provisions within the board's county.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-107 County weed control board responsible for control of noxious weeds -- Cooperation with other county boards -- Authority to designate noxious weed -- Public hearing before removal of noxious weed from state list.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-107(1): A county weed control board is responsible, under the general direction of the county executive, for the formulation and implementation of a county-wide coordinated noxious weed control program designed to prevent and control noxious weeds within the board's county.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-107(2): A county weed control board is required, under the general direction of the board's commission, to cooperate with other county weed control boards to prevent and control the spread of noxious weeds.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-107(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-107(3)(a): A county legislative body may declare a particular weed or competitive plant, not appearing on the state noxious weed list, a county noxious weed within the board's county.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-107(3)(b): A county executive, with the approval of the county legislative body, may petition the commissioner for removal of a particular noxious weed from the state noxious weed list.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-107(3)(c): The county legislative body may not approve a petition of the county executive to the commissioner to remove a noxious weed unless the county legislative body has first conducted a public hearing after due notice.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108 Weed control supervisor -- Qualification -- Appointment -- Duties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(1)(a): Each commission may employ one or more weed control supervisors qualified to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(1)(a)(i): detect and treat noxious weeds; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(1)(a)(ii): direct the weed control program for the county weed control board.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(1)(b): A person may be a weed control supervisor for more than one county weed control board.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(1)(c): Terms and conditions of employment shall be prescribed by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(2): A supervisor, under the direction of the local county weed control board, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(2)(a): examine all land under the jurisdiction of the county weed control board to determine whether this chapter and the rules adopted by the department have been met;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(2)(b): compile data on infested areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(2)(c): consult and advise upon matters pertaining to the best and most practical method of noxious weed control and prevention;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(2)(d): render assistance and direction for the most effective control and prevention;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(2)(e): investigate violations of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(2)(f): enforce noxious weed controls within the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-108(2)(g): perform any other duties required by the county weed control board.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-109 Notice of noxious weeds to be published annually in county -- Notice to particular property owners to control noxious weeds -- Methods of prevention or control specified -- Failure to control noxious weeds considered public nuisance.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-109(1): 63G-30-102; 45-1-101 Each county weed control board before May 1 of each year shall post a general notice of the noxious weeds within the county and publish the notice:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-109(1)(a): 63G-30-102 for the county, as a class A notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-109(1)(b): 45-1-101 as required in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-109(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-109(2)(a): If the county weed control board determines that particular property within the county requires prompt and definite attention to prevent or control noxious weeds, the county weed control board shall serve the owner or the person in possession of the property, personally or by certified mail, a notice specifying when and what action is required to be taken on the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-109(2)(b): Methods of prevention or control may include definite systems of tillage, cropping, use of chemicals, and use of livestock.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-109(3): An owner or person in possession of property who fails to take action to control or prevent the spread of noxious weeds as specified in the notice is maintaining a public nuisance.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-110 Noxious weeds -- Failure to control after notice of nuisance -- Notice and hearing -- Control at county expense -- Owner liable for county costs -- Charges lien against property.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-110(1): If the owner or person in possession of the property fails to take action to control or prevent the spread of noxious weeds within five working days after the property is declared a public nuisance, the county may, after reasonable notification, enter the property, without the consent of the owner or the person in possession, and perform any work necessary, consistent with sound weed prevention and control practices, to control the weeds.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-110(2): (1); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-110(2)(a): (1) If the county controls weeds on a piece of property, as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-110(2)(b): (2)(a) The property owner of record or the person in possession of the property, as the case may be, shall reimburse the county for the county's expense within 90 days after receipt of the demand for payment, as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-110(2)(c): If the demand for payment is not paid within 90 days after receipt, the charges become a lien against the property and are collectible by the county treasurer at the time general property taxes are collected.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-111 Hearing before county weed control board -- Appeal of decision to the county legislative body -- Judicial review.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-111(1): Any person served with notice to control noxious weeds may request a hearing to appeal the terms of the notice before the county weed control board within 10 days of receipt of such notice and may appeal the decision of the county weed control board to the county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-111(2): Any person served with notice to control noxious weeds who has had a hearing before both the county weed control board and the  county legislative body may further appeal the decision of the county legislative body by filing written notice of appeal with a court of competent jurisdiction.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-112 Jurisdiction of state and local agencies to control weeds.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The departments or agencies of state and local governments shall develop, implement, and pursue an effective program for the control and containment of noxious weeds on all lands under the department's or agency's control or jurisdiction, including highways, roadways, rights-of-way, easements, game management areas, and state parks and recreation areas.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-113 County noxious weed control fund authorized.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
A commission may establish and maintain a noxious weed control fund in each county for use in the administration of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-115 Cooperative agreements and grants to rehabilitate areas infested with or threatened by invasive species.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department may:Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-115(1): enter into a cooperative agreement with a political subdivision, a state agency, a federal agency, a tribe, a county weed board, a cooperative weed management area, a nonprofit organization, a university, or a private landowner to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-115(1)(a): rehabilitate or treat an area infested with, or threatened by, an invasive species; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-115(1)(b): conduct research related to invasive species; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-17-115(2): in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, make rules to award grants and administer this section.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 18 - Conservation Commission Act
************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Conservation Commission Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102 Findings and declarations -- Duties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(1): 4-46-101 In addition to the policy provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(1)(a): the soil and water resources of this state constitute one of the state's basic assets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(1)(b): the preservation of soil and water resources requires planning and programs to ensure:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(1)(b)(i): the development and use of soil and water resources; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(1)(b)(ii): soil and water resources' protection from the adverse effects of wind and water erosion, sediment, and sediment related pollutants.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(2): The Legislature finds that local production of food is essential for:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(2)(a): the security of the state's food supply; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(2)(b): the self-sufficiency of the state's citizens.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(3): The Legislature finds that sustainable agriculture is critical to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(3)(a): the success of rural communities;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(3)(b): the historical culture of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(3)(c): maintaining healthy farmland;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(3)(d): maintaining high water quality;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(3)(e): maintaining abundant wildlife;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(3)(f): high-quality recreation for citizens of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(3)(g): helping to stabilize the state economy.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(4): The Legislature finds that livestock grazing on public lands is important for the proper management, maintenance, and health of public lands in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(5): The Legislature encourages each agricultural producer in the state to operate in a reasonable and responsible manner to maintain the integrity of soil, water, and air.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(6): 4-18-107 The department shall administer the Utah Agriculture Certificate of Environmental Stewardship Program, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-102(7): The Legislature finds that soil health is essential to protecting the state's soil and water resources, bolstering the state's food supply, and sustaining the state's agricultural industry.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(1)(a): "Agricultural discharge" means the release of agriculture water from the property of a farm, ranch, or feedlot that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(1)(a)(i): pollutes a surface body of water, including a stream, lake, pond, marshland, watercourse, waterway, river, ditch, or other water conveyance system;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(1)(a)(ii): pollutes ground water; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(1)(a)(iii): constitutes a significant nuisance to urban land.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(1)(b): "Agricultural discharge" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(1)(b)(i): runoff from a farm, ranch, or feedlot, or the return flow of water from an irrigated field onto land that is not part of a body of water; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(1)(b)(ii): a release of water from a farm, ranch, or feedlot into a normally dry water conveyance leading to an active body of water, if the release does not reach the water of a lake, pond, stream, marshland, river, or other active body of water.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(2): "Agricultural operation" means a farm, ranch, or animal feeding operation.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(3): "Agriculture water" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(3)(a): water used by a farm, ranch, or feedlot for the production of food, fiber, or fuel;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(3)(b): the return flow of water from irrigated agriculture; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(3)(c): agricultural storm water runoff.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(4): "Alternate" means a substitute for a district supervisor if the district supervisor cannot attend a meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(5)(a): "Animal feeding operation" means a facility where animals, other than aquatic animals, are stabled or confined and fed or maintained for a total of 45 days or more in any 12-month period.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(5)(b): "Animal feeding operation" does not include an operation where animals are in areas such as pastures or rangeland that sustain crops or forage growth during the normal growing season.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(6): "Best management practices" means practices, including management policies and the use of technology, used by each sector of agriculture in the production of food and fiber that are commonly accepted practices, or that are at least as effective as commonly accepted practices, and that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(6)(a): protect the environment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(6)(b): protect human health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(6)(c): ensure the humane treatment of animals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(6)(d): promote the financial viability of agricultural production.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(7): 4-18-107 "Certified agricultural operation" means an agricultural operation that is certified under the Utah Agriculture Certificate of Environmental Stewardship Program in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(8): 4-18-107 "Certified conservation planner" means a planner of a state conservation district, or other qualified planner, that is approved by the commission to certify an agricultural operation under the Utah Agriculture Certificate of Environmental Stewardship Program, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(9): 4-18-104 "Commission" means the Conservation Commission created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(10): "Comprehensive nutrient management plan" or "nutrient management plan" means a plan to properly store, handle, and spread manure and other agricultural byproducts to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(10)(a): protect the environment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(10)(b): provide nutrients for the production of crops.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(11): "Coordinated resource management plan" means a plan of action created at a local level with broad participation of land owners, natural resource agencies, and interested stakeholders to protect or enhance the environment, human health, humane treatment of animals, and financial viability in the community.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(12): 17D-3-102 "District" or "conservation district" has the same meaning as "conservation district" as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(13): "Fodder" means food for livestock.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(14): "Hydroponic" means a technique for growing plants without soil.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(15): "Pollution" means a harmful human-made or human-induced alteration to the water of the state, including an alteration to the chemical, physical, biological, or radiological integrity of water that harms the water of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(16): "State technical standards" means a collection of best management practices that will protect the environment in a reasonable and economical manner for each sector of agriculture as required by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(17): "Sustainable agriculture" means agriculture production and practices that promote:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(17)(a): the environmental responsibility of owners and operators of farms, ranches, and feedlots; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-103(17)(b): the profitability of owners and operators of farms, ranches, and feedlots.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104 Conservation Commission created -- Composition -- Appointment -- Terms -- Compensation -- Attorney general to provide legal assistance.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(1): There is created within the department the Conservation Commission to perform the functions specified in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(2): The Conservation Commission shall be composed of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(2)(a): 12 voting members, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(2)(a)(i): the director of the Extension Service at Utah State University or the director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(2)(a)(ii): the executive director of the Department of Natural Resources or the executive director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(2)(a)(iii): the executive director of the Department of Environmental Quality or the executive director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(2)(a)(iv): the president of the County Weed Supervisors Association or the president's designee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(2)(a)(v): seven district supervisors who provide district representation on the commission on a multicounty basis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(2)(b): the commissioner or the commissioner's designee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(3): If a district supervisor is unable to attend a meeting, the district supervisor may designate an alternate to serve in the place of the district supervisor for that meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(4): None of the members described in Subsection (2)(a)(v) or (3) may serve on an association that represents a conservation district.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(5)(a): The commissioner or the commissioner's designee shall serve as chair of the Conservation Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(5)(b): The commissioner or the commissioner's designee may not vote except in the event of a tie, in which case the commissioner or the commissioner's designee shall cast the deciding vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(6): The members of the commission specified in Subsection (2)(a)(v) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(6)(a): be recommended by the commission to the governor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(6)(b): be appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 2, Vacancies.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(7)(a): Except as required by Subsection (7)(b), as terms of current commission members expire, the governor shall appoint each new member or reappointed member to a four-year term.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(7)(b): Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection (7)(a), the governor shall, at the time of appointment or reappointment, adjust the length of terms to ensure that the terms of commission members are staggered so that approximately half of the commission is appointed every two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(7)(c): A commission member may not be appointed to more than two consecutive terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(8): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(9): When the governor makes a new appointment or reappointment under Subsection (7)(a), or a vacancy appointment under Subsection (8), the governor's new appointment, reappointment, or vacancy appointment shall be made with the advice and consent of the Senate in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 2, Vacancies.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(10): Attendance of six voting members of the commission at a meeting constitutes a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(11): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(11)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(11)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(11)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(12): The commission shall keep a record of the commission's actions.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(13): The attorney general shall provide legal services to the commission upon request.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-104(14): A member shall comply with the conflict of interest provisions described in Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 3, Conflicts of Interest.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-201 Title -- Definitions.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-201(1): This part is known as "Salinity Offset Fund."
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-201(2): As used in this part, "Colorado River Salinity Offset Program" means a program, administered by the Division of Water Quality, allowing oil, gas, or mining companies and other entities to provide funds to finance salinity reduction projects in the Colorado River Basin by purchasing salinity credits as offsets against discharges made by the company under permits issued by the Division of Water Quality.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-301 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Utah Soil Health Program."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(1): 4-1-109 "Agricultural producer" means a person engaged in the production of a product of agriculture, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(2): 4-18-104 "Commission" means the Conservation Commission created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(3): "Commissioner" means the commissioner of agriculture and food or the commissioner's designee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(4): "Demonstration project" means an on- or off-farm or ranch project that incorporates soil health practices and principles into soil management for the purposes of demonstrating soil health practices and the resulting impacts to agricultural producers and others.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(5)(a): "Educational project" means a project that promotes knowledge about soil health to eligible entities, consumers, policymakers, and others.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(5)(b): "Educational project" includes the development of written or video-based materials or in-person events, such as workshops, field days, or conferences.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(6): "Eligible entities" means public, governmental, and private entities, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(6)(a): conservation districts;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(6)(b): producers;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(6)(c): groups of producers;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(6)(d): producer groups;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(6)(e): producer cooperatives;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(6)(f): water conservancy districts;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(6)(g): American Indian Tribes;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(6)(h): nonprofit entities;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(6)(i): academic or research institutions and subdivisions of these institutions;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(6)(j): the United States or any corporation or agency created or designed by the United States; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(6)(k): the state or any of the state's agencies or political subdivisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(7): "Environmental benefits" means benefits to natural and agricultural resources and human health, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(7)(a): improved air quality;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(7)(b): surface or ground water quality and quantity;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(7)(c): improved soil health, including nutrient cycling, soil fertility, or drought resilience;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(7)(d): reductions in agricultural inputs;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(7)(e): carbon sequestration or climate resilience;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(7)(f): increased biodiversity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(7)(g): improved nutritional quality of agricultural products.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(8): "Historically underserved producer" means a producer who qualifies as one of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(8)(a): a beginning farmer or rancher, as defined in 7 U.S.C. Sec. 2279;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(8)(b): a limited resource farmer or rancher, as described in 7 U.S.C. Sec. 9081;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(8)(c): a socially disadvantaged farmer or rancher, as defined in 7 U.S.C. Sec. 2003; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(8)(d): a veteran farmer or rancher, as defined in 7 U.S.C. Sec. 1502.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(9): "Implementation project" means a project that provides incentives directly to producers to implement on-farm or on-ranch soil health practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(10): "Incentives" means monetary incentives, including grants and loans, or non-monetary incentives, including equipment, technical assistance, educational materials, outreach, and market development assistance for market premiums or ecosystem services markets.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(11): "Land manager" means a manager of land where agricultural activities occur, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(11)(a): a federal land manager;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(11)(b): a lessee of federal, tribal, state, county, municipal, or private land where agricultural activities occur; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(11)(c): others as the department may determine.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(12): "Landowner" means an owner of record of federal, tribal, state, county, municipal, or private land where agricultural activities occur.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(13): 4-18-303 "Program" means the Utah Soil Health Program created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(14): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(14)(a): "Research project" means a project that advances the scientific understanding of how agricultural practices improve soil health, and related impacts, such as environmental benefits, benefits to human health, including the nutritive composition of foods, or economic impacts.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(14)(b): "Research project" includes projects at experiment stations, on:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(14)(b)(i): lands owned by the United States or any corporation or agency created or designed by the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(14)(b)(ii): lands owned by the state or any of the state's agencies or political subdivisions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(14)(b)(iii): private lands.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(15): "Soil health" means the continued capacity of soil to function as a vital living ecosystem that sustains plants, animals, and humans.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(16): "Soil health activities" means implementation of soil health practices, research projects, demonstration projects, or educational projects, or other activities the department finds necessary or appropriate to promote soil health.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(17): 4-18-306 "Soil Health Advisory Committee" means the committee created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(18): 4-18-304 "Soil health grant program" means the grant program authorized in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(19): "Soil health practices" means those practices that may contribute to soil health, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(19)(a): no-tillage;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(19)(b): conservation tillage;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(19)(c): crop rotations;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(19)(d): intercropping;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(19)(e): cover cropping;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(19)(f): planned grazing;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(19)(g): the application of soil amendments that add carbon or organic matter, including biosolids, manure, compost, or biochar;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(19)(h): revegetation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(19)(i): other practices the department determines contribute or have the potential to contribute to soil health.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(20): "Soil health principle" means a principle that promotes soil health and includes maximizing soil cover, minimizing soil disturbance, maximizing biodiversity, maintaining a continual live plant or root in the soil, or integrating livestock.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(21): "State soil health inventory and platform" means a tool, including a geospatial inventory, documenting:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(21)(a): the condition of agricultural soils;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(21)(b): the implementation of soil health practices; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(21)(c): the environmental and economic impacts, including current and potential future carbon holding capacity of soils, or other information the department considers appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-302(22): "Technical assistance organization" means a person, including an eligible entity, who has demonstrated technical expertise in implementing soil health practices and soil health principles, as determined by the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303 Creates Utah Soil Health Program -- Program and purposes.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(1): Under the commission there is created the Utah Soil Health Program.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(2): The program shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(2)(a): encourage widespread adoption of soil health practices by producers;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(2)(b): promote environmental benefits;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(2)(c): advance the understanding of the environmental and economic benefits of soil health practices by producers, policymakers, consumers, and the general public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(2)(d): support scientific research.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(3): (2) The program may obtain the objectives described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(3)(a): providing incentives to implement soil health practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(3)(b): increasing the understanding of the benefit of soil health practices through education and outreach programs;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(3)(c): advancing scientific understanding of soil health as it relates to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(3)(c)(i): the existing conditions of Utah's agricultural soils, including current carbon storage and carbon storage potential;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(3)(c)(ii): the on- and off-farm or ranch environmental benefits of soil health practices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(3)(c)(iii): the on- and off-farm or ranch economic benefits of soil health practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(3)(d): evaluating currently available or developing new consistent soil health sampling and testing protocols appropriate for Utah's agricultural systems; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(3)(e): facilitating multi-stakeholder collaboration to advance the understanding of the science of soil health and the implementation of soil health practices, including amongst the federal government and the federal government's agencies, agencies and political subdivisions of the state, academic or research institutions, non-governmental organizations, private entities, nonprofits, producers, or other parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-303(4): The department shall provide support to the commission in implementing the program.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304 Program development.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304(1): 4-18-306; 4-18-305(1)(e) In consultation with the Soil Health Advisory Committee created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304(1)(a): a grant program for eligible entities to engage in soil health activities including implementation, research, education, or demonstration projects;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304(1)(b): a state soil health monitoring and inventory platform; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304(1)(c): other programs the commission considers appropriate or necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304(2): (1) In establishing a program in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304(3): A program established pursuant to this section shall be voluntary and incentive-based and may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304(3)(a): require participation by an eligible entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304(3)(b): mandate the implementation of soil health practices by non-participating entities; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304(3)(c): bind participants to execute specific practice standards in adverse climate conditions or circumstances with limited or no chance of success or that would cause irreparable physical or economic harm to the producer's operation physically or economically.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304(4): 4-18-307 In addition to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304(4)(a): the commission, grantees, partners, or other program participants may not disclose, sell, or otherwise provide information that could be used to identify the agricultural operations or practices of program participants without express permission provided in writing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304(4)(b): in determining whether information may be released, the private interests of a participant are presumed to outweigh the public interest in disclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-304(5): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 4-18-305 The commission shall act as the policy board to set guidelines by rule, made in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306 Soil Health Advisory Committee.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(1): The Soil Health Advisory Committee is created under the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(2): The Soil Health Advisory Committee shall assist the commission in administering the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(3): The Soil Health Advisory Committee shall maintain no less than seven members appointed by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(4): Soil Health Advisory Committee members shall include farmers, ranchers, or other agricultural producers of diverse production systems, including diversity in size, product, irrigated and dryland systems, and other production methods. Members may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(4)(a): an irrigated crop producer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(4)(b): a dryland crop producer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(4)(c): a dairyman or pasture producer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(4)(d): a rancher;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(4)(e): a specialty crop or small farm producer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(4)(f): a crop consultant;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(4)(g): a tribal representative;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(4)(h): a representative with expertise in soil health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(4)(i): a committee member representative of the commission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(4)(j): a Utah Association of Conservation Districts representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(5): At least two members of the Soil Health Advisory Committee shall be water users who own, lease, or represent owners of adjudicated water rights used for agricultural purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(6): Representation on the Soil Health Advisory Committee shall reflect the different geographic areas and demographic diversity of the state, to the greatest extent possible.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(7): (7)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(7)(a): The commissioner shall appoint members of the Soil Health Advisory Committee for four year terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(7)(b): (7)(a) Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(7)(c): An appointee to the Soil Health Advisory Committee may not serve more than two full terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(8): A Soil Health Advisory Committee member shall hold office until the expiration of the term for which the member is appointed or until a successor has been duly appointed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(9): The commissioner may remove a member of the Soil Health Advisory Committee for cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(10): The Soil Health Advisory Committee may invite a representative of the Utah Association of Conservation Districts, the United States Department of Agriculture Natural Resources Conservation Service, Utah State University faculty member, the Department of Natural Resources, Division of Water Rights, and Division of Water Quality, to provide technical expertise to the Soil Health Advisory Committee on an as needed basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(11): The department will provide staff to manage the Soil Advisory Health Committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(12): 4-18-305(1)(f) The Soil Health Advisory Committee shall make recommendations to the commission concerning and assist in:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(12)(a): setting program priorities;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(12)(b): developing the development of guidelines for the implementation of the program, including guidelines and recommendations for the qualifications of nonprofit entities to receive grant money;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(12)(c): soliciting input from similar stakeholders within each member's area of expertise and region of the state and communicate the Soil Health Advisory Committee's recommendations to the region and stakeholders represented by each member;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(12)(d): soliciting input, in collaboration with the department, from underserved agricultural producers;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(12)(e): soliciting input from producers that reflect the different geographic areas and demographic diversity of the state to the greatest extent possible;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(12)(f): identifying key questions and areas of need to recommend for future research and demonstration efforts;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(12)(g): reviewing soil health grant proposals, including proposed budgets, proposed grant outcomes, and the qualifications of any nonprofits applying for grants;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(12)(h): creating a screening and ranking system for proposals and proposing funding recommendations to the commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(12)(i): 4-18-305(1)(f) reviewing agreements for cooperation or collaboration entered into by the department pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(12)(j): reviewing and recommending soil health practices to ensure they support soil health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(12)(k): evaluating the results and effectiveness of soil health activities and the program in improving soil health; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-306(12)(l): recommending to the commission, ways to enhance statewide efforts to support healthy soils throughout the state.
