Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-307 Producer and landowner information - confidentiality.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-307(1): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act With regard to information that constitutes a record under
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-307(2): In determining whether a record may be released, private interests are presumed to outweigh the public interest in disclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-307(3): Summary or aggregated data that does not specifically identify agricultural practices of an individual landowner or producer is not subject to this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-308 Reporting requirement.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-308(1): Each year, before November 1, the department shall prepare and make available to the public a report on the department's official website that contains the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-308(1)(a): an accounting of money received and spent for the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-308(1)(b): a description of activities undertaken, including the number and type of grant-funded projects and the educational and stakeholder engagement activities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-308(1)(c): a summary of the activities and recommendations of the Soil Health Advisory Committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-18-308(2): The commissioner shall annually report to the Natural Resources, Agriculture, and Environment Interim Committee by no later than the November interim meeting of that committee.  The report shall include the information described in Subsection (1).


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 19 - Rural Rehabilitation
*****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Rural Rehabilitation."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-102 Department responsible for conduct and administration of rural rehabilitation program.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall conduct and administer the rural rehabilitation program within the state in accordance with the agreement entered into in January 1975, between the United States of America through its Farm Home Administration and the state through its commissioner.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-103 Department authorized to approve and make grants and loans, acquire property, and lease or operate property.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department, in conjunction with the administration of the rural rehabilitation program, may:Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-103(1): Title 3, Uniform Agricultural Cooperative Association Act; 4-19-104 approve and make a loan to a farm or agricultural cooperative association regulated under
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-103(1)(a): taking security for the loan through a mortgage, trust deed, pledge, or other security device;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-103(1)(b): purchasing a promissory note, real estate contract, mortgage, trust deed, or other instrument or evidence of indebtedness; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-103(1)(c): collecting, compromising, canceling, or adjusting a claim or obligation arising out of the administration of the rural rehabilitation program;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-103(2): purchase or otherwise obtain property in which the department has acquired an interest on account of a mortgage, trust deed, lien, pledge, assignment, judgment, or other means at any execution or foreclosure sale;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-103(3): operate or lease, if necessary to protect its investment, property in which it has an interest, or sell or otherwise dispose of the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-103(4): approve and make an education loan or an education grant to an individual for the purpose of attending a vocational school, college, or university to obtain additional education, qualifications, or skills.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-104 Loans -- Not to exceed period of 10 years -- Agricultural Advisory Board executive committee to approve loans and renewals, methods of payments, and interest rates -- Guidelines in fixing interest rates declared.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-104(1): The department may not make a loan authorized under this chapter for a period to exceed 10 years, but the loan is renewable.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-104(2): (5); 4-2-108 Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-104(2)(a): loans and renewals;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-104(2)(b): the methods of repayment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-104(2)(c): the interest rates charged.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-104(3): In fixing interest rates, the Agricultural Advisory Board executive committee shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-104(3)(a): the current applicable interest rate or rates being charged by the USDA Farm Service Agency on similar loans;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-104(3)(b): the current prime rate charged by leading lending institutions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-104(3)(c): any other pertinent economic data.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-104(4): The interest rates established shall be compatible with guidelines stated in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-104(5): The Agricultural Advisory Board executive committee may create a subcommittee from the Agricultural Advisory Board membership to approve a loan or renewal under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-105 Utah Rural Rehabilitation Fund.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-105(1): The department shall deposit all income generated from the administration of the rural rehabilitation program in a separate fund known as the "Utah Rural Rehabilitation Fund."
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-105(2): The Division of Finance shall maintain the Utah Rural Rehabilitation Fund and record all debits and credits made to the fund by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-19-105(3): The Office of the Treasurer shall deposit interest and other earnings derived from investment of money in the Utah Rural Rehabilitation Fund into the fund.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 4-20-108 Commissioner to supervise distribution of undistributed funds if United States alters or discontinues funding leaving funds or resources available.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the United States alters or discontinues funding under the Taylor Grazing Act, 43 U.S.C. Sec. 315 et seq., or the operation of advisory boards, leaving funds or other resources undistributed or otherwise without means for continuation, the commissioner shall supervise and control the distribution of such undistributed funds or other resources.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 21 - Beef Promotion
***********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Beef Promotion."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-102(1): 4-21-103 "Council" means the Utah Beef Council created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-102(2): 4-2-102 "Department" means the Utah Department of Agriculture and Food created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-102(3): "Marketing agency" means a person who acts as an agent of the seller in the sale of cattle in that the person issues payment to the seller and is entitled to a commission based upon the sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-102(4): "Producer" means a person who owns and raises or owns and feeds cattle.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-102(5): "Purchaser" means a person who buys cattle.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-102(6): "Seller" means a person who offers cattle for sale.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103 Utah Beef Council created -- Composition -- Nomination and selection of appointed members -- Terms of appointed members -- Qualifications for nomination.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(1): There is created an independent state agency known as the Utah Beef Council.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(2): (4) The Utah Beef Council consists of 10 members as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(2)(a): the commissioner of the Utah Department of Agriculture and Food, or the commissioner's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(2)(b): the president of the Utah Cattlemen's Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(2)(c): the vice president of the Utah Cattlemen's Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(2)(d): a member of the Utah Cattlemen's Association board of directors, chosen by the Utah Cattlemen's Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(2)(e): the appointee from Utah on the national beef checkoff Cattlemen's Beef Promotion and Research Board, appointed by the United States Secretary of Agriculture;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(2)(f): the president of the Utah Cattlewomen's Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(2)(g): a member of the Utah Dairy Commission, chosen by the Utah Dairy Commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(2)(h): (4) three at-large producers from the state of Utah, appointed as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(3): (2) In addition to the members listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(4)(a): At-large candidates for appointment to the council shall be nominated by a formal written request signed by two or more producers and submitted to the council no later than October 1.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(4)(b): A membership committee, consisting of the commissioner or the commissioner's designee, the council member representing the Utah Dairy Commission, and the president of the Utah Cattlemen's Association shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(4)(b)(i): select candidates for appointment to the council from the nominees submitted by producers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(4)(b)(ii): present the candidates to the governor for review and appointment on or before December 1.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(5): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(5)(a): The governor shall appoint the at-large members to three-year terms beginning on January 1 of the year following appointment to the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(5)(b): (5)(a) Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(6): Each at-large member shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(6)(a): a citizen of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(6)(b): 18 years of age or older;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(6)(c): an active producer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-103(6)(d): a resident of Utah.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104 Council -- Organization -- Quorum to transact business -- Removal for cause -- Vacancies -- Ineligibility to serve -- Compensation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(1): (1)(a); 4-21-103(2)(a); (e); (h)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(1)(a): The council members shall elect a chair, vice chair, and secretary annually from the voting members of the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(1)(b): (1)(a); 4-21-103(2)(a); (e); (h) At least two of the members elected pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(2)(a): A majority of voting members shall constitute a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(2)(b): A majority vote of the quorum is necessary for the council to act.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(3): The council shall meet:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(3)(a): at the time and place designated by the chair; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(3)(b): no less than once every three months.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(4): The commissioner, or the commissioner's designee, may, in consultation with the other members of the membership committee, remove a member for cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(5): Vacancies that occur on the council for any reason shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term of the vacated member.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(6): If an at-large member ceases to act as a producer during the member's term, the member shall resign from the council within 30 days after ceasing production.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(7): (8); 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 Subject to Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-104(8): A nonvoting member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service and may not receive per diem or travel expenses.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105 Council powers, duties, and functions -- Reporting requirements.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(1): The council has the following powers, duties, and functions:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(1)(a): hire and fix the salary of an administrator and staff, who may not be members of the council, to administer the policies adopted and perform the duties assigned by the council;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(1)(b): promote the beef industry of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(1)(c): encourage local, national, and international use of Utah beef, through advertising or otherwise;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(1)(d): investigate and participate in studies of problems unique to Utah producers;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(1)(e): take actions consistent with this chapter to promote, protect, and stabilize the state's beef industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(1)(f): enter into contracts and incur indebtedness in furtherance of the council's business activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(1)(g): cooperate with local, state, or national organizations engaged in activities similar to those of the council;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(1)(h): accept grants, donations, or gifts for use consistent with this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(1)(i): do other things necessary for the efficient and effective management and operation of the council's business.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(2): The council shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(2)(a): submit the council's proposed budget and an end-of-year audited financial statement to the department and the Office of the State Auditor within 180 days of the end of each fiscal year;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(2)(b): provide the department, on an annual basis, with a detailed outline of the council's plans for future publications and messaging; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-105(2)(c): report, by October 1 of each year, to the Retirement and Independent Entities Interim Committee on the operations and activities of the council.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-107 Council may require surety bond -- Payment of premium.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-107(1): The council may require the administrator or a council employee to post a surety bond conditioned for the faithful performance of the council's official duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-107(2): The amount and type of bond shall be fixed by the council and each bond premium shall be paid by the council.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-201 Beef promotion fee -- Deposit of revenue.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-201(1): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-201(1)(a): (2) The department shall collect a fee established as required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-201(1)(b): The fee is collected by the local brand inspector at the time of inspection of cattle, or deducted and collected by the marketing agency or the purchaser.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-201(1)(c): All revenue collected under this section shall be paid to the department, which shall deposit the revenue in a fund that is hereby created and is known as the "Beef Promotion Fund."
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-201(2): (1) Any fee currently assessed by the department continues in effect until modified by the department under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-201(3): The fee assessed under this section is in addition to the amount of any assessment required to be paid pursuant to the Beef Promotion and Research Act of 1985, 7 U.S.C. Sec. 2901 et seq.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-202 Refund of fees allowed -- Claim for refund to be filed with department -- Payment of refunds.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-202(1): A person who objects to payment of the assessed fee may file a claim with the department within 60 days after the fee is collected.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-202(2): A claim for refund is not allowed if it is filed more than 60 days after the date the fee is collected.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-202(3): Each claim for a refund shall be certified by the department to the state treasurer for payment from the beef promotion account, subject to applicable provisions of the Beef Promotion and Research Act of 1985, 7 U.S.C.  Sec.  2901 et seq.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-203 Revenue from fees to be used to promote beef industry -- Payment of revenue monthly to Utah Beef Council -- Deduction of costs of administration and processing funds -- Annual audit of books, records, and accounts -- Financial statement of audit published.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-203(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-203(1)(a): All revenue derived from the collection of fees authorized by this chapter shall be paid to the council and used to promote the beef industry of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-203(1)(b): The revenue shall be paid monthly, as requested by the council, and the actual costs of administration for processing the funds shall be deducted before disbursing the funds.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-203(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-203(2)(a): The books, records, and accounts of the council shall be audited at least once annually by a licensed accountant approved by the Office of the State Auditor.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-203(2)(b): The results of the audit shall be submitted to the commissioner, and a financial statement of the audit and a general statement of operations and promotional and advertising activities shall be published by the council in a major livestock publication having general circulation in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-203(3): The books, records, and accounts of the council's activities are public records.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-301 State disclaimer of liability.
-------------------------------------------------------------
The state is not liable for the acts or omissions of the council, council officers, agents, or employees.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-302 Council not eligible for coverage under Risk Management Fund.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The council is not eligible to receive coverage under the Risk Management Fund created by Section

Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-303 Representation by the attorney general.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-303(1): The attorney general is not the legal advisor for the council and has no obligation to defend the council or the council's members in an action or proceeding brought against the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-21-303(2): The attorney general may choose, at its sole discretion, to represent the council or its members if requested to do so and pursuant to reimbursement by contract.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 22 - Dairy Promotion
************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Dairy Promotion."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-102(1): "Commission" means the Utah Dairy Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-102(2): "Dealer" means any person who buys and processes raw milk or milk fat, or who acts as agent in the sale or purchase of raw milk or milk fat, or who acts as a broker or factor with respect to raw milk or milk fat or any product derived from either.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-102(3): "Producer" means a person who produces milk or milk fat from cows and who sells it for human or animal consumption, or for medicinal or industrial uses.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-102(4): "Producer-handler" means any producer who processes raw milk or milk fat.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-103 Utah Dairy Commission created.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-104 Commission -- Organization -- Quorum to transact business -- Vacancies -- Ineligibility to serve -- Compensation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-104(1): The members of the commission shall elect a chair, vice chair, and secretary from the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-104(2): Attendance of a simple majority of the commission members at a called meeting shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of official business.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-104(3)(b): no less often than once every three months.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-104(4): Vacancies that occur on the commission for any reason shall be filled for the unexpired term of the vacated member by appointment of a majority of the remaining members.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-104(5): If a member moves from the district that the member represents or ceases to act as a producer during the member's term of office, the member shall resign from the commission within 30 days after moving from the district or ceasing production.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-105 Commission to conduct elections -- Nomination of candidates -- Expenses of election paid by commission.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-105(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-105(1)(a): The commissioner shall administer all commission elections.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-105(1)(b): The commissioner shall mail a ballot to each producer within the district in which an election is to be held by May 15 of each election year.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-105(1)(c): The candidate who receives the highest number of votes cast in the candidate's district shall be elected.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-105(1)(d): The commissioner shall determine all questions of eligibility.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-105(1)(e): A ballot shall be postmarked by May 31 of an election year.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-105(1)(f): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-105(1)(f)(i): All ballots received by the commissioner shall be counted and tallied by June 15.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-105(1)(f)(ii): A member of the commission whose name appears on a ballot may not participate in counting or tallying the ballots.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-105(2): Candidates for election to the commission shall be nominated, not later than April 15, by a petition signed by two or more producers who are residents of the district in which the election is to be held.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-105(3): The names of all nominees shall be submitted to the commissioner on or before May 1 of each election year.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-105(4): All election expenses incurred by the commissioner shall be paid by the commission.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-106 Commission powers, duties, and functions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
The commission has and shall exercise the following functions, powers, and duties:Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-106(1): to use one of the following means to administer the policies adopted, and perform the duties assigned, by the commission:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-106(1)(a): employ and fix the compensation of one or more individuals who are not members of the commission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-106(1)(b): retain and fix the compensation of an entity, including an entity engaged in activities similar to the commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-106(2): to conduct a campaign of research, nutritional education, and publicity, showing the value of milk, cream, and dairy products;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-106(3): to encourage local, national, and international use of Utah dairy products and by-products, through marketing or otherwise;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-106(4): to investigate and participate in studies of problems peculiar to producers in Utah and to take the actions consistent with this chapter in an effort to promote, protect, and stabilize the state dairy industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-106(5): 4-22-201 to sue and be sued, prosecute actions in the name of the state for the collection of the assessment imposed by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-106(6): to cooperate with any local, state, or national organization engaged in activities similar to those of the commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-106(7): to accept grants, donations, or gifts for use consistent with this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-106(8): to do other things necessary for the efficient and effective management and operation of the commission's business.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-107(1)(d)(ii): at competitive prices;

Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-108 Commission may require surety bond -- Payment of premium.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The commission may require the administrator, or any commission employees, to post a surety bond conditioned for the faithful performance of the commission's official duties. The amount, form, and kind of such a bond shall be fixed by the commission and each bond premium shall be paid by the commission.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201 Assessment imposed on sale of milk or cream produced, sold, or contracted for sale in state -- Time of assessment -- Collection by dealer or producer-handler -- Penalty for delinquent payment or collection -- Statement to be given to producer.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(1): An assessment of 10 cents is imposed upon each 100 pounds of milk or cream produced and sold, or contracted for sale, through commercial channels in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(2): The assessment shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(2)(a): based upon daily or monthly settlements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(2)(b): due at a time set by the commission, which may not be later than the last day of the month next succeeding the month of sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(3)(a): The assessment shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(3)(a)(i): assessed against the producer at the time the milk or milk fat is delivered for sale;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(3)(a)(ii): deducted from the sales price; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(3)(a)(iii): collected by the dealer or producer-handler.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(3)(b): The proceeds of the assessment shall be paid directly to the commission who shall issue a receipt to the dealer or producer-handler.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(3)(c): If a dealer or producer-handler fails to remit the proceeds of the assessment or deduct the assessment on time:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(3)(c)(i): a penalty equal to 10% of the amount due is to be added to the assessment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(3)(c)(ii): the commission may bring an action against the dealer or producer-handler for:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(3)(c)(ii)(A): injunctive relief compelling payment of the assessment and penalty;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(3)(c)(ii)(B): damages, including interest at the statutory prejudgment rate from the date the payment was due;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(3)(c)(ii)(C): costs of collection, including reasonable attorney fees, whether incurred in litigation or otherwise; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(3)(c)(ii)(D): other relief to which the commission may be entitled at law or in equity.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(4)(a): At the time of payment of the assessment, the dealer or producer-handler shall deliver a statement to the producer calculating the assessment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(4)(b): The commission may require other relevant information to be included in the statement.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-201(5): If the mandatory assessment required by the Dairy and Tobacco Adjustment Act of 1983, Pub. L. No. 98-180, 97 Stat. 1128 (1150.152), is abolished, a producer who objects to payment of the assessment imposed under this section may, by January 31, submit a written request to the commission for a refund of the amount of the assessment the producer paid during the previous year.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202 Revenue from assessment used to promote dairy industry -- Deposit of money -- Annual audit of books, records, and accounts -- Annual financial report to producers.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(1): 4-22-201 The revenue derived from the assessment imposed by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(1)(a): administration of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(1)(b): promotion of the state's dairy industry.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(2): The commission may deposit the proceeds of the assessment in one or more accounts in one or more banks approved by the state as depositories.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(3)(a): The commission shall keep a voucher, receipt, or other written record for each withdrawal from the commission accounts.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(3)(b): Money may not be withdrawn from the commission accounts except:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(3)(b)(i): upon order of the commission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(3)(b)(ii): pursuant to a procedure adopted by the commission if the withdrawal is subsequently ratified by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(4): The books, records, and accounts of the commission's activities are public records.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(5)(a): The accounts of the commission shall be audited once annually by a licensed accountant selected by the commission and approved by the state auditor.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(5)(b): The results of the audit shall be submitted to the:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(5)(b)(i): commissioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(5)(b)(ii): commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(5)(b)(iii): Division of Finance.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-202(5)(c): The commission shall send annually a financial report to each producer.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-203 Additional assessment for government liaison and industry relations programs -- Exemption from the assessment.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-203(1): 4-22-201; (3) In addition to the assessment provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-203(2): 4-22-201 The three-fourths of one cent assessment shall be paid in the same manner as the assessment required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-203(3): The commission shall use the revenue derived from the three-fourths of one cent assessment imposed by this section to contract out for services and expenses of government liaison and industry relations programs created to stabilize and protect the state's dairy industry and the health and welfare of the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-203(4): A producer who objects to payment of the assessment imposed by this section may, by January 31, submit a written request to the commission to be exempted from payment of the assessment for that year.  By January 1 each year, the commission shall send to each person subject to the assessment a postage-paid, self-addressed postcard which may be returned to request an exemption.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-301 State disclaimer of liability.
-------------------------------------------------------------
The state is not liable for the acts or omissions of the commission, commission officers, agents, or employees.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The commission is not eligible to receive coverage under the Risk Management Fund created under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 4-22-303 Enforcement -- Inspection of books and records of dealer or producer-handler.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The commission at reasonable times may enter upon the premises and inspect the records of any dealer or producer-handler for the purpose of enforcing this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 23 - Agricultural and Wildlife Damage Prevention Act
********************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Agricultural and Wildlife Damage Prevention Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-102 Purpose declaration.
---------------------------------------------------
The Legislature finds and declares that it is important to the economy of the state to maintain agricultural production at the highest possible level and at the same time, to promote, to protect, and preserve the wildlife resources of the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-103 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-103(1): "Agricultural crops" means any product of cultivation;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-103(2): "Board" means the Agricultural and Wildlife Damage Prevention Board;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-103(3): "Bounty" means the monetary compensation paid to persons for the harvest of predatory or depredating animals;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-103(4): "Damage" means any injury or loss to livestock, poultry, agricultural crops, or wildlife inflicted by predatory or depredating animals or depredating birds;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-103(5): "Depredating animal" means a field mouse, gopher, ground squirrel, jack rabbit, raccoon, or prairie dog;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-103(6): "Depredating bird" means a Brewer's blackbird or starling;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-103(7): "Livestock" means cattle, horses, mules, sheep, goats, and swine;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-103(8): "Predatory animal" means any coyote; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-103(9): "Wildlife" means any form of animal life generally living in a state of nature, except a predatory animal or a depredating animal or bird.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104 Agricultural and Wildlife Damage Prevention Board created -- Composition -- Appointment -- Terms -- Vacancies -- Compensation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(1): There is created an Agricultural and Wildlife Damage Prevention Board composed of the commissioner and the director of the Division of Wildlife Resources who shall serve, respectively, as the board's chair and vice chair together with seven other members appointed by the governor to four-year terms of office as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(1)(a): one sheep producer representing wool growers of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(1)(b): one cattle producer representing range cattle producers of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(1)(c): one person from an organization representing the agricultural interests of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(1)(d): one agricultural landowner representing agricultural landowners of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(1)(e): one person representing the wildlife interests of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(1)(f): one person from the United States Forest Service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(1)(g): one person from the United States Bureau of Land Management.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(2): Appointees' term of office shall commence June 1.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(3)(a): Except as required by Subsection (3)(b), as terms of current board members expire, the governor shall appoint each new member or reappointed member to a four-year term.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(3)(b): Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection (3)(a), the governor shall, at the time of appointment or reappointment, adjust the length of terms to ensure that the terms of board members are staggered so that approximately half of the board is appointed every two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(4): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(5)(a): Attendance of five members at a duly called meeting shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of official business.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(5)(b): The board shall convene at the times and places prescribed by the chair or vice chair.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(6): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(6)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(6)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-104(6)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-105 Board responsibilities -- Damage prevention policy -- Rules -- Methods to control predators and depredating birds and animals.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-105(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The board is responsible for the formulation of the agricultural and wildlife damage prevention policy of the state and may, consistent with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-105(2): In the board's policy deliberations the board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-105(2)(a): specify programs designed to prevent damage to livestock, poultry, and agricultural crops; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-105(2)(b): specify methods for the prevention of damage and for the selective control of predators and depredating birds and animals including hunting, trapping, chemical toxicants, and the use of aircraft.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-105(3): The board may also:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-105(3)(a): specify bounties on designated predatory animals and recommend procedures for the payment of bounty claims, recommend bounty districts, recommend persons not authorized to receive bounty, and recommend to the department other actions the board considers advisable for the enforcement of the board's policies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-105(3)(b): cooperate with federal, state, and local governments, educational institutions, and private persons or organizations, through agreement or otherwise, to effectuate the board's policies.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106 Department to issue licenses and permits -- Department to issue aircraft use permits -- Aerial hunting.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106(1): The department is responsible for the issuance of permits and licenses for the purposes of the federal Fish and Wildlife Act of 1956.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106(2): A private person may not use an aircraft for the prevention of damage without first obtaining a use permit from the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106(3): The department may issue an annual permit for aerial hunting to a private person for the protection of land, water, wildlife, livestock, domesticated animals, human life, or crops, if the person shows that the person or the person's designated pilot, along with the aircraft to be used in the aerial hunting, are licensed and qualified in accordance with the requirements of the department set by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106(4): The department may predicate the issuance or retention of a permit for aerial hunting upon the permittee's full and prompt disclosure of information as the department may request for submission pursuant to rules made by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106(5): 63J-1-504 The department shall collect an annual fee, set in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106(6): Aerial hunting activity under a permit issued by the department is restricted to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106(6)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106(6)(a)(i): private lands that are owned or managed by the permittee;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106(6)(a)(ii): state grazing allotments where the permittee is permitted by the state or the State Institutional Trust Lands Administration to graze livestock; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106(6)(a)(iii): federal grazing allotments where the permittee is permitted by the United States Bureau of Land Management or United States Forest Service to graze livestock; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106(6)(b): only during the time period for which the private land owner has provided written permission for the aerial hunting.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106(7): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The department shall make rules, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-106(8): 23A-1-101; 23A-5-315 The issuance of an aerial hunting permit or license under this section does not authorize the holder to use aircraft to hunt, pursue, shoot, wound, kill, trap, capture, or collect protected wildlife, as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107 Annual fees on sheep, goats, cattle, and turkeys -- Determination by board -- Collection methods.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(1): To assist the department in meeting the annual expense of administering this chapter, the following annual predator control fees are imposed upon animals owned by persons whose interests this chapter is designed to protect:Sheep and goats (except on farm dairy
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(2): The amount of the fees imposed upon each category of animals specified in this section shall be determined by the board annually on or before January 1 of each year.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(3)(a): Fee brand inspected cattle are subject to a predator control fee upon change of ownership or slaughter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(3)(b): The fee shall be collected by the local brand inspector at the time of the inspection of cattle, or withheld and paid by the market from proceeds derived from the sale of the cattle.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(3)(c): Cattle that are fee brand inspected prior to confinement to a feedlot are not subject to any subsequent predator control fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(4)(a): Fleece of sheared sheep is subject to a predator control fee upon sale of the fleece.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(4)(b)(i): The fee shall be withheld and paid by the marketing agency or purchaser of wool from proceeds derived from the sale of the fleece.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(4)(b)(ii): The department shall enter into cooperative agreements with in-state and out-of-state wool warehouses and wool processing facilities for the collection of predator control fees on the fleece of sheep that graze on private or public range in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(4)(c): The fee shall be based on the number of pounds of wool divided by 10 pounds for white face sheep and five pounds for black face sheep.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(5): Predator control fees on turkey breeding stock shall be paid by the turkey cooperative.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(6): (3); (4); (6)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(6)(a): (3); (4) Livestock owners shall pay a predator control fee on any livestock that uses public or private range in the state which is not otherwise subject to the fee under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(6)(b): (6)(a) By January 1, the commissioner shall mail to each owner of livestock specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(6)(c): Each owner shall file the completed form and the appropriate fee with the commissioner before April 1.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(6)(d): If any person who receives the reporting form fails to return the completed form and the imposed fee as required, the commissioner is authorized to commence suit through the office of the attorney general, in a court of competent jurisdiction, to collect the imposed fee, the amount of which shall be as determined by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-107(7): All fees collected under this section shall be remitted to the department and deposited in the Agricultural and Wildlife Damage Prevention Account.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-108 Agricultural and Wildlife Damage Prevention Account.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-108(1): There is created in the General Fund a restricted account known as the Agricultural and Wildlife Damage Prevention Account.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-110 Applicability of chapter.
--------------------------------------------------------
This chapter, unless contrary to a federal statute, shall apply to all federal, state, and private lands.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-111 Holding a raccoon or coyote in captivity prohibited -- Penalty.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-111(1): No individual may hold in captivity a raccoon or coyote, except as provided by rules of the Agricultural and Wildlife Damage Prevention Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-111(2): The Division of Wildlife Resources, with the cooperation of the department and the Department of Health, shall enforce this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-23-111(3): Any violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 24 - Utah Livestock Brand and Anti-Theft Act
************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Livestock Brand and Anti-Theft Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(1): "Brand" means an identifiable mark, including a tattoo or cutting and shaping of the ears or brisket area, applied to livestock that is intended to show ownership and the mark's location.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(2): "Carcass" means any part of the body of an animal, including entrails and edible meats.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(3): 4-39-102 "Domesticated elk" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(4): "Hide" means any skins or wool removed from livestock.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(5): "Livestock" means cattle, calves, horses, mules, or sheep.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(6)(a): "Livestock market" means a public market place consisting of pens or other enclosures where cattle, calves, horses, or mules are received on consignment and kept for subsequent sale, either through public auction or private sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(6)(b): "Livestock market" does not mean:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(6)(b)(i): a place used solely for liquidation of livestock by a farmer, dairyman, livestock breeder, or feeder who is going out of business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(6)(b)(ii): a place where an association of livestock breeders under the association's own management:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(6)(b)(ii)(A): offers registered livestock or breeding sires for sale;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(6)(b)(ii)(B): assumes the responsibility for the sale;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(6)(b)(ii)(C): guarantees title to the livestock or sires sold; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(6)(b)(ii)(D): arranges with the department for brand inspection of the animals sold.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(7): "Open range" means land upon which cattle, sheep, or other domestic animals are grazed or permitted to roam by custom, license, lease, or permit.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-102(8): "Slaughterhouse" means a building, plant, or establishment where animals are harvested, dressed, or processed and the animals' meat or meat products produced for human consumption.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-103 Department authorized to make and enforce rules.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department is authorized, subject to

Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104 Livestock Brand Board created -- Composition -- Terms -- Removal -- Quorum for transaction of business -- Compensation -- Duties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(1): There is created the Livestock Brand Board consisting of seven members appointed by the governor as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(1)(a): one feeder operator recommended by the Utah Cattlemen's Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(1)(b): three cattle ranchers, one from each of the state's brand districts;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(1)(c): one dairyman recommended by the Utah Dairymen's Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(1)(d): one livestock market operator recommended jointly by the Utah Cattlemen's Association and the Utah Dairymen's Association; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(1)(e): one horse breeder recommended by the Utah Horse Council.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(2): If a nominee is rejected by the governor, the recommending association shall submit another nominee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(3): (3)(b); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(3)(a): (3)(b) Except as required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(3)(b): (3)(a) Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(4)(a): A member may, at the discretion of the governor, be removed at the request of the association that recommended the appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(4)(b): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(5)(a): One member elected by the board shall serve as chair for a term of one year and be responsible for the call and conduct of meetings of the Livestock Brand Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(5)(b): Attendance of a simple majority of the members at a duly called meeting shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of official business.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(6): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(6)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(6)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(6)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-104(7): The Livestock Brand Board with the cooperation of the department shall direct the procedures and policies to be followed in administering and enforcing this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-105 Commission to appoint supervisor for brand inspection -- Appointment subject to approval -- Salary.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-105(1): The commissioner shall appoint a state supervisor for livestock brand inspection, subject to the approval of the Livestock Brand Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-105(2): The salary or compensation of the supervisor shall be fixed in accordance with standards adopted by the Division of Finance.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201 Central Brand Registry -- Division of state into brand districts -- Identical or confusingly similar brands -- Publication of registered brands.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(1): The department shall maintain a central Brand Registry that lists each brand recorded in this state. For each brand registered the list shall specify:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(1)(a): the name and address of the registrant;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(1)(b): a facsimile or diagram of the brand recorded;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(1)(c): the location of the brand upon the animal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(1)(d): the date the brand is filed in the central Brand Registry.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(2): The commissioner may divide the state into districts for the purpose of recording brands, but a brand that is identical or confusingly similar to a brand previously recorded in a district may not be recorded.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(3)(a): A brand that is identical or confusingly similar to a brand previously filed in the central Brand Registry may not be recorded.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(3)(b): If two or more brands appear identical or confusingly similar:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(3)(b)(i): the brand first recorded shall prevail over a later conflicting brand; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(3)(b)(ii): the later brand shall be cancelled and the recording fees refunded to the owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(4)(a): The commissioner shall publish from time to time a list of all brands recorded in the central Brand Registry and may issue supplements to that publication containing additional brands or changes in ownership of brands recorded after the last publication.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(4)(b): The commissioner may publish the publication described in Subsection (4)(a) in hard copy or electronic copy.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(4)(c): The publication published under Subsection (4)(a) shall contain a facsimile or diagram of all brands recorded together with the owner's name and address.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(4)(d): The commissioner shall, upon request, send one electronic copy of the publication published under Subsection (4)(a) and each supplement to each brand inspector, county clerk, county sheriff, livestock organization, or any other person considered appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(4)(e): The department shall make the publication described in Subsection (4)(a) available to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-201(4)(f): The department shall, upon request, make a hard copy of the publication described in Subsection (4)(a) available at the cost of printing and distribution per publication.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202 Recordation of brand.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(1)(a): Application for a recorded brand shall be made to the department upon forms prescribed and furnished by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(1)(b): The application shall contain the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(1)(b)(i): the name of each applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(1)(b)(ii): a single designated address where the department will send a notice of brand renewal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(1)(b)(iii): a description of the brand that is the subject of the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(1)(c): An application may not be approved without payment of the appropriate recording fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(1)(d): Upon receipt of a proper application, payment of the recording fee, and recordation of the brand in the central Brand Registry of the department, the commissioner shall issue the applicant a certified copy of recording that entitles the applicant to the exclusive use of the brand recorded.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(2): (1)(b)(ii); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(2)(a): A recorded brand filed with the central Brand Registry expires during the calendar year 1980, and during each fifth year thereafter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(2)(b): (1)(b)(ii); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(2)(b)(i): (1)(b)(ii) The department shall send notice in writing to the address designated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(2)(b)(ii): (2)(b) The notice required by this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(2)(b)(iii): The holder of a registered brand has an affirmative duty to inform the department of a change to the contact information provided on the initial application for a recorded brand.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(2)(c): Brand renewal is affected by filing an appropriate application with the department together with payment of the renewal fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-202(2)(d): A recorded brand, not timely renewed, shall lapse and be removed from the central Brand Registry.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-303 Livestock -- Verification of ownership through brand inspection -- Issuance of certificate of brand inspection -- Brand inspector may demand evidence of ownership -- Brand inspection of livestock seized by the federal government prohibited -- Exception.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-303(1): A brand inspector, as an agent of the department, shall verify livestock ownership by conducting a brand inspection during daylight hours.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-303(2): After conducting the brand inspection, the brand inspector, if satisfied that the livestock subject to inspection bears registered brands owned by the owner of the livestock, shall issue a brand inspection certificate to the owner or owner's agent.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-303(3): The brand inspector shall record the number, sex, breed, and brand on each animal inspected together with the owner's name.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-303(4): If any livestock subject to inspection bears a brand other than that of the owner, or if no brand appears on the livestock, or if the ownership of the livestock is disputed, the brand inspector may demand evidence of ownership before issuing a brand inspection certificate or may decline to issue a brand inspection certificate until the ownership dispute is resolved.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-303(5): A brand inspector may not issue a brand inspection certificate for privately owned livestock seized by the federal government unless the:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-303(5)(a): brand inspector receives consent from the livestock's owner;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-303(5)(b): owner is unknown; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-303(5)(c): brand inspector receives a copy of a court order authorizing the seizure.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-303(6): Breed papers alone do not constitute proof of ownership, but may be considered as a factor in determining ownership.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-304(2)(b): The department may authorize a custom exempt slaughter facility or a farm custom slaughter licensee to verify ownership of cattle, calves, horses, or mules before slaughter for the owner's use.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-304(2)(c): A custom exempt slaughter facility or farm custom slaughter licensee authorized by the department, shall verify ownership of cattle, calves, horses, or mules before slaughter for the owner's use.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-306 Movement across state line -- Brand inspection required -- Exception -- Request for brand inspection -- Time and place of inspection.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-306(1): Except as provided in Subsection (2), a person may not drive or transport any cattle, calves, horses, domesticated elk, or mules from any place within this state to a place outside this state until the animal has been brand inspected.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-306(2): Subsection (1) does not apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-306(2)(a): if the animals described in Subsection (1) customarily forage on an open range that transgresses the Utah state line and that of an adjoining state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-306(2)(b): to rodeo stock that have received a current yearly brand inspection; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-306(2)(c): to non-resident equine traveling to Utah for 30 or fewer days.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-306(3): The owner or person responsible for driving or transporting the animals shall request the department to inspect the brands of the animals to be moved.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-306(4): The department shall conduct the inspection at the time and place determined by the department.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-309 Livestock emergency.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-309(1): As used in this section, "livestock emergency" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-309(1)(a): the presence of a contagious, infectious, or transmissible disease risk to livestock; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-309(1)(b): a natural disaster which may affect livestock.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-309(2): During a livestock emergency, the department may require a person transporting livestock to present the livestock for brand inspection.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-401 Hides and pelts -- Bill of sale to accompany purchase -- Purchaser to maintain records -- Hides and records examination and inspection.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-401(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-401(1)(a): A person who buys a hide or pelt shall secure a bill of sale from the seller.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-401(1)(b): The bill of sale shall be executed in duplicate with one copy being retained by the seller and the other by the buyer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-401(1)(c): The bill of sale shall specify the number of hides or pelts sold and the brand borne by each hide or pelt.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-401(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-401(2)(a): A hide buyer within this state shall maintain a record specifying the name and address of the seller, date of purchase, and the brands or other identification found on the hides and pelts purchased.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-401(2)(b): The hides and records of any hide buyer are subject to examination and inspection by the department at reasonable times and places.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-402 Livestock markets -- Records to be maintained -- Retention of records -- Schedule of fees and charges to be posted.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-402(1): An owner or operator of a livestock market shall keep a record of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-402(1)(a): the date a consignment of livestock is received for sale together with the number of each type of livestock within the consignment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-402(1)(b): the name and address of the buyer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-402(1)(c): the date of sale and the number and species of livestock purchased by the buyer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-402(1)(d): the description and brand appearing on each animal at the time of sale to the buyer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-402(2): An owner or operator of a livestock market shall retain the records mandated by this section for a period of two years from the date on which the livestock market sold the livestock.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-402(3): A schedule of the fees and commission rates charged by the livestock market shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises of each market.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-402(4): A statement of the gross sales price, commission, and other fees charged for the sale of a consignment shall be available for inspection by the department, and a copy furnished the owner or consignor of the livestock.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-404(1)(a): Livestock may not be sold at any livestock market until after they have been brand inspected by the department.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-404(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-404(2)(a): Upon notice from the department that a question exists concerning the ownership of consigned livestock, the operator of the livestock market or meat packing plant shall withhold the proceeds from the sale of the livestock for 60 days to allow the consignor of the questioned livestock to establish ownership.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-404(2)(b): If the owner or consignor fails within 60 days to establish ownership to the satisfaction of the department, the proceeds of the sale shall be transmitted to the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-404(2)(c): Receipt of the proceeds by the department shall relieve the livestock market or meat packing plant from further responsibility for the proceeds.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-404(3)(b): If ownership is not satisfactorily established within one year, the department shall use the proceeds for animal identification.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-502 Unlawful acts specified -- Allegation concerning evidence of ownership relative to hides.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-502(1): It is unlawful for a person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-502(1)(a): permit cattle, calves, horses, mules, or sheep, except unweaned calves or colts, that are not branded in accordance with this chapter, to forage upon an open range in this state or outside an enclosure;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-502(1)(b): brand livestock with a brand that is not a matter of record on the central Brand Registry;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-502(1)(c): obliterate, change, or remove a recorded brand;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-502(1)(d): destroy, mutilate, or conceal a hide with intent to, or for the purpose of, removing evidence of ownership of the hide, or ownership of the animal from which the hide was removed;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-502(1)(e): hold or ship an estray or livestock owned by another without notifying the owner, a brand inspector, or law enforcement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-502(1)(f): offer for sale an estray or the livestock owned by another.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-502(2): In a prosecution for violation of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-502(2)(a): the state does not need to allege the ownership of the hide or the animal or carcass from which the hide was removed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-502(2)(b): the complaint or information is sufficient if the complaint or information alleges that ownership is unknown and that the hide is not the property of the defendant.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-503 Use of vehicle to transport stolen livestock prohibited -- Vehicle subject to seizure and sale -- Procedure for sale -- Defense.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-503(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-503(1)(a): No person shall use any vehicle for the transportation of stolen livestock or carcasses.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-503(1)(b): A vehicle used in transporting stolen livestock or carcasses is subject to seizure and public sale by the sheriff of the county where the vehicle is found, after written notice of the proposed sale is served upon the person in whose custody the vehicle is found.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-503(2): (1)(b) A person who receives the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-503(3): A stolen vehicle used for unlawful transportation is not subject to seizure and sale if the owner of the vehicle is not acting in concert with the thief.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-504 Enforcement -- Brand inspector's powers delineated.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-504(1): A brand inspector has the authority of a special function officer for the purpose of enforcing this chapter and the brand inspector may, if proper, stop a vehicle carrying livestock or livestock carcasses for the purpose of examining brands, certificates of brand inspection, and bills of lading or bills of sale relating to the livestock in transit.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-504(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-504(2)(a): A brand inspector may enter premises where livestock are kept or maintained for the purpose of examining brands.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-504(2)(b): If admittance is refused, the department may proceed immediately to obtain an ex parte warrant from the nearest court of competent jurisdiction to allow entry upon the premises for the purpose of examining brands or other evidence of ownership.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-505 Commissioner authorized to cooperate with local governments, other states, or federal government in enforcement.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The commissioner is empowered with authority, if necessary, to cooperate or enter into cooperative agreements with authorities in any city, town, or county within the state, or with federal authorities, or with authorities in another state for the purpose of securing assistance in the administration and enforcement of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-506 Penalties.
-----------------------------------------
A person who violates a provision of this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-506(1): is guilty of a class B misdemeanor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-24-506(2): may be subject to administrative fines, payable to the department, of up to $1,000 per violation.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 25 - Estrays
****************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Estrays."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
For the purpose of this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-102(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-102(1)(a): "Estray" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-102(1)(a)(i): an unbranded sheep, cow, horse, mule, or ass found running at large;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-102(1)(a)(ii): a branded sheep, cow, horse, mule, or ass found running at large whose owner cannot be found after reasonable search; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-102(1)(a)(iii): a swine found running at large whose owner cannot be found after reasonable search.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-102(1)(b): "Estray" does not mean any unweaned animal specified in this section that is running with its mother.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-102(2): "Feral swine" means any species, or hybrid species:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-102(2)(a): of the family Suidae, including the European boar, the Eurasian boar, the Russian boar, a feral hog, or a domestic pig;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-102(2)(b): that is not conspicuously identified by an ear tag or other form of visual identification; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-102(2)(c): that is roaming freely upon public land or private land.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-102(3): "Swine" means any domesticated species of the family Suidae that is conspicuously identified by an ear tag or other form of visible identification.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-103 County responsibility for estrays -- Contracts with other local governments authorized.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-103(1): Each county is responsible for the disposition of all estrays found within the county's boundaries.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-103(2): Each county in the discharge of the county's responsibility, however, may contract upon mutually agreeable terms with any city, town, or other county with an animal control office to perform any or all of the functions imposed by this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-104 Department authorized to make and enforce rules.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-203 Compensation for care of estrays -- Liability of county -- Notice required.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-203(1): A person who finds an estray and who, after giving notice is authorized by the county to maintain and care for the estray, is entitled to compensation from the owner, or from the county, as the case may be, for the reasonable costs of feeding and maintaining the estray; provided, that the county is liable for such cost only if the owner is not located after diligent search.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-203(2): No person who finds an estray, however, is entitled to reimbursement for feed and maintenance or for any other cost incurred on behalf of the estray before such time as notice of the estray is given to the county or to the appropriate animal control office.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-204 County legislative body authorized to adopt fence ordinance  -- Lawful fence to be specified by ordinance -- Dividing the county into divisions for different fencing regulations.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-204(1): A county legislative body may, by ordinance, declare and enforce a general policy within the county for the fencing of farms, subdivisions, or other private property to allow domestic animals to graze without trespassing on farms, subdivisions, or other private property.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-204(2): (1) If an ordinance is adopted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-204(2)(a): shall through ordinance declare and specify what constitutes a lawful fence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-204(2)(b): may divide the county into divisions and prescribe different fencing regulations for each division.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-205 Owner liable for trespass of animals -- Exception -- Intervention by county representative.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-205(1): The owner of any cattle, horse, ass, mule, sheep, goat, or swine that trespasses upon the premises of another person, except in cases where the premises are not enclosed by a lawful fence in a county or municipality that has adopted a fence ordinance, is liable in a civil action to the owner or occupant of the premises for any damage inflicted by the trespass.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-205(2): A county representative may intervene to remove the animal and the county is entitled to fair compensation for costs incurred.  If the animal is not claimed within 10 days after written notification is sent to the animal's owner, a county representative may sell the animal to cover costs incurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-205(3): (1); (2); 57-13b-102 Notwithstanding Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-205(3)(a): 57-13b-102 the animal enters the premises from an historic livestock trail, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-205(3)(b): the premises that was trespassed is not enclosed by an adequate fence at the time the trespass occurs.

A person is guilty of a third degree felony if the person releases a:Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-302(1): swine on public or private property for hunting purposes; or

Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-303 Feral swine detrimental to state's interests -- Seizure, capture, or destruction of feral swine.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-303(1): Feral swine are detrimental to the state's interests in agriculture and wildlife.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-303(2): Feral swine may be seized, captured, or destroyed at any time, in any place, and in any manner by:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-303(2)(a): the department and the department's authorized agents;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-303(2)(b): the Division of Wildlife Resources and the Division of Wildlife Resources' authorized agents; or

Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-303(3)(c)(ii): in any number; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-25-303(3)(c)(iii): with a firearm, bow and arrow, or crossbow.
