Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 26 - Enclosures and Fences
******************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-101 Title -- Failure to close entrance to enclosure -- Class C misdemeanor -- Damages.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-101(1): This chapter is known as "Enclosures and Fences."
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-101(2): A person who willfully throws down a fence or opens bars or gates into any enclosure other than the person's own enclosure or into any enclosure jointly owned or occupied by such person and others, and leaves the enclosure open:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-101(2)(a): is guilty of a class C misdemeanor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-101(2)(b): is liable in damage for any injury sustained by any person as a result of such an act.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-102 Adjoining landowners -- Partition fences -- Contribution.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-102(1): If two or more persons agree to a fence enclosure or to the construction of a partition fence, the cost of construction and maintenance of the fence shall be apportioned between each party to the agreement based upon the amount of land enclosed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-102(2): (1) A person who is a party to an agreement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-102(3): (3)(b)(i); (3)(b)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-102(3)(a): If a person has enclosed land with a fence and the owner of adjoining land desires to enclose land adjoining the fence so that the existing fence or any part of it will become a partition fence between such tracts of land, the owner of the adjoining land shall, before making the enclosure, pay to the owner of the existing fence one-half of the value of all that part of the fence that will become a partition fence.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-102(3)(b): (3)(b)(i); (3)(b)(ii) If a person whose land is enclosed, in whole or in part, by a partition fence  ceases to improve or cultivate that person's land or opens the enclosure, the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-102(3)(b)(i): shall give notice to the other owner of the partition fence and an opportunity to pay for the person's reasonable value of the fence;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-102(3)(b)(ii): (3)(b)(i) may not remove any part of the partition fence until the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-102(3)(b)(ii)(A): (3)(b)(i) 30 days after the day on which the person gave notice to the other owner, as described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-103 Definitions -- Qualified landowners' and qualified adjoining landowners' partition fences -- Contribution -- Civil action for damages.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-103(1): 57-18-2; Title 57, Chapter 18, Land Conservation Easement Act; 59-2-502; 57-18-2; Title 57, Chapter 18, Land Conservation Easement Act; 59-2-502 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-103(1)(a): 57-18-2; Title 57, Chapter 18, Land Conservation Easement Act; 59-2-502 "Qualified adjoining landowner" means a private landowner whose land adjoins the land of a qualified landowner and is used for grazing livestock or as habitat for big game wildlife and:

Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-103(3): If the qualified adjoining landowner refuses, the qualified landowner may maintain a civil action against the qualified adjoining landowner for one-half of the cost of that portion of the fence.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-103(4): The cost of the maintenance of the fence shall also be apportioned between each party based on the amount of land enclosed.  A party who fails to maintain that party's part of the fence is also liable in a civil action for any damage sustained by the other party as a result of the failure to maintain the fence.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104 Fencing for bison.
-------------------------------------------------
Perimeter fencing intended to hold bison shall meet the following minimum standards:Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(1): (1)(b)(i); (ii) fence sections and gates shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(1)(a): reach a height of at least eight feet above ground level; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(1)(b): (1)(b)(i); (ii) be constructed in a mesh pattern consisting of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(1)(b)(i): hi-tensile steel wire of at least 14-1/2 gauge;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(1)(b)(ii): a maximum mesh size of six inches by six inches; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(1)(b)(iii): (1)(b)(i); (ii) a material with the strength equivalent of the material described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(2): (2)(a)(i) fence posts shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(2)(a): (2)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(2)(a)(i): be constructed of treated wood at least four inches in diameter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(2)(a)(ii): (2)(a)(i) be constructed of a material with the strength equivalent of the material described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(2)(b): reach a height of at least six feet, two inches above ground level;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(2)(c): have at least two feet of length below ground level;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(2)(d): be installed at intervals of no more than 20 feet; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(2)(e): if located on a corner or connected to a gate, be braced with wood or the strength equivalent of wood; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(3): fence stays shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(3)(a): be constructed of treated wood or steel;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(3)(b): be installed at intervals of no more than 10 feet from any fence post; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-26-104(3)(c): reach a height of at least six feet, two inches above ground level.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 30 - Livestock Markets
**************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Livestock Markets."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
For the purpose of this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-102(1): "Consignor" or "shipper" means any person who consigns, ships, or delivers livestock to a livestock market for storage, handling, or sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-102(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-102(2)(a): "Livestock market" means a public market place consisting of pens or other enclosures where all classes of livestock or poultry are received on consignment and kept for subsequent sale, either through public auction or private sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-102(2)(b): "Livestock market" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-102(2)(b)(i): a place used solely for liquidation of livestock by a farmer, dairyman, livestock breeder, or feeder who is going out of such business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-102(2)(b)(ii): a place where an association of livestock breeders or an individual livestock breeder offers registered livestock or breeding sires for sale and assumes all responsibility for the sale, guarantees title to the livestock or sires sold, and arranges with the department for brand inspection of all animals sold.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-102(3): "Person" means an individual, partnership, corporation, or association.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-104 Department authorized to make and enforce rules.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department is authorized, subject to

Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105 License required -- Application -- Fee -- Expiration -- Renewal.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(1)(a): No person may operate a livestock market in this state without a license issued by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(1)(b): Application for a license shall be made to the department upon forms prescribed and furnished by the department, and the application shall specify:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(1)(b)(i): if the applicant is an individual, the name, address, and date of birth of the applicant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(1)(b)(ii): if the applicant is a partnership, corporation, or association, the name, address, and date of birth of each person who has a financial interest in the applicant and the amount of each person's interest;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(1)(b)(iii): a certified statement of the financial assets and liabilities of the applicant detailing:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(1)(b)(iii)(A): current assets;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(1)(b)(iii)(B): current liabilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(1)(b)(iii)(C): long-term assets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(1)(b)(iii)(D): long-term liabilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(1)(b)(iv): a legal description of the property where the market is proposed to be located, the property's street address, and a description of the facilities proposed to be used in connection with the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(1)(b)(v): a schedule of the charges or fees the applicant proposes to charge for each service rendered; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(1)(b)(vi): a detailed statement of the trade area proposed to be served by the applicant, the potential benefits which will be derived by the livestock industry, and the specific services the applicant intends to render at the livestock market.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(2): 4-2-103(2); 4-2-103(2)

Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-105(3): No livestock market original or renewal license may be issued until the applicant has provided the department with a certified copy of a surety bond filed with the United States Department of Agriculture as required by the Packers and Stockyards Act, 1921, 7 U.S.C.  Section 181 et seq.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-106 Hearing on license application -- Notice of hearing.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-106(1): Upon the filing of an application, the department may set a time for hearing on the application in the city or town nearest the proposed site of the livestock market and cause notice of the time and place of the hearing together with a copy of the application to be forwarded by mail, not less than 15 days before the hearing date, to the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-106(1)(a): each licensed livestock market operator within the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-106(1)(b): each livestock or other interested association or group of persons in the state that has filed written notice with the department requesting receipt of notice of such hearings.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-106(2): 63G-30-102 Notice of the hearing shall be published for 14 days before the scheduled hearing date, as a class A notice under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-107 Guidelines delineated for decision on application.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-107(1): The department, in determining whether to approve or deny the application, shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-107(1)(a): the applicant's proven or potential ability to comply with the Packers and Stockyards Act, 7 U.S.C. Sec. 221 through 229b;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-107(1)(b): the financial stability, business integrity, and fiduciary responsibility of the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-107(1)(c): the livestock marketing benefits which potentially will be derived from the establishment and operation of the public livestock market proposed;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-107(1)(d): the need for livestock market services in the trade area proposed;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-107(1)(e): the adequacy of the livestock market location and facilities proposed in the application, including facilities for health inspection and testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-107(1)(f): whether the operation of the proposed livestock market is likely to be permanent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-107(1)(g): the economic feasibility of the proposed livestock market based on competent evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-107(2): Any interested person may appear at the hearing on the application and give an opinion or present evidence either for or against granting the application.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-108 Transfer of livestock market license permitted -- Conditions.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-108(1): No livestock market license is transferable to another person without the prior approval of the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-108(2): A change in the membership of a partnership or association, or the sale or transfer of a 25% or greater interest in the stock ownership of a corporate livestock market shall be considered a transfer of the livestock market license and is subject to the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-108(3): Application to allow transfer of a livestock market license shall be made to the department on a form prescribed and furnished by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-108(4): 4-30-105; 4-30-107 The commissioner may grant a transfer of the license:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-108(4)(a): 4-30-105 if the proposed transferee meets all the requirements specified for an original license in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-108(4)(b): 4-30-107 based on the criteria specified in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-109 Financial responsibility.
--------------------------------------------------------
Each livestock market shall maintain a financial condition of total assets in excess of total liabilities, including total current assets in excess of total current liabilities.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110 Custodial accounts for trust funds.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(1)(a): Each payment that a livestock buyer makes to a livestock market selling on commission is a trust fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(1)(b): Funds deposited into custodial accounts are trust funds.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(2): Each livestock market engaged in selling livestock on a commission or agency basis shall establish and maintain a separate bank account designated as "custodial account for shippers' proceeds," or some similar identifying designation, to disclose that the depositor is acting as a fiduciary and that the funds in the account are trust funds.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(3)(a): The livestock market shall deposit into its custodial account before the close of the next business day after the livestock is sold:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(3)(a)(i): the proceeds that have been collected from the sale of the livestock; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(3)(a)(ii): an amount equal to the proceeds receivable from the sale of livestock that are due from:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(3)(a)(ii)(A): the livestock market;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(3)(a)(ii)(B): any owner, officer, or employee of the livestock market; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(3)(a)(ii)(C): any buyer to whom the livestock market has extended credit.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(3)(b): The livestock market shall thereafter deposit into the custodial account all proceeds collected until the account has been reimbursed in full and shall, before the close of the seventh day following the sale of livestock, deposit an amount equal to all the remaining proceeds receivable regardless of whether the proceeds have been collected by the livestock market.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(4): The custodial account shall be drawn on only:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(4)(a): for payment of the net proceeds to the consignor or shipper, or to any person that the livestock market knows is entitled to payment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(4)(b): to pay lawful charges against the consignment of livestock which the market agency shall, in its capacity as agent, be required to pay; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(4)(c): to obtain any sums due the livestock market as compensation for its services.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(5)(a): Each livestock market shall keep accounts and records that will disclose at all times the handling of funds in the custodial account.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(5)(b): Accounts and records shall at all times disclose the name of the consignors and the amount due and payable to each from funds in the custodial account.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-110(6): The custodial account shall be established and maintained in a bank whose deposits are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-111 Weighman license required -- Application -- Fee -- Bond -- Expiration -- Renewal.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-111(1): 4-2-103(2); 4-2-103(2)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-111(1)(a): No person may act as a weighman at a livestock market without a license from the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-111(1)(b): Application for a weighman's license shall be made to the department upon forms prescribed and furnished by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-111(1)(c): 4-2-103(2) Upon receipt of a proper application, payment of a license fee in an amount determined by the department pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-111(1)(d): 4-2-103(2) A weighman's license is annually renewable on or before December 31 of each year upon the payment of an annual license renewal fee in an amount determined by the department pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-111(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-111(2)(a): Each weighman's surety bond shall be written by a surety licensed under the laws of Utah and name the state, as obligee, for the use and benefit of persons who consign livestock to a livestock market.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-111(2)(b): The bond shall further be conditioned for the faithful and accurate weighing of livestock consigned to a livestock market and for the payment of court costs and reasonable attorney fees to the prevailing party incident to any suit brought upon the bond.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-112 Suspension or revocation of license -- Grounds.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department is authorized to suspend or revoke the license of any livestock market or livestock market weighman who:Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-112(1): violates any provision of this chapter or any rule made under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-30-112(2): engages in any fraudulent or deceitful activity.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 31 - Control of Animal Disease
**********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Control of Animal Disease."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-102 Dead domestic animals -- Duty of owner to bury or otherwise dispose-- Liability for costs.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-102(1): An owner or other person responsible for a domestic animal that dies shall bury or dispose of the animal within a reasonable period of time after the owner or other person responsible for the animal becomes aware that the animal is dead.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-102(2): The owner of a dead bovine, horse, mule, goat, sheep, bird, or swine may bury the dead animal on the owner's property.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-102(3): If the owner or other person responsible for the dead animal cannot be found, the county, city, or town within which the dead animal is found, shall, at the political subdivision's expense, bury the dead animal.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-102(4): A county, city, or town that incurs expense under this section is entitled to reimbursement from the owner of the dead animal.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-103 Dead animals -- Deposit on another's land prohibited.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person may not deposit a dead animal upon the land of another person without the landowner's consent.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-104 Penalty.
---------------------------------------
A person who violates Section

Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-105 Outbreak of contagious or infectious disease -- Assistance of federal authorities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If there is an outbreak of contagious or infectious disease among domestic animals in this state that imperils livestock, the commissioner may request the assistance of the United States Department of Agriculture, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, in preventing the spread of the disease to other states.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-106 Epidemic of contagious or infectious disease -- Condemnation or destruction of infected or exposed livestock -- Destruction of other property.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-106(1): If there is an outbreak of contagious or infectious disease of epidemic proportion among domestic animals in this state that imperils livestock, the commissioner, with approval of the governor, may condemn, destroy, or dispose of any infected livestock or any livestock exposed to the disease or considered by the commissioner capable of transmitting the disease to other domestic animals.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-106(2): The commissioner may, with gubernatorial approval, condemn and destroy any barns, sheds, corrals, pens, or other property necessary to prevent the spread of contagion or infection.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-107 Value determination before destruction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-107(1): 4-31-106 Before any livestock or property that is not otherwise indemnified is destroyed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-107(2): The commissioner shall make the value determination described in Subsection (1) based on available data from the United States Department of Agriculture or other reliable government sources.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-107(3): 63G-9-201 After review, the commissioner shall forward the determined value and an appraisal described in Subsection (4), if any, to the board of examiners described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-107(4): An owner of livestock or other property subject to destruction may pay for an independent appraisal of the value of the livestock or other property, which appraisal the board of examiners shall consider in the board of examiners' recommendation described in Subsection (3).


Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-108 Euthanasia for postmortem examination.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
The commissioner may order the euthanasia and postmortem examination of a diseased domestic animal if the exact nature of the animal's disease is not readily determined through other means.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-109 Department authorized to make and enforce rules concerning brucellosis, trichomoniasis, tuberculosis, and other infectious diseases in livestock.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-109.1 Trichomoniasis fines.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-109.1(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 4-31-109 A person who knowingly sells a bull infected with trichomoniasis, other than to slaughter, without declaring the disease status of the animal shall be subject to citation and fines as prescribed by the department or may be called to appear before an administrative proceeding by the department, as established by rule in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-109.1(2): After May 15 of each calendar year, an owner of a bull that has not been tested for trichomoniasis may be fined $1,000 per bull.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-109.1(3): An owner of a bull that has not been tested for trichomoniasis and that has been exposed to female cattle may be fined $1,000 per animal regardless of the time of year.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-111 Imported animals -- Health certificate.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Except as provided by rule made by the department, a person may not import an animal into this state unless the animal is accompanied by a health certificate that:Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-111(1): meets the requirements of department rules; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-111(2): is issued by a federally accredited veterinarian.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-113 Restrictions on movement of infected or exposed animals.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-113(1): A person who owns or has possession of an animal and knows that the animal is infected with, or has been exposed to, any contagious or infectious disease may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-113(1)(a): permit the animal to run at large or come in contact with an animal that can be infected; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-113(1)(b): sell, ship, trade, or give away the infected animal without disclosing that the animal is diseased or has been exposed to disease.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-113(2): (1) A person who violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-113(3): The provisions of this section do not apply to protected wildlife that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-113(3)(a): living in nature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-113(3)(b): under the jurisdiction of the Division of Wildlife Resources.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-114 Report of vesicular disease.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-114(1): A person who identifies symptoms of vesicular disease in livestock shall immediately report it to the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-114(2): The department may report a veterinarian licensed in this state to the veterinarian's licensing authority for the veterinarian's failure to report a diagnosed case of vesicular disease to the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-114(3): Failure by an owner of livestock to report symptoms of vesicular disease among the owner's livestock constitutes forfeiture of the right to claim an indemnity for an animal euthanized on account of the disease.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115 Contagious or infectious disease, or any epidemic or poisoning -- Duties of department.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(1)(a): The department shall investigate and may quarantine a reported case of contagious or infectious disease, or any epidemic or poisoning, affecting a domestic animal or an animal that the department believes may jeopardize the health of animals within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(1)(b): The department shall make a prompt and thorough examination of the circumstances surrounding the disease, epidemic, or poisoning and may order quarantine, care, or any necessary remedies.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(1)(c): The department may also order immunization or testing and sanitary measures to prevent the spread of disease.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(1)(d): An investigation involving fish or wildlife shall be conducted under a cooperative agreement with the Division of Wildlife Resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(2)(a): If the owner or person in possession of an animal with a contagious or infectious disease, epidemic, or poisoning, after written notice from the department, fails to take the action ordered, the commissioner may seize and hold the animal and take action necessary to prevent the spread of disease, including immunization, testing, or treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(2)(b): An animal seized for testing or treatment under this section may be sold by the commissioner at public sale to reimburse the department for the costs incurred in the seizure, testing, treatment, maintenance, and sale of the animal unless the owner, before the sale, tenders payment for the costs incurred by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(2)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(2)(c)(i): The commissioner may not sell a seized animal until the owner or person in possession of the animal is served with a notice specifying the itemized costs incurred by the department, the time, place, and purpose of sale, and the number of animals to be sold.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(2)(c)(ii): The notice shall be served at least three days in advance of sale in the manner:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(2)(c)(ii)(A): prescribed for personal service in Rule 4(d)(1), Utah Rules of Civil Procedure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(2)(c)(ii)(B): if the owner cannot be found after due diligence, prescribed for service by publication in Rule 4(d)(4), Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(3)(a): Any amount realized from the sale of the animal over the total charges shall be paid to the owner of the animal if the owner is known or can by reasonable diligence be found.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(3)(b): If the owner is unknown and cannot be found by reasonable diligence, as described in Subsection (3)(a),  the excess shall remain in the General Fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-115(3)(c): If the total cost incurred is greater than the amount realized, the owner shall pay the difference.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-116 Quarantine -- Peace officers to assist in maintenance of quarantine.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-116(1): The commissioner may quarantine any infected domestic animal or area within the state to prevent the spread of infectious or contagious disease.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-116(2): A sheriff or other peace officer in the state shall, upon request of the commissioner, assist the department in maintaining a quarantine and arrest a person who violates the quarantine.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-116(3): The department shall pay all costs and fees incurred by any law enforcement authority in assisting the department.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-31-118(2): (1) enforce the rules described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 32 - Utah Meat and Poultry Products Inspection and Licensing Act
********************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Meat and Poultry Products Inspection and Licensing Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-102 Purpose declaration.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-102(1): It is the purpose of this chapter to provide a meat and poultry inspection program in the state at least equal to the programs imposed under the:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-102(1)(a): Federal Meat Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 601 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-102(1)(b): Poultry Products Inspection Act,   21 U.S.C. Sec. 451 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-102(1)(c): Humane Slaughter Act, 7 U.S.C. Sec. 1901 et seq.; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-102(1)(d): the Egg Product Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. 1031 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-102(2): (1) The commissioner shall administer and enforce this chapter to accomplish the purpose described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-103(1)(b): the Federal Meat Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 601 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-103(1)(c): the Poultry Products Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 451 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-103(1)(d): the Humane Slaughter Act, 7 U.S.C. Sec. 1901 et seq.; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-103(1)(e): the Egg Product Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. 1031 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-103(2): (1) Changes to the federal laws, regulations, and standards referenced in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-104 Emergency rules.
-----------------------------------------------
The department may make emergency rules concerning the meat and poultry inspection program only in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(1): (1)(c); (d) "Adulterated" means any meat or poultry product that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(1)(a): bears or contains any poisonous or deleterious substance that may render it injurious to health, but, if the substance is not an added substance, the meat or poultry product is not considered adulterated under this subsection if the quantity of the substance in or on the meat or poultry product does not ordinarily render it injurious to health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(1)(b): bears or contains, by reason of the administration of any substance to the animal or otherwise, any added poisonous or added deleterious substance that in the judgment of the commissioner makes the meat or poultry product unfit for human food;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(1)(c): contains, in whole or in part, a raw agricultural commodity and that commodity bears or contains a pesticide chemical that is unsafe within the meaning of 21 U.S.C. Sec. 346a;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(1)(d): bears or contains any food additive that is unsafe within the meaning of 21 U.S.C. Sec. 348;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(1)(e): (1)(c); (d) bears or contains any color additive that is unsafe within the meaning of 21 U.S.C. Sec. 379e, provided that a meat or poultry product that is not otherwise considered adulterated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(1)(f): consists, in whole or in part, of any filthy, putrid, or decomposed substance or is for any other reason unsound, unhealthful, unwholesome, or otherwise unfit for human food;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(1)(g): has been prepared, packaged, or held under unsanitary conditions if the meat or poultry product may have become contaminated with filth, or if it may have been rendered injurious to health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(1)(h): is in whole or in part the product of an animal that died other than by slaughter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(1)(i): is contained in a container that is composed, in whole or in part, of any poisonous or deleterious substance that may render the meat or poultry product injurious to health;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(1)(j): has been intentionally subjected to radiation, unless the use of the radiation conforms with a regulation or exemption in effect pursuant to 21 U.S.C. Sec. 348;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(1)(k): has a valuable constituent in whole or in part omitted, abstracted, or substituted; or if damage or inferiority is concealed in any manner; or if any substance has been added, mixed, or packed with the meat or poultry product to increase its bulk or weight, reduce its quality or strength, or make it appear better or of greater value; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(1)(l): is margarine containing animal fat and any of the raw material used in the margarine consists in whole or in part of any filthy, putrid, or decomposed substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(2): "Amenable species" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(2)(a): livestock, including cattle, sheep, goats, swine, or equine; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(2)(b): poultry, including a domesticated chicken, turkey, duck, goose, guinea, ratite, or squab.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(3): "Animal" means a domesticated or captive mammalian or avian species.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(4): "Animal food manufacturer" means any person engaged in the business of preparing animal food derived from animal carcasses or parts or products of the carcasses.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(5): "Antemortem inspection" means an inspection of a live animal immediately before slaughter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(6): "Broker" means any person engaged in the business of buying and selling meat or poultry products other than for the person's own account.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(7): "Capable of use as human food" means any animal carcass, or part or product of a carcass, unless it is denatured or otherwise identified as required by rules of the department to deter the carcass or product's use as human food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(8): "Commissioner" includes a person authorized by the commissioner to carry out the provisions of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(9): "Container" or "package" means any box, can, tin, cloth, plastic, or other receptacle, wrapper, or cover.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(10): "Custom exempt processing" means processing meat, wild game, amenable species, or nonamenable species as a service for the person who owns the meat, wild game, amenable species, or nonamenable species, if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(10)(a): uses the meat, meat food products, slaughtered amenable species, wild game, or slaughtered nonamenable species for the person's own consumption, including consumption by immediate family members and nonpaying guests; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(10)(b): offers the slaughtered nonamenable species for wholesale or retail sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(11)(a): "Custom exempt slaughter" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(11)(a)(i): slaughtering an amenable species or nonamenable species as a service for the person who owns the amenable species or nonamenable species and uses the slaughtered amenable species or slaughtered nonamenable species for the person's own consumption, including consumption by immediate family members and nonpaying guests; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(11)(a)(ii): the slaughter of a nonamenable species intended for wholesale or retail sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(11)(b): "Custom exempt slaughter" includes farm custom slaughter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(12): "Diseased animal":
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(12)(a): means an animal that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(12)(a)(i): is diagnosed with a disease not known to be cured; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(12)(a)(ii): has exhibited signs or symptoms of a disease that is not known to be cured; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(12)(b): does not include an otherwise healthy animal that suffers only from injuries such as fractures, cuts, or bruises.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(13): "Farm custom mobile unit" means a portable slaughter vehicle or trailer that is used by a farm custom slaughter licensee to slaughter animals.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(14): "Farm custom slaughter" means custom exempt slaughtering of an animal, amenable species, or nonamenable species  for an owner without official inspection.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(15): "Farm custom slaughter license" means a license issued by the department to allow farm custom slaughter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(16): "Farm custom slaughter NOT FOR SALE tag" means a tag issued by the department to the owner of the facility before the animal is slaughtered that specifies the animal's identification and certifies its ownership.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(17): "Federal acts" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(17)(a): the Federal Meat Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 601 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(17)(b): the Federal Poultry Products Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 451 et seq.; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(17)(c): the Humane Slaughter Act, 7 U.S.C. 1901 et seq..
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(18): "Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act" means the act so entitled, approved June 25, 1938 (52 Stat. 1040) (21 U.S.C. 301 et seq.), and any amendments to the act.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(19): "Immediate container" means any consumer package, or any other container, in which meat or poultry products not consumer packaged are packed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(20): "Inspector" means a department employee who is trained in:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(20)(a): humane handling;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(20)(b): antemortem and postmortem inspection;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(20)(c): processing inspection; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(20)(d): regulatory requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(21): "Label" means a display of printed or graphic matter upon any meat or poultry product or the immediate container, not including package liners, of any such product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(22): "Labeling" means all labels and other printed or graphic matter:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(22)(a): upon any meat or poultry product or any of its containers or wrappers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(22)(b): accompanying a meat or poultry product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(23): "Licensee" means a person who holds a valid farm custom slaughter license.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(24): "Meat" means the edible muscle, and other edible parts, of an animal, including edible:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(24)(a): skeletal muscle;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(24)(b): organs;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(24)(c): muscle found in the tongue, diaphragm, heart, or esophagus; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(24)(d): fat, bone, skin, sinew, nerve, or blood vessel that normally accompanies meat and is not ordinarily removed in processing.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(25): "Meat establishment" means a plant or fixed premises used to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(25)(a): slaughter animals for human consumption; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(25)(b): process meat or poultry products for human consumption.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(26): "Meat product" means any product capable of use as human food that is made wholly or in part from any meat or other part of the carcass of any non-avian animal.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27): (27)(e); (27)(e)(ii); 4-32-109; (27)(g); (27)(i)(ii) "Misbranded" means any meat or poultry product that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(a): bears a label that is false or misleading in any particular;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(b): is offered for sale under the name of another food;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(c): is an imitation of another food, unless the label bears, in type of uniform size and prominence, the word "imitation" followed by the name of the food imitated;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(d): if it has a container, the container is made, formed, or filled as to be misleading;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(e): (27)(e); (27)(e)(ii) does not bear a label showing:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(e)(i): the name and place of business of the manufacturer, packer, or distributor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(e)(ii): (27)(e); (27)(e)(ii) an accurate statement of the quantity of the product in terms of weight, measure, or numerical count, provided that under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(f): does not bear any word, statement, or other information required by or under authority of this chapter to appear on the label or other labeling that is not prominently placed with such conspicuousness, as compared with other words, statements, designs, or devices, in the labeling, and in such terms as to render it likely to be read and understood by the ordinary individual under customary conditions of purchase and use;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(g): 4-32-109 is a food for which a definition and standard of identity or composition has been prescribed by rules of the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(h): is a food for which a standard of fill has been prescribed by rule of the department for the container and the actual fill of the container falls below that prescribed unless the food's label bears, in a manner and form as the rule specifies, a statement that the food falls below the standard;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(i): (27)(g); (27)(i)(ii) is a food for which no standard or definition of identity has been prescribed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(i)(i): the common or usual name of the food, if there be any; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(i)(ii): (27)(i)(ii) if the food is fabricated from two or more ingredients, the common or usual name of each such ingredient, except that spices, flavorings, and colorings may, when authorized by the department, be designated as spices, flavorings, and colorings without naming each, provided that to the extent that compliance with the requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(j): is a food that purports to be or is represented to be for special dietary uses, unless the label bears information concerning the food's vitamin, mineral, and other dietary properties as the department, after consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture of the United States, prescribes by rules as necessary to inform purchasers as to the food's value for special dietary uses;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(k): bears or contains any artificial flavoring, artificial coloring, or chemical preservative, unless the food bears labeling stating that fact, provided that to the extent that compliance with the requirements of this subsection are impracticable, exemptions shall be prescribed by rules of the department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(27)(l): does not bear directly thereon and on the food's containers, as the department may prescribe by rule, the official inspection legend and establishment number of the official establishment where the product was prepared, and, unrestricted by any of the foregoing, other information as the department may require by rule to assure that the meat or poultry product will not have false or misleading labeling and that the public will be informed of the manner of handling required to maintain the meat or poultry product in a wholesome condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(28): 4-32a-201
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(28)(a): "Nonamenable species" means a member of a species that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(28)(a)(i): not included in the definition of amenable species; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(28)(a)(ii): domestically raised.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(28)(b): 4-32a-201 "Nonamenable species" includes domesticated game, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(29): "Official certificate" means any certificate prescribed by rules of the department for issuance by an inspector or other person performing official functions under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(30): "Official device" means a device prescribed or authorized by the commissioner for use in applying an official mark.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(31): "Official establishment" means an establishment at which inspection of the slaughter of animals or the preparation of meat or poultry products is maintained under the authority of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(32): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(32)(a): "Official inspection" means mandatory inspection, carried out under grant of inspection issued by the department, of a slaughtered animal or preparation for slaughtering an animal, if the animal is intended for human consumption.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(32)(b): "Official inspection" does not apply to custom exempt processing or farm custom slaughter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(33): "Official inspection legend" means a symbol prescribed by rules of the department showing that a meat or poultry product was inspected and passed in accordance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(34): "Official mark" means the official legend or other symbol prescribed by rules of the department to identify the status of an animal carcass or meat or poultry product under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(35): "Pesticide chemical," "food additive," "color additive," and "raw agricultural commodity," have the same meanings for purposes of this chapter as ascribed to them in the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 301 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(36): "Postmortem inspection" means an inspection of a slaughtered food animal's carcass after slaughter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(37): "Poultry" means any domesticated bird, whether living or dead.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(38): "Poultry product" means any product capable of use as human food that is made wholly or in part from any poultry carcass, excepting products that contain poultry ingredients in relatively small proportion or that historically have not been considered by consumers as products of the poultry food industry, and that are exempted from definition as a poultry product by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(39): "Prepared" means slaughtered, canned, salted, stuffed, rendered, boned, cut up, or otherwise manufactured or processed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(40): "Process" means to cut, grind, manufacture, compound, smoke, intermix, or prepare meat or poultry products.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(41): "Renderer" means any person engaged in the business of rendering animal carcasses, or parts or products of animal carcasses, except rendering conducted under inspection or exemption under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(42): "Slaughter" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(42)(a): the killing of an animal, amenable species, or nonamenable species  in a humane manner including skinning or dressing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(42)(b): the process of performing any of the specified acts in preparing an animal, amenable species, or nonamenable species  for human consumption.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(43): "Wild game" means a species, the products of which are food, that is not classified as an amenable species or nonamenable species, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(43)(a): a deer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(43)(b): an elk;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(43)(c): an antelope;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(43)(d): a moose;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(43)(e): a bison;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(43)(f): a rabbit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-105(43)(g): a bird.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106 Meat establishment license -- Slaughtering livestock except in licensed meat establishment prohibited -- Exceptions -- Violation a misdemeanor.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(1): (2); (3); (4) A person may not, except in a licensed meat establishment, slaughter animals for human consumption or assist other persons in the slaughter or processing of animals except as otherwise provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(2): A person who raises an animal or an employee of that person may slaughter an animal without a farm custom slaughter license if:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(2)(a): slaughtering or processing animals is not prohibited by local ordinance;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(2)(b): any hide, viscera, blood, or other tissue is disposed of by removal to a rendering facility or landfill or by burial, as allowed by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(2)(c): the meat or poultry product derived from the slaughtered animal is consumed exclusively by the person or the person's immediate family, regular employees of the person, or nonpaying guests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(2)(d): the meat or poultry product is marked "Not For Sale."
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(3): Farm custom slaughter may be performed by a person who holds a valid farm custom slaughter license.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(4): A retail establishment that processes meat or poultry products primarily for sale to individual consumers at the retail establishment is exempt from provisions requiring licensing of a meat establishment if:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(4)(a): the retail establishment is not engaged in slaughter operations;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(4)(b): the retail establishment sells the processed meat and poultry products only to individual consumers at the retail establishment or to restaurants or institutions for use in meals served at those restaurants or institutions;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(4)(c): the retail establishment's sales of processed meat and poultry products to restaurants or institutions do not exceed the federal adjusted dollar limitation, or 25% by dollar volume of all meat sales from the retail establishment, whichever is less;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(4)(d): the retail establishment receives meat only from a meat establishment licensed under this chapter or inspected by the United States Department of Agriculture under 21 U.S.C. Secs. 451 to 695;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(4)(e): the operator of the retail establishment does not sell to any person other than an individual consumer any meat or poultry product that is cured, smoked, seasoned, canned, or cooked at the retail establishment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(4)(f): the retail establishment does not sell any meat or poultry product that is cured, smoked, seasoned, canned, or cooked at the retail establishment at a location other than the retail establishment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(4)(g): the operator of the retail establishment does not sell to any person other than an individual consumer any meat product made by combining meat from different animal species at the retail establishment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(5): (6) Any person who violates this section, except as otherwise provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-106(6): Any person who offers for sale or sells any uninspected meat or poultry product is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-108 Duties of person who holds a farm custom slaughter license.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Each person who holds a farm custom slaughter license shall:Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-108(1): keep accurate records of each animal or a nonamenable species slaughtered, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-108(1)(a): the name, address, and telephone number of each person for whom the animal or a nonamenable species is slaughtered;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-108(1)(b): a full description of each animal or a nonamenable species slaughtered including age, brands, marks, or other identifying marks, proof of ownership, and the destination of the carcass for processing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-108(1)(c): the date of slaughter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-108(2): require that each animal presented for slaughter bear a farm custom slaughter NOT FOR SALE tag;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-108(3): render the animal to be slaughtered insensible to pain by captive bolt, gunshot, electric shock, or other humane means before it is shackled, hoisted, thrown, cast, or cut; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-108(4): stamp and tag the carcass of any slaughtered animal "Not For Sale."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110 Discretionary functions, powers, and duties of commissioner prescribed.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The commissioner may:Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(1): 4-32-109(3) remove inspectors from any official establishment that fails to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(1)(a): 4-32-109(3) destroy condemned products pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(1)(b): comply with any other of this chapter's requirements;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(2): refuse to provide inspection for any official establishment for any cause specified in Section 401 of the Federal Meat Inspection Act or Section 18 of the federal Poultry Products Inspection Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(3): withhold the use of labels and containers if the labeling is false or misleading or the containers are misleading in size or form;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(4): prescribe the type size and style to be used for labeling:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(4)(a): information;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(4)(b): definitions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(4)(c): standards of identity, composition, or container fill;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(5): prescribe conditions for the storage and handling of meat and poultry products by any person who sells, freezes, stores, or transports these products to prevent them from becoming adulterated or misbranded;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(6): require that equines be slaughtered and prepared in official establishments separate from those where other animals are slaughtered or their products are prepared;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(7): require that the following people register the name and address of each place of business and all trade names:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(7)(a): broker;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(7)(b): renderer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(7)(c): animal food manufacturer;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(7)(d): wholesaler;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(7)(e): public warehouseman of meat or poultry products; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(7)(f): anyone engaged in the business of buying, selling, or transporting any:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(7)(f)(i): dead, dying, disabled, or diseased animals; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(7)(f)(ii): parts of animal carcasses that died other than by slaughter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(8): make inspections of official establishments at night, as well as during the day, if animals or meat and poultry products are slaughtered and prepared for commercial purposes in those establishments at night;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(9): divide the state into inspection districts and designate killing days and partial killing days for each official establishment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(10): cooperate with the Secretary of Agriculture of the United States in the administration of this chapter and accept federal assistance and use funds appropriated for the administration of this chapter to pay the state's proportionate share of the cooperative program;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(11): recommend the names of officials and employees of the department to the Secretary of Agriculture of the United States for appointment to the advisory committees provided for in the federal acts;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(12): serve as the representative of the governor for consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture under paragraph (c) of Section 301 of the Federal Meat Inspection Act and Section 5(c) of the federal Poultry Products Inspection Act, unless the governor selects another representative; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(13): exempt from inspection:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(13)(a): the slaughter and processing of an animal by any person who raises an animal for the person's own use, members of the person's household, employees, or nonpaying guests;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(13)(b): custom exempt slaughter and processing operations;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(13)(c): farm custom slaughter performed by a licensee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(13)(d): any other operation, if the exemption:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(13)(d)(i): furthers the purposes of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-110(13)(d)(ii): conforms to federal acts.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-113 Preparation and slaughter of livestock, poultry, or livestock and poultry products -- Adulterated or misbranded products -- Violation of rule or order.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-113(1): An animal or meat or poultry product that may be used for human consumption shall not be:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-113(1)(a): slaughtered or prepared unless it is done in compliance with this chapter's requirements;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-113(1)(b): sold, transported, offered for sale or transportation, or received for transportation, if it is adulterated or misbranded, unless it has been inspected and approved; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-113(1)(c): subjected to any act while being transported or held for sale after transportation resulting in one of the products becoming adulterated or being misbranded.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-113(2): 4-32-109(4); (7); 4-32-110(3); (5); (7) A person may not violate any rule or order of the commissioner under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114 Unauthorized use or possession of official devices, labels, marks, or certificates -- False statements, misrepresentations, and trade secrets.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(1): A person may not cast, print, lithograph, or make any device or label containing or bearing any official mark or simulation of a mark, or any form or simulation of an official certificate, unless authorized by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2): A person may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(a): forge any official device, mark, or certificate;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(b): use any official device, mark, or certificate without the authorization of the commissioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(c): alter, detach, deface, or destroy any official device, mark, or certificate;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(d): fail to use, detach, deface, or destroy any official device, mark, or certificate as required by this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(e): knowingly possess any of the following, if it bears any unauthorized, counterfeit, simulated, forged, or altered official mark:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(e)(i): an official device;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(e)(ii): a counterfeit, simulated, forged, or altered official certificate;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(e)(iii): a device;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(e)(iv): a label;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(e)(v): a carcass of any animal, including poultry; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(e)(vi): a part or product of any animal, including poultry;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(f): knowingly make any false statement in any shipper's certificate, or nonofficial or official certificate;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(g): knowingly represent that any meat or poultry product has been inspected and approved, or exempted, under this chapter when, in fact, it has not; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(h): use to the person's advantage or reveal any information acquired under the authority of this chapter relating to any matter entitled to protection as a trade secret unless the information is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(h)(i): revealed to an authorized government representative; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-114(2)(h)(ii): ordered by a court in a judicial proceeding.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-115 Meat or poultry products to be marked or labeled -- Meat or poultry products not intended for human food -- Dead, dying, disabled, or diseased animals.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-115(1): A person may not sell, transport, offer for sale or transportation, or receive for transportation, any animal carcasses or parts of such carcasses, or the meat or meat products, unless they are plainly and conspicuously marked or labeled or otherwise identified as required by rules adopted by the department to show the kinds of animals from which they were derived.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-115(2): A person may not buy, sell, transport, or offer for sale or transportation, or receive for transportation any meat or poultry products that are not intended for human food unless they are denatured or otherwise identified as required by the rules of the department or are naturally inedible by humans.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-115(3): A person engaged in the business of buying, selling, or transporting dead, dying, disabled, or diseased animals, or any parts of the carcasses of any animals that died otherwise than by slaughter, may not buy, sell, transport, offer for sale or transportation, or receive for transportation the animals or parts of carcasses unless the transaction or transportation is made in accordance with rules adopted by the department to assure that the animals or parts of carcasses will be prevented from being used for human food.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-116 Attempt to bribe state officer or employee -- Acceptance of bribe -- Interference with official duties -- Penalties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-116(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-116(1)(a): A person who gives, pays, or offers, directly or indirectly, any money or other thing of value, to any officer or employee of this state who is authorized to perform any duties under this chapter, with the intent to influence the officer or employee in the discharge of the officer's or employee's duty, is guilty of a felony of the third degree, and upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $5,000 or imprisonment of not more than five years, or both.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-116(1)(b): An officer or employee of this state authorized to perform duties under this chapter who accepts money, a gift, or other thing of value from any person given with intent to influence the officer's or employee's official action, is guilty of a felony of the third degree and shall, upon conviction, be discharged from office, and fined in an amount of not more than $5,000, or imprisoned for not more than five years, or both.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-116(2): (2); 76-1-101.5; 76-5-202
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-116(2)(a): A person who assaults, obstructs, impedes, intimidates, or interferes with any person engaged in the performance of official duties under this chapter, with or without a dangerous or deadly weapon, is guilty of a felony of the third degree and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not more than $5,000, or by imprisonment of not more than five years, or both.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-116(2)(b): (2); 76-1-101.5 A person who, in the commission of any violation of Subsection
