Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-117 Inspection of products placed in containers -- Supervision of inspector -- Access to establishment.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-117(1): An inspection of products placed in any container at any official establishment may not be considered to be complete until the products are sealed or enclosed under the supervision of an inspector.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-117(2): For purposes of any inspection of products required by this chapter, inspectors authorized by the department shall have access at all times to every part of every establishment required to have inspection whether the establishment is operated or not.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-118 Detention of animals or meat or poultry products -- Removal of official marks.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-118(1): 4-32-119 Whenever any meat or poultry product or any product exempted from the definition of a meat or poultry product, or any dead, dying, disabled, or diseased animal, is found by any authorized representative of the commissioner, and there is reason to believe that it is adulterated or misbranded and is capable of use as human food, or that it has not been inspected and passed, or that it has been or is intended to be distributed in violation of this chapter, it may be detained by the representative pending action under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-118(2): (1); (1) All official marks may be required by the representative described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-119 Quarantine authorized -- Conditions giving rise to quarantine.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-119(1): A meat or poultry product, or a dead, dying, disabled, or diseased animal that is being transported or is held for sale in this state, shall be seized and quarantined if it:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-119(1)(a): is or has been prepared, sold, transported, or otherwise distributed or offered or received for distribution in violation of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-119(1)(b): is capable of use as human food and is adulterated or misbranded; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-119(1)(c): in any other way violates this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-119(2): Quarantined animals or products shall be condemned and destroyed, except that the owner of the quarantined animals or products may request a hearing within five days, and the commissioner shall, within five days after the request, conduct a hearing to decide whether the quarantined animals or products shall be condemned.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-119(3): (2) The commissioner's decision under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-119(4): This section does not limit the authority for condemnation or seizure conferred by other provisions of this chapter, or other laws.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-120 Rules for the construction and operation of meat establishments authorized.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-120(1): For the purposes of administering this chapter and qualifying meat establishments for licenses, the department may adopt sanitary inspection rules and regulations, including those pertaining to the construction, equipment, and facilities of meat establishments.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-120(2): The rules shall conform with the regulations made under the federal acts.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-121 Suspension or revocation -- Grounds.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
The department may upon its own motion, and shall upon the verified complaint in writing of any person, investigate or cause to be investigated the operation of any meat establishment, and may suspend or revoke the license of the meat establishment upon any of the following grounds:Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-121(1): the license was obtained by any false or misleading statement;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-121(2): for slaughtering any animal without an antemortem and a postmortem inspection, or for processing any meat or poultry or products of meat or poultry that have not been inspected and passed, or exempted, and so identified;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-121(3): the advertising or publicizing of any false or misleading statements that pertain to the slaughtering, processing, or distribution of animals or meat or poultry products;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-121(4): the failure to maintain refrigeration or sanitation, or dispose of waste as required by rules of the department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-121(5): the failure to comply with rules of the department pertaining to the disposal of carcasses or parts of carcasses that have been determined to be unfit for human consumption.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-122 Denial of application for farm custom slaughter license -- Venue for judicial review.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-122(1): An applicant whose application for a license to operate a meat establishment or to obtain a farm custom slaughter license is denied may file a request for agency action with the department, requesting a hearing on the issue of denial.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-122(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-122(2)(a): A person who is aggrieved by an order issued under this section may obtain judicial review.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-122(2)(b): Venue for judicial review of an informal adjudicative proceeding is in the district court in the county in which the alleged unlawful activity occurred or, in the case of an order denying a license application, in the county where the applicant resides.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-122(3): The attorney general's office shall represent the department in an original action or appeal under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32-123 Animals slaughtered or the meat and poultry products not intended for human use -- No inspection -- Products to be denatured or otherwise identified.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Inspection may not be provided under this chapter at any establishment for the slaughter of animals or the preparation of any meat or poultry products that are not intended for use as human food, but the products shall be denatured or otherwise identified as prescribed by rules of the department before the meat and poultry products are offered for sale or transportation.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 32a - Domesticated Game Slaughter and Processing
****************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Domesticated Game Slaughter and Processing."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(1): "Antemortem inspection" means the inspection of live domesticated game immediately before slaughter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(2): "Domesticated game" means one of the following that is commercially raised for wholesale or retail sale to a restaurant, store, or end consumer:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(2)(a): a domesticated elk;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(2)(b): a bison;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(2)(c): a game bird; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(2)(d): a rabbit.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(3): "Domesticated game carcass" means any part of the slaughtered body of domesticated game, including entrails and edible meats.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(4): Chapter 32, Utah Meat and Poultry Products Inspection and Licensing Act "Domesticated game slaughter" means the slaughter of domesticated game that is not regulated under
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(5): 4-32-105 "End consumer" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(5)(a): 4-32-105 purchases a product directly from an agricultural operation or a facility licensed to perform custom exempt processing, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(5)(b): does not resell the purchased product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(6): 4-32-107 "Farm custom slaughter license" means a farm custom slaughter license issued under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(7): "Postmortem inspection" means the inspection of a domesticated game carcass after slaughter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(8): "Process" means to cut, grind, manufacture, compound, smoke, intermix, or prepare products from a domesticated game carcass.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(9): "Slaughter" means killing domesticated game in a humane manner, including skinning or dressing.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(10): Title 58, Chapter 28, Veterinary Practice Act "Veterinarian" means a veterinarian licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-201(11): "Veterinarian designee" means an individual designated by a veterinarian as successfully completing formal training in antemortem inspection and postmortem inspection.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-202 Domesticated game slaughter and processing.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-202(1): Except as provided in this part, the Federal Meat Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 601 et seq., or the Poultry Products Inspection Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 451 et seq., a person may not slaughter domesticated game for:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-202(1)(a): wholesale or retail sale; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-202(1)(b): sale to an end consumer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-202(2): In accordance with this part and department rule, the department shall permit the slaughter and processing of domesticated game.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-202(3): This chapter does not apply to the slaughter of domesticated game if the purpose of slaughtering the domesticated game is for personal use.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-202(4): Nothing in this part prohibits a person from processing a domesticated game carcass in accordance with this part, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-202(4)(a): the domesticated game carcass passes postmortem inspection as described in this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-202(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-202(4)(b)(i): the person holds a farm custom slaughter license; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-202(4)(b)(ii): the person processes the domesticated game carcass in accordance with the exemption described in 9 C.F.R. Secs. 303.1(d)(1) and (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-202(5): A person who slaughters domesticated game under this part may not sell the domesticated game outside of the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-203 Notice to department before slaughtering or processing domesticated game.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-203(1): Before slaughtering domesticated game, a person shall notify the department at least 30 days before the day on which the person slaughters the domesticated game.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-203(2): Before processing slaughtered domesticated game, a person shall notify the department at least five days before the day on which the person processes the slaughtered domesticated game.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204 Inspection and slaughter of domesticated game.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(1): 4-32a-205 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(2): A veterinarian or veterinarian designee may complete an antemortem inspection or postmortem inspection in the field, in accordance with the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(3)(a): Before undertaking an antemortem inspection or postmortem inspection, a veterinarian or veterinarian designee shall inspect the designated slaughter area and facilities in accordance with this part and department rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(3)(b): (3)(a) A veterinarian or veterinarian designee may not undertake an antemortem or postmortem inspection if the designated slaughter area and facilities do not pass the inspection described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(4): If domesticated game requires an antemortem inspection and the domesticated game does not pass the antemortem inspection, the domesticated game may not be slaughtered for wholesale or retail sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(5)(a): Before being shackled, hoisted, thrown, cast, or cut, domesticated game shall be rendered insensible to pain by a single blow, gunshot, electrical shock, or other means that is instantaneous and effective.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(5)(b): Immediately after domesticated game is stunned or killed, the domesticated game or domesticated game carcass shall be shackled, hoisted, stuck, and bled.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(5)(c): The parts of a domesticated game carcass shall be identified with the particular carcass until after completion of the postmortem inspection, in accordance with department rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(6)(a): Postmortem inspection of a domesticated game carcass shall be conducted immediately following the slaughter and evisceration of the domesticated game.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(6)(b): A veterinarian or veterinarian designee that completes a postmortem inspection shall, if condemning a domesticated game carcass:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(6)(b)(i): mark each domesticated game carcass or part of a domesticated game carcass as condemned in accordance with department rule; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-204(6)(b)(ii): retain custody of each condemned domesticated game carcass or carcass part until proper disposal occurs, in accordance with 9 C.F.R. Part 314 and department rule.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-205 Requirements for slaughtered domesticated game intended for sale to an end consumer.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-205(1): Domesticated game intended for sale to an end consumer does not require an antemortem inspection.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-205(2): Domesticated game intended for sale to an end consumer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-205(2)(a): receive a postmortem inspection; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-205(2)(b): in accordance with department rule, prior to sale, be labeled that the purchased product is not certified, licensed, regulated, or inspected by the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-206 Transportation of slaughtered domesticated game.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-206(1): Prior to transport, stunned or slaughtered domesticated game shall be tagged as described in department rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-206(2): A domesticated game carcass intended for processing shall be transported in accordance with department rule.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-207 Fees set by department -- Cost of chronic wasting disease testing.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-207(1): The department shall adopt a schedule of fees to cover the cost of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-207(2): The owner of domesticated game slaughtered under this part is responsible for the cost of required chronic wasting disease testing.

-------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-208(1)(h): procedure for transportation of a domesticated game carcass; and

Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-208(2)(a): with inspection and processed at a farm custom slaughter facility; or

Utah Code Annotated § 4-32a-208(3)(a): a person with a farm custom slaughter license to slaughter and process domesticated game in accordance with this part; and

Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 33 - Motor Fuel Inspection Act
**********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter shall be known as the "Motor Fuel Inspection Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-102 Purpose of chapter.
--------------------------------------------------
It is the purpose of this chapter to promote the safety and welfare of users of motor fuels in this state and also to promote the orderly marketing of motor fuels.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-103 Definition.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter, "motor fuel" means any combustible  liquid or vapor used to power a motor vehicle or a motor vehicle engine.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-104 Administrative and enforcement powers of department.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall administer and enforce this chapter and may:Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-104(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act make and enforce such rules, subject to
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-104(2): acquire and test motor fuel samples to determine compliance with this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-104(3): maintain and staff a laboratory to test motor fuel samples;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-104(4): enter public or private premises during normal working hours to enforce this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-104(5): stop and detain any commercial vehicle transporting motor fuel to inspect the contents and applicable documents or to acquire motor fuel samples; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-104(6): require that records applicable to this chapter be available for examination and review upon request by the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-105 Prohibitions.
--------------------------------------------
It is unlawful for any person in this state to:Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-105(1): offer for sale, sell, or deliver any motor fuel which fails to meet the standards prescribed by the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-105(2): advertise or display the price of motor fuel without advertising or displaying the grade of the motor fuel and the type of service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-105(3): haul or transport motor fuel for the purpose of sale or delivery in this state without an invoice or bill of lading stating the name and address of the owner or person consigning the fuel for transport, the Utah grade of the motor fuel, and the number of gallons consigned.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-106 Octane rating determination and posting.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
The determination of octane ratings and the posting of the octane on dispensing devices shall be in accord with Federal Trade Commission requirements  described in 16 C.F.R. Part 306, Automotive Fuel Ratings, Certification, and Posting.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-107 Inspection, sampling, testing, and analysis of fuels by department.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-107(1): The department shall periodically sample, inspect, analyze and test motor fuels dispensed in this state and may enter any public premises or vehicle for the purpose of determining compliance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-107(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-107(2)(a): Methods of sampling, testing, analyzing, and designating motor fuels shall conform with methods specified and published by the American Society for Testing and Materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-107(2)(b): Unless modified by the department by rule, the latest published standards of the American Society for Testing and Materials apply.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-107(3): Upon request, the department shall pay the posted price for samples and the person from whom the sample is taken shall give a signed receipt evidencing payment.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-107(4): Tests and analyses conducted by the department shall be prima facie evidence of the facts shown by such tests in any court proceeding.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-108 Locking and sealing of pumps in violation of chapter -- Posting notice -- Removal of sealed fuel -- Resealing.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-108(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-108(1)(a): The department may lock and seal any pump or other dispensing device that is in violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-108(1)(b): (1)(a) If  the department locks and seals a pump or other dispensing device pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-108(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-108(2)(a): Any person who is aggrieved by the action of the department may advise the department that such person intends to remove the balance of the motor fuel from the tank or other container which contains the sealed motor fuel.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-108(2)(b): The department, within two working days after the receipt of such notice, shall break the seal or lock for the container to be emptied.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-108(3): 4-2-103(2)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-108(3)(a): If the aggrieved party fails to remove the sealed motor fuel within 24 hours after the department breaks the seal, the department may reseal the dispensing device.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-108(3)(b): 4-2-103(2) The seal may not be broken nor the contents of any container removed, except after a subsequent written notice of intent to remove is filed with the department and upon the payment of a service charge determined by the department pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-108(3)(c): A notice of intent to remove may be filed on paper or electronically.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-109 Warrant to enter premises for inspection or sampling.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If admittance is refused to the department either for sampling or for inspection of transport invoices or bills of lading, the department may obtain an ex parte warrant from the nearest court of competent jurisdiction to allow entry upon the premises for the purpose of inspection or taking samples or to examine transport documents.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-110 Interstate commerce -- Chapter inapplicable to fuel in transit through state.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-110(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-33-110(2): This chapter applies to motor fuel that is consigned or destined for delivery in the state.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 34 - Charitable Donation
****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Charitable Donation."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
For purposes of this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-102(1): "Agricultural product" means a fowl, animal, fish, vegetable, or other product or article, fresh or processed, that is customary food, or that is proper food for human consumption.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-102(2): "Glean" means to harvest, for free distribution, an agricultural crop that has been donated by the owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-102(3): Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act; 10-1-104 "Government food pantry" means the following when receiving, accepting, gleaning, or distributing food donated under this chapter, or a food pantry sponsored by one of the following that accepts, gleans, or distributes food donated under this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-102(3)(a): Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act an association of political subdivisions created under
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-102(3)(b): a county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-102(3)(c): 10-1-104 a municipality as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-102(4): "Nonprofit charitable organization" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-102(4)(a): an organization that is organized and is operating for charitable purposes and that meets the requirements of the Internal Revenue Service of the U.S. Department of Treasury that exempt the organization from income taxation under the Internal Revenue Code; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-102(4)(b): a government food pantry.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-102(5): 4-32-105 "Wild game" means the same as that term is defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-103 Donation to charitable organization authorized.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person engaged in the business of producing, processing, selling, or distributing any agricultural product may donate, free of charge, any such product which is in a fit condition for use as food for human consumption to a nonprofit charitable organization within the state of Utah.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-104 County surplus food collection and distribution system.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-104(1): 4-34-103 To accomplish the purposes of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-104(2): Any nonprofit charitable organization needing agricultural products on a regular basis may be listed with the county for the purpose of receiving notice that the products are available.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-105 Inspection of donated food.
----------------------------------------------------------
The county may provide for the inspection of donated agricultural products by the county health officer upon the request of the donee nonprofit charitable organization to determine whether the products are fit for human consumption.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-106 Limitation of liability of donor, nonprofit charitable organization, and county.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In addition to SectionUtah Code Annotated § 4-34-106(1): a county or an agency of a county that participates in good faith in a food donation program;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-106(2): a donor of an agricultural product who participates in good faith in a food donation program;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-106(3): 4-34-108 a donor of wild game meat, including a custom meat processor, who complies with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-106(4): a nonprofit charitable organization receiving, accepting, gleaning, or distributing an agricultural product or meat from wild game donated under this chapter in good faith to the nonprofit charitable organization.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-107 Sale or use of donations by employee of public agency or charity prohibited.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An employee of a nonprofit charitable organization or of a public agency may not sell, offer for sale, use, or consume any agricultural product donated or distributed under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108 Donation of wild game meat.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(1): 23A-1-101; 4-32-106 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(1)(a): 23A-1-101 "Big game" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(1)(b): 4-32-106 "Custom meat processor" means a person who processes meat but is exempt from licensure under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(1)(c): "Department" means the Department of Agriculture and Food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(2): Wild game, including big game, lawfully taken by a licensed hunter may be donated to a nonprofit charitable organization to feed individuals in need.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(3): Donated wild game meat shall meet the following conditions:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(3)(a): come from an animal in apparent good health before harvest of the animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(3)(b): come from an animal with intact intestines;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(3)(c): be field-dressed immediately after harvest of the animal and be handled in a manner in keeping with generally accepted wild game handling procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(3)(d): be processed by a custom meat processor as soon as possible after harvest of the animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(3)(e): be clearly marked as "not for sale";
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(3)(f): be clearly marked as "donated wild game meat" in letters not less than three-eighths of an inch in height; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(3)(g): may not come from a road-kill animal and a road-kill animal may not be donated under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(4)(a): A donor or custom meat processor of the wild game meat being donated shall advise the nonprofit charitable organization receiving the donated wild game meat that the donated wild game meat should be thoroughly cooked before human consumption.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(4)(b): Before serving donated wild game meat, the nonprofit charitable organization shall prominently post a sign indicating:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(4)(b)(i): that the donated wild game meat is donated wild game meat;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(4)(b)(ii): the type of meat processing used; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(4)(b)(iii): that the meat has not been inspected.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(5): The Department of Natural Resources may donate wild game meat in the Department of Natural Resources' possession if this section is followed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(6): A person may not buy, sell, or offer for sale or barter donated wild game meat.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-34-108(7): Chapter 5, Utah Wholesome Food Act The department may examine, sample, seize, or condemn donated wild game meat if the department has reason to believe that the donated wild game meat is unwholesome under

Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-101 Title.

This chapter is known as the "Plant Pest Emergency Control Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-102(2): 4-35-106 "Fund" means the Plant Pest Fund created by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-102(3): 4-2-103 "Plant pest" means a biological agent that the commissioner determines to be a threat to agriculture in the state as described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-104 Commissioner to declare emergency -- Powers of commissioner in emergency.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-104(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-104(1)(a): The commissioner, with the consent of the governor, may declare that a plant pest emergency situation exists that jeopardizes property and resources, and designate the area or areas affected.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-104(1)(b): (1)(a) An area referred to in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-104(2): 4-35-105 The commissioner is authorized, subject to Section

Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-104(3)(b): enter into contracts for the acquisition, rental, or hire of equipment, services, materials, and supplies;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-104(3)(c): accept assistance, services, and facilities offered by federal and local governmental units or private agencies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-104(3)(d): accept on behalf of the state the provisions and benefits of acts of Congress designated to provide assistance.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-105 Commissioner to act upon declaration of a plant pest emergency.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-105(1): The commissioner initiates operations to control a plant pest in the designated area or upon declaration of an infestation emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-105(2): The commissioner may suspend or terminate control operations upon a determination that the operations will not significantly reduce the plant pest population in the designated emergency area.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-106 Plant Pest Fund.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-106(1): There is created an expendable special revenue fund known as the "Plant Pest Fund."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-106(2)(c): appropriations from the Legislature;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-106(2)(d): federal money deposited into the fund; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-106(2)(e): the interest and earnings on the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-106(3): (4) The department may only use money in the fund to fund survey, detection, eradication, or suppression efforts for plant pests with the exception designated in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-106(4): The department may annually use an amount not to exceed the lesser of the following for staff or administrative costs to carry out the department's duties under this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-106(4)(a): 10% of the fund annually; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-106(4)(b): $300,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-106(5): (2)(a); (c); (e); (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-106(5)(a): (2)(a); (c); (e) The fund may not exceed $10,000,000 of money deposited under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-106(5)(b): (5)(a) The Division of Finance shall transfer the money described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-106(7): Fund money may be used as matching funds for participation in programs of the United States Department of Agriculture for survey, detection, eradication, or suppression efforts of plant pests.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-107 Notice to owner or occupant -- Corrective action required -- Directive issued by department -- Costs -- Owner or occupant may prohibit treatment.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-107(1): The department or an authorized agent of the department shall notify the owner or occupant of the problem and the available alternatives to remedy the problem.  The owner or occupant shall take corrective action within 30 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-107(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-107(2)(a): (1) If the owner or occupant fails to take corrective action under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-107(2)(b): If the owner or occupant fails to act within the required time, the department shall take the necessary action.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-107(2)(c): The department may recover full or partial costs incurred for controlling a plant pest emergency from the owner or occupant of the property on whose property corrective action was taken.  The amount of costs to be recovered is at the department's sole discretion.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-107(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-107(3)(a): An owner or occupant of property may prohibit treatment by presenting an affidavit from the owner's or occupant's attending physician or physician assistant to the department that states that the treatment as planned is a danger to the owner's or occupant's health.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-107(3)(b): The department shall provide the owner or occupant with alternatives to treatment that will abate the plant pest.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-35-108 Persons and activities exempt from civil liability.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
No state agency or state agency officers and employees nor the officers, agents, employees, or representatives of any governmental or private entity acting under the authority granted by this chapter is liable for claims arising out of the reasonable exercise or performance of duties and responsibilities under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 37 - Aquaculture Act
************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Aquaculture Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-102 Purpose statement -- Aquaculture considered a branch of agriculture.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-102(1): The Legislature declares that it is in the interest of the people of the state to encourage the practice of aquaculture, while protecting the public fishery resource, in order to augment food production, expand employment, promote economic development, and protect and better utilize the land and water resources of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-102(2): The Legislature further declares that aquaculture is considered a branch of the agricultural industry of the state for purposes of any laws that apply to or provide for the advancement, benefit, or protection of the agricultural industry within the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(1): "Aquaculture" means the controlled cultivation of aquatic animals.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(2)(a)(i): "Aquaculture facility" means any tank, canal, raceway, pond, off-stream reservoir, or other structure used for aquaculture.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(2)(a)(ii): "Aquaculture facility" does not include any public aquaculture facility or fee fishing facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(2)(b): Structures that are separated by more than 1/2 mile, or structures that drain to or are modified to drain to, different drainages, are considered separate aquaculture facilities regardless of ownership.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(3)(a): "Aquatic animal" means a member of any species of fish, mollusk, crustacean, or amphibian.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(3)(b): (3)(a) "Aquatic animal" includes a gamete of any species listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(4): "Fee fishing facility" means a body of water used for holding or rearing fish for the purpose of providing fishing for a fee or for pecuniary consideration or advantage.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(5): 23A-1-101 "Natural flowing stream" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(6): 23A-1-101 "Natural lake" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(7): 23A-1-101 "Private fish pond" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(8): "Public aquaculture facility" means a tank, canal, raceway, pond, off-stream reservoir, or other structure used for aquaculture by the Division of Wildlife Resources, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, a mosquito abatement district, or an institution of higher education.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(9): "Public fishery resource" means fish produced in public aquaculture facilities and wild and free ranging populations of fish in the surface waters of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(10): 23A-1-101 "Reservoir constructed on a natural stream channel" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-103(11): 23A-1-101 "Short-term fishing event" means the same as that term is defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-104 Department's responsibilities.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-104(1): The department is responsible for enforcing laws and rules made by the Wildlife Board governing species of aquatic animals that may be imported into the state or possessed or transported within the state that are applicable to aquaculture or fee fishing facilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-104(2): Subject to the policies and rules of the Fish Health Policy Board, the department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-104(2)(a): act to prevent the outbreak and act to control the spread of disease-causing pathogens among aquatic animals in aquaculture and fee fishing facilities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-104(2)(b): act to prevent the spread of disease-causing pathogens from aquatic animals in, to be deposited in, or harvested from aquaculture or fee fishing facilities to wild aquatic animals, other animals, and humans.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-105 Responsibilities of Wildlife Board and Division of Wildlife Resources.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-105(1): The Wildlife Board and Division of Wildlife Resources are responsible for  determining the species of aquatic animals which may be imported into, possessed, and transported within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-105(2): Subject to the policies and rules of the Fish Health Policy Board, the Wildlife Board and the Division of Wildlife Resources shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-105(2)(a): act to prevent the outbreak and act to control the spread of disease-causing pathogens among aquatic animals in public aquaculture facilities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-105(2)(b): act to prevent the spread of disease-causing pathogens from aquatic animals in, to be deposited in, or harvested from public aquaculture facilities and private ponds to wild aquatic animals, other animals, and humans.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-106 Cooperative agreements.
------------------------------------------------------
In fulfilling their respective responsibilities under this chapter, the department, Division of Wildlife Resources, and Wildlife Board may make memorandums of understanding or enter into other agreements for mutual cooperation.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-108 Prohibited activities.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-108(1): 4-37-109; 4-37-503 Except as provided in this chapter, in the rules of the department made pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-108(1)(a): acquire, import, or possess aquatic animals intended for use in an aquaculture or fee fishing facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-108(1)(b): transport aquatic animals to or from an aquaculture or fee fishing facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-108(1)(c): stock or propagate aquatic animals in an aquaculture or fee fishing facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-108(1)(d): harvest, transfer, or sell aquatic animals from an aquaculture or fee fishing facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-108(1)(e): release aquatic animals into the waters of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-108(2): (1); 23A-5-311; 23A-5-311 If a person commits an act in violation of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-304 Sale or transfer of live aquatic animals from fee fishing facilities prohibited.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Live aquatic animals may not be sold or transferred from fee fishing facilities.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-305 Fishing license not required to fish at fee fishing facilities -- Transportation of dead fish.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-305(1): A fishing license is not required to take fish from fee fishing facilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-305(2): To transport dead fish from fee fishing facilities the fish shall be accompanied by the seller's receipt containing the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-305(2)(a): species and number of fish;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-305(2)(b): date caught;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-305(2)(c): license number of the fee fishing facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-305(2)(d): name, address, and telephone number of the seller.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-401 License required to import aquatic animals for aquaculture or fee fishing facilities.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-401(1): A person may not import aquatic animals classified as controlled species by rules of the Wildlife Board into the state for use in aquaculture or fee fishing facilities without first obtaining a license from the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-401(2): The department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-401(2)(a): coordinate with the Division of Wildlife Resources in determining which species the holder may import into the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-401(2)(b): specify those species on the license.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-401(3): A person may not import species into the state that are not listed on the license.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-402 Documentation required to import aquatic animals.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any aquatic animals classified as controlled species by rules of the Wildlife Board that are imported into the state for use in aquaculture or fee fishing facilities shall be accompanied by documentation indicating the following:Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-402(1): the health approval number assigned by the department to the source facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-402(2): common or scientific names of the imported animals;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-402(3): name and address of the consignor and consignee;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-402(4): origin of shipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-402(5): final destination;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-402(6): number or pounds shipped;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-402(7): purpose for which shipped;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-402(8): method of transportation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-402(9): any other information required by the department.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503 Fish Health Policy Board.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(1): There is created within the department the Fish Health Policy Board that shall establish policies designed to prevent the outbreak of, control the spread of, and eradicate pathogens that cause disease in aquatic animals.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2): (6)(b) The Fish Health Policy Board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2)(a): (6)(b) in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2)(a)(i): the pathogens for which inspection is required to receive health approval;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2)(a)(ii): the pathogens that may not be present to receive health approval; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2)(a)(iii): standards and procedures required for the inspection of aquatic animals;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2)(b): establish procedures for the timely reporting of the presence of a pathogen and disease threat;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2)(c): create policies and procedures for, and appoint, an emergency response team to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2)(c)(i): investigate a serious disease threat;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2)(c)(ii): develop and monitor a plan of action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2)(c)(iii): report to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2)(c)(iii)(A): the commissioner of agriculture and food;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2)(c)(iii)(B): the director of the Division of Wildlife Resources; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2)(c)(iii)(C): the chair of the Fish Health Policy Board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(2)(d): develop a unified statewide aquaculture disease control plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(3): The Fish Health Policy Board shall advise the commissioner of agriculture and food and the executive director of the Department of Natural Resources regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(3)(a): educational programs and information systems to educate and inform the public about practices that the public may employ to prevent the spread of disease; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-503(3)(b): communication and interaction between the department and the Division of Wildlife Resources regarding fish health policies and procedures.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-601 Enforcement and penalties.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-601(1): Any violation of this chapter is a class B misdemeanor and may be grounds for revocation of the license or denial of any future license as determined by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-37-601(2): A violation of any rule made under this chapter may be grounds for revocation of the license or denial for future license as determined by the department.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 38 - Utah Horse Regulation Act
**********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Horse Regulation Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-102(1): "Commission" means the Utah Horse Racing Commission created by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-102(2): "Executive director" means the executive director of the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-102(3): "Mixed meet" means a race meet that includes races by more than one breed of horse.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-102(4): "Race meet" means the entire period of time for which a licensee has been approved to hold horse races.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-102(5): "Racetrack facility" means a racetrack within Utah approved by the commission for the racing of horses, including the track surface, grandstands, clubhouse, all animal housing and handling areas, and other areas in which a person may enter only upon payment of an admission fee or upon presentation of authorized credentials.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-102(6): "Recognized race meet" means a race meet recognized by a national horse breed association.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-102(7): "Utah bred horse" means a horse that is sired by a stallion standing in Utah at the time the dam was bred.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103 Utah Horse Racing Commission.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(a): There is created within the department the Utah Horse Racing Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(b)(i): The commission shall consist of seven members who shall be United States citizens, Utah residents, and qualified voters in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(b)(ii): Each member shall have an interest in horse racing.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(b)(iii): Two members shall be chosen from horse racing organizations.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(c)(i): The governor shall appoint the members of the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(c)(ii): The governor shall appoint commission members from a list of nominees submitted by the commissioner of agriculture and food.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(d)(i): The members of the commission shall be appointed to four-year terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(d)(ii): A commission member may not serve more than two consecutive terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(e): Each member shall hold office until the member's successor is appointed and qualified.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(f): Vacancies on the commission shall be filled by appointment by the governor for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(g): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(g)(i): A member may be removed from office by the governor for cause after a public hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(g)(ii): Notice of the hearing shall fix the time and place of the hearing and shall specify the charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(g)(iii): Copies of the notice of the hearing shall be served on the member by mailing the notice of hearing to the member at the member's last known address at least 10 days before the date fixed for the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(1)(g)(iv): The governor may designate a hearing officer to preside over the hearing and report the hearing findings to the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(2)(a): The members of the commission shall annually elect a commission chair.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(2)(b): Five members of the commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business of the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(3): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(3)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(3)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(3)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(4): All claims and expenditures made under this chapter shall be first audited and passed by the commission and when approved shall be paid in the manner provided by law for payment of claims against the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(5): Any member of the commission who has a personal or private interest in any matter proposed or pending before the commission shall publicly disclose this fact to the commission and may not vote on the matter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-103(6): Any member of the commission who owns or who has any interest, or whose spouse or member of his immediate family has any interest, in a horse participating in a race shall disclose that interest and may not participate in any commission decision involving that race.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104 Powers and duties of commission.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(1)(a): license, regulate, and supervise the persons involved in the racing of horses as provided in this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(1)(b): license, regulate, and supervise the recognized race meets held in this state under the terms of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(1)(c): cause the various places where recognized race meets are held to be visited and inspected at least once a year;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(1)(d): assist in procuring public liability insurance coverage from a private insurance company for those licensees unable to otherwise obtain the insurance required under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(1)(e): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act make rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(1)(e)(i): to resolve scheduling conflicts and settle disputes among licensees;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(1)(e)(ii): to supervise, discipline, suspend, fine, and bar from events a person required to be licensed by this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(1)(e)(iii): to exclude a horse from a racetrack facility in this state, or prohibit a horse from participating in a horse race or race meet; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(1)(e)(iv): to hold, conduct, and operate all recognized race meets conducted pursuant to this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(1)(f): determine which persons participating, directly or indirectly, in recognized race meets require licenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(1)(g): announce the time, place, and duration of a recognized race meet for which a license is required; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(1)(h): establish reasonable fees for all licenses provided for under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(2): The commission may:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(2)(a): grant, suspend, or revoke licenses issued under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(2)(b): impose fines as provided in this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(2)(c): access criminal history record information for the licensees and commission or contracted employees;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(2)(d): exclude from any racetrack facility in this state a person, including an owner, who:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(2)(d)(i): the commission considers detrimental to the best interests of racing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(2)(d)(ii): violates this chapter or any rule or order of the commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(2)(e): exclude from a racetrack facility in this state, or prohibit from participating in a horse race or race meet, a horse that is owned, in full or part by a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(2)(e)(i): who the commission considers detrimental to the best interests of racing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(2)(e)(ii): who violates this chapter or a rule or order of the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(3): (2)(e); (2)(e); (2)(e)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(3)(a): (2)(e) For purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(3)(b): (2)(e) The period of time a horse may be excluded or prohibited from racing under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(3)(c): (2)(e) A change in ownership or beneficial interest in a horse excluded or prohibited from racing under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-104(4): Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code; (1)(a); (b) The commission may contract, in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-105 Executive director.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-105(1): The commission shall be under the general administrative control of an executive director appointed by the commissioner with the concurrence of the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-105(2): The executive director shall serve at the pleasure of the commissioner.
