Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202 Stewards.
----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(1): (1)(c)(iv); (v)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(1)(a): The commission may delegate authority to enforce commission rules and this chapter to three stewards at each recognized race meet.  At least one of the stewards shall be selected by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(1)(b): For the purpose of enforcing this chapter and the rules and orders of the commission, a decision by the stewards shall be passed by a majority vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(1)(c): (1)(c)(iv); (v) Stewards shall exercise reasonable and necessary authority as designated by rules of the commission including the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(1)(c)(i): enforce rules of the commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(1)(c)(ii): rule on the outcome of events;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(1)(c)(iii): evict from an event any person who has been convicted of bookmaking, bribery, or attempts to alter the outcome of any race through tampering with any animal that is not in accordance with this chapter or the rules of the commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(1)(c)(iv): levy fines not to exceed $2,500 for violations of rules of the commission, which fines shall be reported daily and paid to the commission within 48 hours of imposition and notice;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(1)(c)(v): suspend licenses not to exceed one year for violations of rules of the commission, which suspension shall be reported to the commission daily;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(1)(c)(vi): (1)(c)(iv); (v) recommend that the commission impose fines or suspensions greater than permitted by Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(1)(c)(vii): exclude a horse from a racetrack facility in this state, or prohibit a horse from participating in a horse race or race meet.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(2): If a majority of the stewards agree, they may impose fines or suspend licenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(3): 4-38-301
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(3)(a): A fine or license suspension imposed by a steward may be appealed in writing to the commission within five days after the fine or license suspension imposition. The commission may affirm or reverse the decision of a steward or may increase or decrease any fine or suspension.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(3)(b): 4-38-301 A fine imposed by the commission under this section or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-202(3)(c): Suspensions of a license may be for any period of time but shall be commensurate with the seriousness of the offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-203 Race meets -- Licenses -- Fairs.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-203(1): A person making application for a license to hold a race meet under this chapter shall file an application that sets forth the time, place, and number of days the race meet will continue, and other information the commission may require.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-203(2): A person who has been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude may not be issued a license to hold a race meet.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-203(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-203(3)(a): The license issued shall specify the kind and character of the race meet to be held, the number of days the race meet shall continue, and the number of races per day.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-203(3)(b): The licensee shall pay in advance of the scheduled race meet to the commission a fee of not less than $25. If unforeseen obstacles arise that prevent the holding or completion of any race meet, the license fee held may be refunded to the licensee if the commission considers the reason for failure to hold or complete the race meet sufficient.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-203(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-203(4)(a): An unexpired license held by any person who violates this chapter, or fails to pay to the commission any fees required under this chapter, is subject to cancellation and revocation by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-203(4)(b): This cancellation shall be made only after a summary hearing before the commission, of which seven days notice in writing shall be given the licensee, specifying the grounds for the proposed cancellation. At the hearing, the licensee shall be given an opportunity to be heard in opposition to the proposed cancellation.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-203(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-203(5)(a): A fair board or fair district that conducts a race meet in connection with a regularly scheduled annual fair is exempt from payment of the fees provided in this section, unless the fair board or fair district sponsors a race in which the speed indexes are officially recognized under breed requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-203(5)(b): A race meet in connection with a fair is limited to 14 race days, unless otherwise permitted by a unanimous vote of the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-203(6): (5)(a) The exemption from the payment of fees under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301 Investigation -- License denial and suspension -- Grounds for revocation -- Fines.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(1): The commission or board of stewards of a recognized race meet, upon their own motion may, and upon verified complaint in writing of any person shall, investigate the activities of a licensee within the state or a licensed person upon the premises of a racetrack facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(2): The commission or board of stewards may fine, suspend a license, or deny an application for a license.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(3): 4-38-104(4) A person with whom the commission contracts under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4): The commission may revoke a license, if the licensee has committed any of the following violations:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(a): substantial or willful misrepresentation;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(b): disregard for or violation of this chapter or of a rule issued by the commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(c): conviction of a felony under the laws of this or any other state or of the United States, a true and correct copy of the judgment of the court of conviction of which shall be presumptive evidence of the conviction in any hearing held under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(d): fraud, willful misrepresentation, or deceit in racing;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(e): falsification, misrepresentation, or omission of required information in a license application;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(f): failure to disclose to the commission a complete ownership or beneficial interest in a horse entered to be raced;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(g): misrepresentation or attempted misrepresentation in connection with the sale of a horse or other matter pertaining to racing or registration of racing animals;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(h): failure to comply with an order or ruling of the commission, the stewards, or a racing official pertaining to a racing matter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(i): ownership of any interest in or participation by any manner in any bookmaking, pool-selling, touting, bet solicitation, or illegal enterprise;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(j): being unqualified by experience or competence to perform the activity permitted by the license possessed or being applied for;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(k): employment or harboring of any unlicensed person on the premises of a racetrack facility if a license is required by this chapter or rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(l): discontinuance of or ineligibility for the activity for which the license was issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(m): being currently under suspension or revocation of a racing license in another racing jurisdiction;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(n): possession on the premises of a racetrack facility of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(n)(i): firearms; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(n)(ii): a battery, buzzer, electrical device, or other appliance other than a whip which could be used to alter the speed of a horse in a race or while working out or schooling;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(o): possession, on the premises of a racetrack facility, by a person other than a licensed veterinarian of a hypodermic needle, hypodermic syringe, or other similar device that may be used in administering medicine internally in a horse, or any substance, compound items, or combination of any medicine, narcotic, stimulant, depressant, or anesthetic which could alter the normal performance of a horse unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(o)(i): specifically authorized by a commission-approved veterinarian; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(o)(ii): as otherwise allowed by the stewards for the conditions of that horse race or race meet;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(p): cruelty to or neglect of a horse;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(q): offering, promising, giving, accepting, or soliciting a bribe in any form, directly or indirectly, to or by a person having any connection with the outcome of a race, or failure to report knowledge of such act immediately to the stewards, the patrol judges, or the commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(r): causing, attempting to cause, or participation in any way in any attempt to cause the prearrangement of a race result, or failure to report knowledge of such act immediately to the stewards, the patrol judges, or the commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(s): entering, or aiding and abetting the entry of, a horse ineligible or unqualified for the race entered;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(t): willfully or unjustifiably entering or racing any horse in any race under any name or designation other than the name or designation assigned to the animal by and registered with the official recognized registry for that breed of animal, or willfully setting on foot, instigating, engaging in, or in any way furthering any act by which any horse is entered or raced in any race under any name or designation other than the name or designation duly assigned by and registered with the official recognized registry for the breed of animal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(4)(u): racing at a racetrack facility without having that horse registered to race at that racetrack facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(5)(a): A person who fails to pay in a timely manner a fine imposed pursuant to this chapter shall pay, in addition to the fine due, a penalty amount equal to the fine.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-301(5)(b): A person who submits to the commission a check in payment of a fine or license fee requirement imposed pursuant to this chapter, which is not honored by the financial institution upon which the check is drawn, shall pay, in addition to the fine or fee due, a penalty amount equal to the fine.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-302 Stimulation or retardation of animals prohibited -- Tests.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-302(1): Any person who uses or permits the use of any mechanical or electrical device, or drug of any kind, to stimulate or retard any animal in any race authorized by this chapter, except as prescribed by the commission, is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-302(2): A commission member or race steward may cause tests to be made that the commission considers proper to determine whether any animal has been stimulated or retarded.  Tests performed in furtherance of this section shall be conducted by or under the supervision of a licensed Utah veterinarian.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-303 Bribery and touting prohibited.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who gives or promises or attempts to give, or any person who receives or agrees to receive or attempts to receive, any money, bribe, or thing of value with intent to influence any person to dishonestly umpire, manage, direct, judge, preside, officiate at, or participate in any race conducted under this chapter with the intent or purpose that the result of the race will be affected or influenced thereby, is guilty of a felony of the third degree and subject to a fine of not more than $10,000.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-304 Gambling disclaimer.
---------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this chapter may be construed to legalize or permit any form of gambling.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-401 Race meet money.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-401(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The commission shall make rules, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-401(2): Payment deposits shall be made in a timely manner determined by the commission, and each licensee shall provide proof of deposits as required by the commission.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-402 Horse Racing Account created -- Contents -- Use of account money.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-402(1): There is created within the General Fund a restricted account known as the Horse Racing Account.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-402(2): The Horse Racing Account consists of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-402(2)(a): license fees collected under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-402(2)(b): revenue from fines imposed under this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-402(2)(c): interest on account money.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-402(3): Upon appropriation by the Legislature, money from the account shall be used for the administration of this chapter, including paying the costs of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-402(3)(a): public liability insurance;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-402(3)(b): stewards;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-402(3)(c): veterinarians; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-402(3)(d): drug testing.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-501 Hearings.
----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-501(1): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act Except as otherwise provided in this section, all proceedings before the commission or the commission's hearing officer with respect to the denial, suspension, or revocation of licenses or the imposition of fines shall be conducted pursuant to
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-501(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-501(2)(a): These proceedings shall be held in the county where the commission has an office or in any other place the commission designates.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-501(2)(b): The commission shall notify the applicant or licensee by mailing, by first class mail, a copy of the written notice required to the last address furnished by the application or licensee to the commission at least seven days in advance of the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-501(3): The commission may delegate the commission's authority to conduct hearings with respect to the denial or suspension of licenses or the imposition of a fine to a hearing officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-501(4): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act Proceedings before the board of stewards need not be governed by the procedural or other requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-501(5): The commission and the board of stewards may administer oaths and affirmations, sign and issue subpoenas, order the production of documents and other evidence, and regulate the course of the hearing pursuant to rules adopted by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-501(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-501(6)(a): Any person aggrieved by a final order or ruling issued by a board of stewards may appeal the order or ruling to the commission pursuant to procedural rules adopted by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-38-501(6)(b): The aggrieved party may petition the commission for a stay of execution pending appeal to the commission.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 39 - Domesticated Elk Act
*****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Domesticated Elk Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(1)(a): "Commingle" means maintaining animals in a manner in which physical contact among animals could occur.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(1)(b): "Commingle" includes maintaining animals in the same pasture or enclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(1)(c): "Commingle" does not include holding animals:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(1)(c)(i): at a sale;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(1)(c)(ii): during transportation;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(1)(c)(iii): during artificial insemination; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(1)(c)(iv): in other circumstances involving limited contact among animals for a short period of time.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(2): "Domesticated elk" means elk of the genus and species cervus elaphus, held in captivity and domestically raised for commercial purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(3)(a): "Domesticated elk facility" means a facility where only domesticated elk are raised.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(3)(b): "Domesticated elk facility" includes an elk ranch.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(4): "Domesticated elk product" means any carcass, part of a carcass, hide, meat, meat food product, antlers, or any part of a domesticated elk.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(5): "Elk ranch" means a facility where domesticated elk are harvested through typical hunting methods.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(6): "Suspect domesticated elk" means a domesticated elk for which:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(6)(a): the state veterinarian has determined that the following suggest that the domesticated elk may be infected with a disease spreading pathogen:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(6)(a)(i): unofficial test results;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(6)(a)(ii): laboratory evidence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(6)(a)(iii): clinical signs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(6)(b): official laboratory results for a disease spreading pathogen:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(6)(b)(i): are inconclusive; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-102(6)(b)(ii): have not been conducted.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-103 Department's responsibilities.
-------------------------------------------------------------
The department is responsible for enforcing laws and rules relating to:Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-103(1): the importation, possession, or transportation of domesticated elk into the state or within the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-103(2): the inspection of domesticated elk facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-103(3): preventing the outbreak and controlling the spread of disease-causing pathogens among domesticated elk in domesticated elk facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-103(4): preventing the spread of disease-causing pathogens from domesticated elk to wildlife, other animals, or humans; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-103(5): Chapter 31, Control of Animal Disease if necessary, quarantining any domesticated elk pursuant to


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104 Domesticated Elk Act advisory council.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(1): The department shall establish a Domesticated Elk Act advisory council to give advice and make recommendations on policies and rules adopted pursuant to this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(2): The advisory council shall consist of 10 members appointed by the commissioner of agriculture to four-year terms as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(2)(a): one member, recommended by the executive director of the Department of Natural Resources, shall represent the Department of Natural Resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(2)(b): two members, one of whom shall be the state veterinarian, shall represent the Department of Agriculture;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(2)(c): one member shall represent the livestock industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(2)(d): one member, recommended by the executive director of the Department of Natural Resources from a list of candidates submitted by the Division of Wildlife Resources, shall represent wildlife interests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(2)(e): five members, recommended by the Department of Agriculture, shall represent the domesticated elk industry.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(3): (2) Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(4): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(5)(a): A majority of the advisory council constitutes a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(5)(b): A quorum is necessary for the council to act.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(6): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(6)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(6)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-104(6)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-105 Prohibited activities.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-105(1): Except as provided in this title or in the rules of the department made pursuant to this title, a person may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-105(1)(a): acquire, import, or possess domesticated elk intended for use in a domesticated elk facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-105(1)(b): transport domesticated elk to or from a domesticated elk facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-105(1)(c): propagate domesticated elk in a domesticated elk facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-105(1)(d): harvest, transfer, possess, or sell domesticated elk or domesticated elk products from a domesticated elk facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-105(2): Releasing domesticated elk into the wild is prohibited.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-106 Department to make rules.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-106(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The department shall make rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-106(1)(a): specifying procedures for the application and renewal of licenses for operating a domesticated elk facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-106(1)(b): governing the disposal or removal of domesticated elk from a domesticated elk facility for which the license has lapsed or been revoked;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-106(1)(c): setting standards and requirements for operating a domesticated elk facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-106(1)(d): setting health requirements and standards for health inspections; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-106(1)(e): governing the possession, transportation, and accompanying documentation of domesticated elk carcasses.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-106(2): 4-39-103 The department may make other rules consistent with its responsibilities set forth in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107 Powers of state veterinarian.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(1): The state veterinarian shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(1)(a): set up periodic or ongoing surveillance programs considered necessary for:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(1)(a)(i): the recognition, control, monitoring, and elimination of infectious diseases and parasites; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(1)(a)(ii): monitoring genetic purity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(1)(b): quarantine or make any disposition of diseased animals that the state veterinarian considers necessary for the control or eradication of that disease.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(2): In carrying out the state veterinarian's duties under this section, the state veterinarian may impose reasonable restrictions, as determined by the department, on the transfer of domesticated elk to or from a domesticated elk herd for a limited time for the purpose of conducting a health risk assessment for the domesticated elk herd.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(3): Within 30 calendar days after the day on which the state veterinarian begins an animal disease traceability investigation for a domesticated elk herd, the state veterinarian shall provide written notice to an owner of the domesticated elk facility of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(3)(a): the status of the animal disease traceability investigation, including any findings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(3)(b): the owner's right to appeal.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(4): The state veterinarian may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(4)(a): quarantine a domesticated elk facility unless a domesticated elk at the domesticated elk facility has, within the previous 60 months:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(4)(a)(i): tested positive for a disease spreading pathogen; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(4)(a)(ii): commingled with a domesticated elk in a quarantined domesticated elk facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(4)(b): continue a previously ordered domesticated elk facility quarantine if an animal disease traceability investigation finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(4)(b)(i): a suspect domesticated elk was not commingled with a domesticated elk that tested positive for a disease spreading pathogen in the 60 months before the day on which the state veterinarian begins the investigation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(4)(b)(ii): no suspect domesticated elk resides at the domesticated elk facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-107(4)(c): restrict the movement of a domesticated elk in transport to an elk ranch or slaughter facility.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-108 Deposit of fees.
-----------------------------------------------
The department shall deposit all fees collected under this chapter into the Utah Livestock Brand and Anti-Theft Account created in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201 Fencing, posts, and gates.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(1): A domesticated elk facility shall, at a minimum, meet the requirements of this section and shall be constructed to prevent the movement of domestic elk and wild cervids into or out of the facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(2)(a): All perimeter fences and gates shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(2)(a)(i): a minimum of eight feet above ground level; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(2)(a)(ii): constructed of hi-tensile steel.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(2)(b): At least the bottom four feet shall be mesh with a maximum mesh size of 6" x 6".
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(2)(c): The remaining four feet shall be mesh with a maximum mesh size of 12" x 6".
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(3): The minimum wire gauge shall be 14-1/2 gauge for a 2 woven hi-tensile fence.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(4): All perimeter gates at the entrances of a domesticated elk handling facility shall be locked, with consecutive or self-closing gates when animals are present.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(5): (5)(a)(i) Posts shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(5)(a): (5)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(5)(a)(i): constructed of treated wood that is at least four inches in diameter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(5)(a)(ii): (5)(a)(i) constructed of a material with the strength equivalent of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(5)(b): spaced no more than 30 feet apart if one stay is used, or 20 feet apart if no stays are used; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(5)(c): at least eight feet above ground level and two feet below ground level.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(6): Stays, between the posts, shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(6)(a): constructed of treated wood or steel;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(6)(b): spaced no more than 15 feet from any post; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(6)(c): at least eight feet above ground level, and two feet below ground level.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-201(7): Corner posts and gate posts shall be braced wood or its strength equivalent.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-202 General facility requirements.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-202(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-202(1)(a): Internal handling facilities shall be capable of humanely restraining an individual animal and to facilitate:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-202(1)(a)(i): the application or reading of any animal identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-202(1)(a)(ii): the taking of blood or tissue samples; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-202(1)(a)(iii): any other required or necessary testing procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-202(1)(b): A domesticated elk facility shall be properly constructed to protect inspection personnel while inspection personnel are handling the domesticated elk.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-202(2): The domesticated elk facility owner shall provide ample signage around the facility indicating that it is a domesticated elk facility, so that the public is put on notice that the animals are not wild elk.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203 License required to operate a domesticated elk facility.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(1): A person may not operate a domesticated elk facility without first obtaining a license from the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(2): 63J-1-504
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(2)(a): Each application for a license to operate a domesticated elk facility shall be accompanied by a fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(2)(b): 63J-1-504 The fee shall be established by the department in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(3): Each applicant for a domesticated elk facility license shall submit an application providing all information in the form and manner as required by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(4)(a): No license shall be issued until the department has inspected and approved the facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(4)(b): The department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(4)(b)(i): notify the Division of Wildlife Resources at least 48 hours prior to a scheduled inspection so that a Division of Wildlife Resources representative may be present at the inspection; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(4)(b)(ii): provide the Division of Wildlife Resources with copies of all licensing and inspection reports.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(5): Each separate location of the domesticated elk operation shall be licensed separately.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(6)(a): If a domesticated elk facility is operated under more than one business name from a single location, the name of each operation shall be listed with the department in the form and manner required by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(6)(b): The department shall require that a separate fee be paid for each business name listed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(6)(c): If a domesticated elk facility operates under more than one business name from a single location, each facility shall maintain separate records.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(7): Each person or business entity with an equity interest in the domesticated elk shall be listed on the application for license.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(8): Each domesticated elk facility license shall expire on July 1 in the year following the year of issuance.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(9): Each licensee shall report to the department, in the form and manner required by the department, any change in the information provided in the licensee's application or in the reports previously submitted, within 15 days of each change.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-203(10): Licenses issued pursuant to this section are not transferable.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-204 Inspection of domesticated elk.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Following the issuance of a license, the licensee shall have each domesticated elk inspected within 60 days following the stocking of the facility.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205 License renewal.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205(1): To renew a license, the licensee shall submit to the department the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205(1)(a): renewal fee;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205(1)(b): paperwork showing that the:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205(1)(b)(i): domesticated elk, on the domesticated elk facility, have been inspected and certified by the department for health, proof of ownership, and genetic purity certification for all elk imported into the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205(1)(b)(ii): facility has been properly maintained, as provided in this chapter, during the immediately preceding 60-day period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205(1)(c): record of each purchase of domesticated elk and transfer of domesticated elk into the facility, which shall include the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205(1)(c)(i): name, address, and health approval number of the source;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205(1)(c)(ii): date of transaction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205(1)(c)(iii): number and sex.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205(2)(a): If the renewal fee and paperwork are not received on or before April 30, a late fee will be charged.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205(2)(b): A license may not be renewed until the fee is paid.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-205(3): If the application and fee for renewal are not received on or before July 1, the license may not be renewed, and a new license shall be required.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-206 Records to be maintained.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-206(1): The following records and information shall be maintained by a domesticated elk facility for the life of the animal plus two years:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-206(1)(a): records of purchase, acquisition, distribution, and production histories of domesticated elk;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-206(1)(b): records documenting antler harvesting, production, and distribution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-206(1)(c): health certificates.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-206(2): For purposes of carrying out the provisions of this chapter and rules made under this chapter, at any reasonable time during regular business hours, the department shall have free and unimpeded access to inspect all records required to be kept.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-206(3): The department may make copies of the records referred to in this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-207 Inspection of facilities.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-207(1): The department may conduct pathological or physical investigations at any domesticated elk facility to ensure compliance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-207(2): For purposes of carrying out the provisions of this chapter and rules made under this chapter, at any reasonable time during regular business hours, the department shall have free and unimpeded access to inspect all buildings, yards, pens, pastures, and other areas in which any domesticated elk are kept, handled, or transported.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-207(3): The department shall notify the Division of Wildlife Resources prior to an inspection so that a Division of Wildlife Resources representative may be present at the inspection.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-301 Health and genetic purity requirements -- Proof of source.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall require:Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-301(1): that each domesticated elk, including gametes, eggs, or sperm, imported into the state:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-301(1)(a): test negative for the red deer genetic factor;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-301(1)(b): be registered with gold or silver status with the North American Elk Breeders Association; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-301(1)(c): come from a state which has a red deer genetic factor prevention program approved by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-301(2): 4-39-302 proof that the domesticated elk originates from a legal source as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-302 Acquisition of domesticated elk for use in domesticated elk facilities.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Domesticated elk intended for use in domesticated elk facilities shall meet all health and genetic requirements of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303 Importation of domesticated elk -- Enforcement.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(1): A person may not import domesticated elk into the state for use in domesticated elk facilities without first obtaining:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(1)(a): an entry permit from the state veterinarian's office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(1)(b): a domesticated elk facility license from the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(2): 4-39-301 The entry permit shall include the following information and certificates:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(2)(a): a health certificate with an indication of the current health status;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(2)(b): 4-39-301 proof of genetic purity as required in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(2)(c): the name and address of the consignor and consignee;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(2)(d): proof that the elk are:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(2)(d)(i): tuberculosis free; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(2)(d)(ii): enrolled in a tuberculosis herd monitoring accreditation program administered by the United State Department of Agriculture or the Canadian Food Inspection Agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(2)(e): the origin of shipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(2)(f): the final destination;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(2)(g): the total number of animals in the shipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(2)(h): for an elk imported from east of the 100 degree meridian, proof that the elk has been dewormed in accordance with Subsection (3)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(2)(i): any other information required by the state veterinarian's office or the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(3): In addition to the requirements described in Subsections (1) and (2), a person importing a domesticated elk from east of the 100 degree meridian shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(3)(a): deworm the elk within 60 days before arrival in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(3)(b): deworm or harvest the elk no later than 150 days after arrival in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(3)(c): for a bull sent to an elk ranch:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(3)(c)(i): hold the bull for harvest until the bull has completed a slaughter withdrawal period; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(3)(c)(ii): be able to demonstrate that the elk is free from dewormer residue; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(3)(d): make the elk available to the department for monitoring and inspection upon request by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(4): The department may stop the importation of a domesticated elk or quarantine a domesticated elk if the department identifies the spread of meningeal worm in the elk or the elk's domesticated herd.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(5): A person who imports domesticated elk into the state from an international herd:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(5)(a): may only import domesticated elk:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(5)(a)(i): that are male; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(5)(a)(ii): to an elk ranch for use in the elk ranch; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(5)(b): shall ensure that the domesticated elk are harvested in the same season in which the domesticated elk enter the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-303(6): For the purpose of enforcing Subsection (5), the department may make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, for the use of radio frequency identification tags to track male elk imported into the state from an international herd.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-304 Marking domesticated elk.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-304(1): (2) Each domesticated elk shall be marked by either an official USDA tag or by an electronic identification tag, as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-304(1)(a): within 30 days of a change of ownership; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-304(1)(b): in the case of newborn calves, within 15 days after being weaned, but in any case, no later than January 31.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-304(2): If a domesticated elk is identified with an electronic identification tag, it shall be placed in the right ear.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-305 Transportation of domesticated elk to or from domesticated elk facilities.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-305(1): A person may transport domesticated elk without an official state brand certificate or other proof of ownership if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-305(1)(a): only moves domesticated elk accompanied by an intrastate transfer form provided by the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-305(1)(b): reports the move to the department within five days;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-305(1)(c): only moves domesticated elk from a licensed facility to another licensed facility owned by the same person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-305(1)(d): only moves domesticated elk intrastate.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-305(2): An official state brand inspection certificate shall accompany all domesticated elk sold or slaughtered.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-306 Inspection before movement, sale, or slaughter.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-306(1): Each domesticated elk facility licensee shall have the domesticated elk inspected by the department before sale or slaughter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-306(2): 4-39-305 Except as provided by Section


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-307 Inspections -- Qualifications of inspectors.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Health certification shall be based upon inspections carried out in accordance with standards specified by the department.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-401 Escape of domesticated elk -- Liability.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-401(1): The owner shall try to capture domesticated elk that escape.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-401(2): The escape of a domesticated elk shall be reported immediately to the domestic elk program manager, who shall notify the Division of Wildlife Resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-401(3): If the domesticated elk is not recovered within 72 hours of the escape, the department, in conjunction with the Division of Wildlife Resources, shall take whatever action is necessary to resolve the problem.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-401(4): The owner shall reimburse the state or a state agency for any reasonable recapture costs incurred in the recapture or destruction of an escaped domesticated elk.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-401(5): Title 23A, Wildlife Resources Act An escaped domesticated elk taken by a licensed hunter in a manner that complies with the provisions of
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-401(6): The owner shall be responsible for containing the domesticated elk to ensure that there is no spread of disease from domesticated elk to wild elk and that the genetic purity of wild elk is protected.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-402 Removal of wild cervids -- Liability.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-402(1): Upon discovery of a wild cervid in a domesticated elk facility, the licensee shall immediately notify the Division of Wildlife Resources, which shall remove the wild cervid.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-402(2): The state or a state agency is not liable for disease or genetic purity problems of domesticated elk that may be attributed to wild cervids.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-501 Enforcement and penalties.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-501(1): Any violation of this chapter is a class B misdemeanor and may be grounds for revocation of the license or denial of any future license as determined by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-501(2): A violation of any rule made under this chapter may be grounds for revocation of the license or denial for future licenses as determined by the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-502 Adjudicative proceedings.
--------------------------------------------------------
Adjudicative proceedings under this chapter shall be conducted in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503 Grounds for denial, suspension, or revocation of licenses for domestic elk facilities.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(1): 4-39-303 The department shall deny, suspend, or revoke a license to operate a domestic elk facility if the licensee or applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(1)(a): fails, for two consecutive years, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(1)(a)(i): meet inventory requirements as required by the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(1)(a)(ii): submit chronic wasting disease test samples for at least 90% of mortalities over 12 months old; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(1)(a)(iii): notify the department that there are wild cervids inside a domestic elk farm or elk ranch;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(1)(b): fails to present animals for identification at the request of the department or allow the department to have access to facility records; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(1)(c): 4-39-303 violates the import requirements described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2): The department may deny, revoke, or suspend a license to operate a domestic elk facility if, after delivery of notice and an opportunity to correct, the licensee or applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(a): provides:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(a)(i): an unfinished application or incorrect application information; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(a)(ii): incorrect records or fails to maintain required records;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(b): fails to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(b)(i): notify the department of movement of elk onto or off of the facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(b)(ii): identify elk as required;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(b)(iii): notify the department concerning an escape of an animal from a domestic elk facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(b)(iv): maintain a perimeter fence that prevents escape of domestic elk or ingress of wild cervids into the facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(b)(v): participate with the department in a cooperative wild cervid removal program;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(b)(vi): submit chronic wasting disease test samples for at least 90% of mortalities over 12 months old; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(b)(vii): have the minimum proper equipment necessary to safely and humanely handle animals in the facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(c): moves imported elk onto a facility without getting a Certificate of Veterinary Inspection that has an import permit number from the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(d): imports animals that are prohibited or controlled by the division; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-39-503(2)(e): handles animals in a manner that violates acceptable animal husbandry practices.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 41 - Hemp and Cannabinoid Act
*********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-101(1): This chapter is known as the "Hemp and Cannabinoid Act."
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-101(2): This part is known as "Industrial Hemp."


Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(1): "Adulterant" means any poisonous or deleterious substance in a quantity that may be injurious to human health, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(1)(a): pesticides;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(1)(b): heavy metals;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(1)(c): solvents;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(1)(d): microbial life;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(1)(e): artificially derived cannabinoids;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(1)(f): toxins; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(1)(g): foreign matter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(2)(a): "Artificially derived cannabinoid" means a chemical substance that is created by a chemical reaction that changes the molecular structure of any chemical substances derived from the cannabis plant.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(2)(b): "Artificially derived cannabinoid" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(2)(b)(i): a naturally occurring chemical substance that is separated from the cannabis plant by a chemical or mechanical extraction process; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(2)(b)(ii): cannabinoids that are produced by decarboxylation from a naturally occurring cannabinoid acid without the use of a chemical catalyst.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(3): "Cannabidiol" or "CBD" means the cannabinoid identified as CAS# 13956-29-1.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(4): "Cannabidiolic acid" or "CBDA" means the cannabinoid identified as CAS# 1244-58-2.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(5): "Cannabinoid processor license" means a license that the department issues to a person for the purpose of processing a cannabinoid product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(6): "Cannabinoid product" means a product that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(6)(a): contains or is represented to contain one or more naturally occurring cannabinoids;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(6)(b): contains less than the cannabinoid product THC level, by dry weight;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(6)(c): contains a combined amount of total THC and any THC analog that does not exceed 10% of the total cannabinoid content;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(6)(d): does not exceed a total of THC and any THC analog that is greater than:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(6)(d)(i): 5 milligrams per serving; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(6)(d)(ii): 150 milligrams per package; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(6)(e): unless the product is in an oil based suspension, has a serving size that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(6)(e)(i): is an integer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(6)(e)(ii): is a discrete unit of the cannabinoid product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(7): "Cannabinoid product class" means a group of cannabinoid products that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(7)(a): have all ingredients in common; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(7)(b): are produced by or for the same company.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(8): "Cannabinoid product THC level" means a combined concentration of total THC and any THC analog of less than 0.3% on a dry weight basis if laboratory testing confirms a result within a measurement of uncertainty that includes the combined concentration of 0.3%.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(9): 26B-4-201 "Cannabis" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(10): "Delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol" or "delta-9-THC" means the cannabinoid identified as CAS# 1972-08-3, the primary psychotropic cannabinoid in cannabis.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(11): "Industrial hemp" means any part of a cannabis plant, whether growing or not, with a concentration of less than 0.3% tetrahydrocannabinol by dry weight.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(12): "Industrial hemp producer registration" means a registration that the department issues to a person for the purpose of processing industrial hemp or an industrial hemp product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(13): "Industrial hemp retailer permit" means a permit that the department issues to a retailer who sells any viable industrial hemp seed or cannabinoid product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(14): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(14)(a): "Industrial hemp product" means a product made by processing industrial hemp plants or industrial hemp parts.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(14)(b): "Industrial hemp product" does not include cannabinoid material.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(15): "Key participant" means any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(15)(a): a licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(15)(b): an operation manager;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(15)(c): a site manager; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(15)(d): an employee who has access to any industrial hemp material with a THC concentration above 0.3%.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(16): "Licensee" means a person possessing a cannabinoid processor license that the department issues under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(17): "Non-compliant material" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(17)(a): a hemp plant that does not comply with this chapter, including a cannabis plant with a concentration of 0.3% tetrahydrocannabinol or greater by dry weight; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(17)(b): a cannabinoid product, chemical, or compound with a concentration that exceeds the cannabinoid product THC level.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(18): "Permittee" means a person possessing a permit that the department issues under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(19): "Person" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(19)(a): an individual, partnership, association, firm, trust, limited liability company, or corporation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(19)(b): an agent or employee of an individual, partnership, association, firm, trust, limited liability company, or corporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(20): "Retailer permittee" means a person possessing an industrial hemp retailer permit that the department issues under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(21): "Tetrahydrocannabinol" or "THC" means a delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol, the cannabinoid identified as CAS# 1972-08-3.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(22): 521-35-7
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(22)(a): "THC analog" means a substance that is structurally or pharmacologically substantially similar to, or is represented as being similar to, delta-9-THC.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(22)(b): 521-35-7 "THC analog" does not include the following substances or the naturally occurring acid forms of the following substances:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(22)(b)(i): cannabichromene (CBC), the cannabinoid identified as CAS# 20675-51-8;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(22)(b)(ii): cannabicyclol (CBL), the cannabinoid identified as CAS# 21366-63-2;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(22)(b)(iii): cannabidiol (CBD), the cannabinoid identified as CAS# 13956-29-1;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(22)(b)(iv): cannabidivarol (CBDV), the cannabinoid identified as CAS# 24274-48-4;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(22)(b)(v): cannabielsoin (CBE), the cannabinoid identified as CAS# 52025-76-0;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(22)(b)(vi): cannabigerol (CBG), the cannabinoid identified as CAS# 25654-31-3;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(22)(b)(vii): cannabigerovarin (CBGV), the cannabinoid identified as CAS# 55824-11-8;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(22)(b)(viii): 521-35-7 cannabinol (CBN), the cannabinoid identified as CAS#
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(22)(b)(ix): cannabivarin  (CBV), the cannabinoid identified as CAS# 33745-21-0; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(22)(b)(x): delta-9-tetrahydrocannabivarin (THCV), the cannabinoid identified as CAS# 31262-37-0.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(23): "Total cannabidiol" or "total CBD" means the combined amounts of cannabidiol and cannabidiolic acid, calculated as "total CBD = CBD + (CBDA x 0.877)".
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(24): "Total tetrahydrocannabinol" or "total THC" means the sum of the determined amounts of delta-9-THC, tertrahydrocannabinolic acid, calculated as "total THC = delta-9-THC + (THCA x 0.877)".
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(25): "Transportable industrial hemp concentrate" means any amount of a natural cannabinoid in a purified state that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(25)(a): is the product of any chemical or physical process applied to naturally occurring biomass that concentrates or isolates the cannabinoids contained in the biomass;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(25)(b): is derived from a cannabis plant that, based on sampling that was collected no more than 30 days before the day on which the cannabis plant was harvested, contains a combined concentration of total THC and any THC analog of less than 0.3% on a dry weight basis;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(25)(c): has a THC and THC analog concentration total that is less than 20% when concentrated from the cannabis plant to the purified state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-102(25)(d): is intended to be processed into a cannabinoid product.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1 Authority to regulate production, sale, and testing of cannabinoid products and industrial hemp -- Information sharing with the State Tax Commission.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(1): The department shall make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(1)(a): establish requirements for a cannabinoid processor license to process cannabinoid products;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(1)(b): establish requirements for an industrial hemp retailer permit to market or sell industrial hemp products;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(1)(c): establish the standards, methods, practices, and procedures a laboratory must use when:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(1)(c)(i): testing industrial hemp, transportable industrial hemp concentrate, and cannabinoid products; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(1)(c)(ii): disposing of non-compliant material;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(1)(d): establish requirements for registration of processors of non-cannabinoid industrial hemp products; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(1)(e): establish standards for transporting transportable industrial hemp concentrate into and out of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(2): The department shall maintain a list of each licensee and permittee.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(3): Beginning January 1, 2025, the department shall provide to the State Tax Commission:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(3)(a): a regularly updated list of every retailer permittee that sells a cannabinoid product;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(3)(b): any information obtained by the department regarding a person who is not a retailer permittee and is selling a cannabinoid product; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(3)(c): the tax identification number:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(3)(c)(i): for a retailer permittee described in Subsection (3)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.1(3)(c)(ii): a person described in Subsection (3)(b).

---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.2(1): The department or a licensee of the department may process a cannabinoid product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.2(2): A person seeking a cannabinoid processor license shall provide to the department:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.2(2)(a): the legal description and global positioning coordinates sufficient for locating the facility the person uses to process industrial hemp; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.2(2)(b): written consent allowing a representative of the department and local law enforcement to enter all premises where the person processes or stores industrial hemp for the purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.2(2)(b)(i): conducting a physical inspection; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.2(2)(b)(ii): ensuring compliance with the requirements of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.2(3): An individual who has been convicted of a drug-related felony within the last 10 years is not eligible to obtain a cannabinoid processor license.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.5 Industrial hemp producer registration -- Limitation on industrial hemp product use.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.5(1): A person may produce an industrial hemp product if the person has registered with the department as an industrial hemp producer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.5(2): (1) A person seeking to register under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.5(2)(c)(i): conducting a physical inspection; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.5(2)(c)(ii): ensuring compliance with the requirements of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-103.5(3): An industrial hemp product or byproduct may not be used for production of a cannabinoid product.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-104(1): A cannabinoid product class or cannabinoid product that is not registered with the department may not be distributed in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-104(2): 4-2-103(2) A person seeking registration for a cannabinoid product class or cannabinoid product shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-104(2)(a): apply to the department on forms provided by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-104(2)(b): 4-2-103(2) submit an annual registration fee, determined by the department pursuant to Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-104(4): (2) Upon receipt by the department of a proper application and payment of the appropriate fee, as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-104(5): The department shall mail, either through the postal service or electronically, forms for the renewal of a registration to a registrant at least 30 days before the day on which the registrant's registration expires.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-104 Product registration required for distribution -- Application -- Fees -- Renewal.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-104(1): A cannabinoid product class or cannabinoid product that is not registered with the department may not be distributed in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-104(2): A person seeking registration for a cannabinoid product class or cannabinoid product shallapply to the department on forms provided by the departmentfor a registration for each cannabinoid product class or cannabinoid product the person intends to distribute in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-104(3): The department may conduct tests, or require test results, to ensure that any claim made by an applicant about a cannabinoid product class or cannabinoid product is accurate.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-104(4): Upon receipt by the department of a proper application, as described in Subsection (2), the department shall issue a registration to the applicant allowing the applicant to distribute the registered cannabinoid product class or cannabinoid product in the state for one year from the date on which the application is approved, subject to suspension or revocation for cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-104(5): The department shall mail, either through the postal service or electronically, forms for the renewal of a registration to a registrant at least 30 days before the day on which the registrant's registration expires.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105 Unlawful acts.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(1): It is unlawful for a person to handle, process, or market living industrial hemp plants, viable hemp seeds, leaf materials, or floral materials derived from industrial hemp without the appropriate license or permit issued by the department under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2): 4-41-104; 4-41-403; 4-41-403; 4-41-103.1
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(a): 4-41-104; 4-41-403; 4-41-403 It is unlawful for any person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(a)(i): 4-41-104 distribute, sell, or market a cannabinoid product that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(a)(i)(A): 4-41-104 not registered with the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(a)(i)(B): noncompliant material;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(a)(ii): except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), transport into or out of the state extracted material or final product that contains 0.3% or more of total THC and any THC analog;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(a)(iii): 4-41-403; 4-41-403 sell or use a cannabinoid product that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(a)(iii)(A): 4-41-403 added to a conventional food or beverage, as the department further defines in rules described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(a)(iii)(B): 4-41-403 marketed or manufactured to be enticing to children, as further defined in rules described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(a)(iii)(C): smokable flower; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(a)(iv): knowingly or intentionally sell or give a cannabinoid product that contains THC or a THC analog in the course of business to an individual who is not at least 21 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(b): 4-41-103.1 A person may transport transportable industrial hemp concentrate if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(b)(i): 4-41-103.1 complies with rules created by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(b)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(b)(ii)(A): has an industrial hemp producer registration; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(2)(b)(ii)(B): the equivalent to an industrial hemp producer registration from another state.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(3): The department may seize and destroy non-compliant material.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-105(4): Nothing in this chapter authorizes any person to violate federal law, regulation, or any provision of this title.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106 Enforcement -- Fine -- Citation.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(1): 4-2-304 If a person violates this part, the department may:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(1)(a): revoke the person's license or permit;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(1)(b): decline to renew the person's license or permit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(1)(c): 4-2-304 assess the person a civil penalty that the department establishes in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(2): Except for a fine that the department assesses for an unlicensed processor, an unregistered product, or the sale of a cannabinoid product to an individual younger than 21 years old, the department shall deposit a penalty imposed under this section into the General Fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(3): The department may take an action described in Subsection (4) if the department concludes, upon investigation, that a person has violated this chapter, a rule made under this chapter, or an order issued under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(4): If the department makes the conclusion described in Subsection (3), the department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(4)(a): issue the person a written administrative citation;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(4)(b): attempt to negotiate a stipulated settlement;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(4)(c): seize, embargo, or destroy the industrial hemp batch or unregistered product;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(4)(d): order the person to cease the violation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(4)(e): if a stipulated settlement cannot be reached, conduct an adjudicative proceeding under Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(5): The department may, for a person, other than an individual, that is subject to an uncontested citation, a stipulated settlement, or a finding of a violation in an adjudicative proceeding under this section, for a fine amount not already specified in law, assess the person a fine of up to $5,000 per violation, in accordance with a fine schedule that the department establishes by rule in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(6): The department may not revoke a cannabinoid processor license or an industrial hemp retailer's permit without first giving the person the opportunity to appear before an adjudicative proceeding conducted under Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(7): If, within 30 calendar days after the day on which a department serves a citation for a violation of this chapter, the person that is the subject of the citation fails to request a hearing to contest the citation, the citation becomes the department's final order.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(8): The department may, for a person who fails to comply with a citation under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(8)(a): refuse to issue or renew the person's processor license or retailer permit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-106(8)(b): suspend, revoke, or place on probation the person's processor license or retailer permit.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-401 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as "Cannabinoid Product Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-402 Cannabinoid sales and use authorized.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-402(1): The sale or use of a cannabinoid product is prohibited:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-402(1)(a): except as provided in this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-402(1)(b): unless the United States Food and Drug Administration approves the product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-402(2): 4-41-403 The department shall keep a list of registered cannabinoid products that the department has determined, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-402(3): (2); (2); Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-402(3)(a): (2) A person may sell or use a cannabinoid product that is in the list of registered cannabinoid products described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-402(3)(b): (2); Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act An individual may use cannabidiol or a cannabidiol product that is not in the list of registered cannabinoid products described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-402(3)(b)(i): the individual purchased the product outside the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-402(3)(b)(ii): Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act the product's contents do not violate
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-402(4): 26B-4-201 Any marketing for a cannabinoid product shall include a notice to consumers that the product is hemp or CBD and is not cannabis or medical cannabis, as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-402(5): A cannabinoid product that is designed to be inhaled shall include a warning on the label regarding the possible health effects of inhaling cannabinoid products.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403 Standards for registration.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (1)(a); (1)(a)(iv); (v)
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The department shall make rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(i): to determine standards for a registered cannabinoid product, including standards for:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(i)(A): testing to ensure the product is safe for human consumption; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(i)(B): accurate labeling;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(ii): governing an entity that manufactures cannabinoid products, including standards for health and safety;

Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(iv)(B): a product that is marketed or manufactured to be enticing to children; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(v): regarding any other issue the department considers necessary for the safe production and sale of cannabinoid products.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403 Standards for registration.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a): The department shall make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(i): to determine standards for a registered cannabinoid product, including standards for:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(i)(A): testing to ensure the product is safe for human consumption; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(i)(B): accurate labeling;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(ii): governing an entity that manufactures cannabinoid products, including standards for health and safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(iii): to determine when and how a cannabinoid processor's cannabinoid must be tested by the department at the expense of the cannabinoid processor;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(iv): regarding what constitutes:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(iv)(A): a conventional food or beverage; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(iv)(B): a product that is marketed or manufactured to be enticing to children;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(v): regarding any other issue the department considers necessary for the safe production and sale of cannabinoid products; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(a)(vi): for a cannabinoid product that is not in an oil based suspension, prohibiting a serving size that is less than the full portion of a discrete unit of the cannabinoid product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(1)(b): Notwithstanding Subsection (1)(a), the department may not prohibit a sugar coating on a cannabinoid product to mask the product's taste, subject to the limitations described in Subsection (1)(a)(iv) or (v).
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(2): 26B-1-102 In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the department may make rules to immediately ban or limit the presence of any substance in a cannabinoid product after receiving a recommendation to do so from a public health authority as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41-403(3): The department shall set a fine of not more than $5,000 for a person who sells a cannabinoid product that is not registered by the department.
