Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206 Closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(1): 63J-1-504
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(1)(a): Subject to Subsections (1)(b) and (c), a home delivery medical cannabis pharmacy may open a single closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(1)(b): A home delivery medical cannabis pharmacy may not open a closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy unless the home delivery medical cannabis pharmacy:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(1)(b)(i): has an operating plan that includes a closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(1)(b)(ii): obtains a license issued by the department for a closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(1)(c): An entity that owns multiple home delivery medical cannabis pharmacies may open only one closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(1)(d): 63J-1-504 The department may institute a fee in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(2): A home delivery medical cannabis pharmacy that opens a closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy under Subsection (1) shall ensure:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(2)(a): that a pharmacy medical provider who is a licensed pharmacist:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(2)(a)(i): is directly supervising the packaging of an order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(2)(a)(ii): is present in the closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy when an order is packaged for delivery; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(2)(b): all record keeping requirements, labeling requirements, and patient counseling requirements described in this chapter and Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis, are satisfied before sending out an order.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(3): An individual who prepares an order at a closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy under this section shall be registered as:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(3)(a): a pharmacy medical provider; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(3)(b): a medical cannabis pharmacy agent.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4)(a): A closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy shall operate:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4)(a)(i): except as provided in Subsection (4)(b), in a facility that is accessible only by an individual who is a pharmacy medical provider or a medical cannabis pharmacy agent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4)(a)(ii): at a physical address in accordance with Subsection (6).
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4)(b): A closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy may authorize an individual who is at least 18 years old and is not a pharmacy medical provider or a cannabis pharmacy agent to access the closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy if the closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4)(b)(i): tracks and monitors the individual at all times while the individual is at the closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4)(b)(ii): maintains a record of the individual's access, including arrival and departure.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4)(c): A closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy shall operate in a facility that has:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4)(c)(i): a single, secure public entrance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4)(c)(ii): a security system with a backup power source that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4)(c)(ii)(A): detects and records entry into the closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4)(c)(ii)(B): provides notice of an unauthorized entry to law enforcement when the closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy is closed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4)(c)(ii)(C): a lock or equivalent restrictive security feature on any area where the closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy stores a cannabis product.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(4)(d): A closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy shall ensure that any cannabis or cannabis products in the closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy that are intended for home delivery are separated in a manner that is readily distinguishable from any other cannabis or cannabis product in the facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(5): A closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy may only provide cannabis or a cannabis product to an individual through a delivery that complies with this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(6)(a): A person may not locate a closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(6)(a)(i): within 1,000 feet of a community location; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(6)(a)(ii): in or within 600 feet of a district that the relevant municipality or county has zoned as primarily residential.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(6)(b): The proximity requirements described in Subsection (6)(a) shall be measured from the nearest entrance to the closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy by following the shortest route of ordinary pedestrian travel to the property boundary of the community location or residential area.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(6)(c): The licensing board may grant a waiver to reduce the proximity requirements in Subsection (6)(a) by up to 20% if the licensing board determines that it is not reasonably feasible for the applicant to site the proposed closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy without the waiver.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(6)(d): An applicant for a license under this section shall provide evidence of compliance with the proximity requirements described in Subsection (6)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(7): 17-50-501 When determining where a closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy may open, the licensing board:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(7)(a): shall utilize geographic regions created by the department through rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(7)(b): shall prioritize allowing entities that do not have a medical cannabis pharmacy in a region to open a closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy in the region;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(7)(c): 17-50-501 of the total amount of closed-door medical cannabis pharmacies, may allow only three closed-door medical cannabis pharmacies to operate in counties of the first and second class as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(7)(d): for determining the three closed-door medical cannabis pharmacies described in Subsection (7)(c), consider the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(7)(d)(i): the history of compliance with state law and rules for all licenses issued under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(7)(d)(ii): the medical cannabis pharmacy's willingness to offer a variety of brands and products;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(7)(d)(iii): the ability of the operating plan to ensure the safety and security of the community;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(7)(d)(iv): the suitability of the proposed location and the location's ability to serve the local community; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(7)(d)(v): any other relevant information determined through rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(8): A closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy may not account for more than:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(8)(a): for an entity that holds a single medical cannabis pharmacy license, the greater of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(8)(a)(i): 35% of the medical cannabis pharmacy's total revenue; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(8)(a)(ii): $2,000,000 in total revenue; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(8)(b): for an entity that holds more than one medical cannabis pharmacy license, the greater of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(8)(b)(i): 35% of the total revenue of the entity's medical cannabis pharmacy that generates the most revenue; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(8)(b)(ii): $2,000,000 in total revenue.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(9): Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the department may issue only three closed-door medical cannabis pharmacy licenses before July 1, 2027.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-41a-1206(10): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the department shall make rules to implement this section.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 44 - Agricultural Operations Nuisances Act
**********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Agricultural Operations Nuisances Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(1): 78B-4-512
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(1)(a): "Agricultural operation" means the commercial production of crops, orchards, livestock, poultry, aquaculture, livestock products, or poultry products.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(1)(b): 78B-4-512 "Agricultural operation" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(1)(b)(i): the real property where the commercial production described in Subsection (1)(a) occurs;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(1)(b)(ii): a facility, a property, or equipment used to facilitate the commercial production described in Subsection (1)(a);
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(1)(b)(iii): 78B-4-512 an agritourism activity, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(1)(b)(iv): an agricultural protection area established under Title 17, Chapter 41, Agriculture, Industrial, or Critical Infrastructure Materials Protection Areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(2): "Fundamental change to the operation" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(2)(a): a change in ownership or size;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(2)(b): an interruption of farming for a period of no more than three years;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(2)(c): participation in a government-sponsored agricultural program;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(2)(d): employment of new technology; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(2)(e): a change in the type of agricultural product produced.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-102(3): "Nuisance" means anything that is injurious to health, indecent, offensive to the senses, or an obstruction to the free use of property, so as to interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-201 Defenses in nuisance actions.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-201(1): It is a defense in a civil action for nuisance against an agricultural operation that:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-201(1)(a): the plaintiff is not a legal possessor of the real property affected by the conditions alleged to be the nuisance;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-201(1)(b): the real property affected by the conditions alleged to be the nuisance is located outside one-half mile of the source of the activity or structure alleged to be the nuisance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-201(1)(c): the action is filed more than one year after:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-201(1)(c)(i): the establishment of the agricultural operation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-201(1)(c)(ii): the agricultural operation undergoes a fundamental change.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-201(2): This section may not be construed to invalidate any contract made before May 14, 2019.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-201(3): In a nuisance action against an agricultural operation, the court shall award costs and expenses, including reasonable attorney fees, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-201(3)(a): the agricultural operation when the court finds the agricultural operation is not a nuisance and the nuisance action is frivolous or malicious; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-201(3)(b): the plaintiff when the court finds the agricultural operation is a nuisance and the agricultural operation asserts an affirmative defense in the nuisance action that is frivolous and malicious.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-201(4): A person who knowingly violates a judgment or order abating or otherwise enjoining a nuisance is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-202 Application of other statutes -- Ordinances.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-202(1): 76-10-803
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-202(1)(a): 76-10-803 In a civil action for nuisance or a criminal action for public nuisance under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-202(1)(b): Agricultural operations undertaken in conformity with federal, state, and local laws and regulations, including zoning ordinances, are presumed to be operating within sound agricultural practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-202(2): 17-41-101; 17-41-403 If the agricultural operations occur in an agricultural protection area, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-202(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-202(3)(a): An ordinance of a political subdivision that would make the operation of an agricultural operation or appurtenances to an agricultural operation a nuisance or that provide for abatement of the agricultural operation as a nuisance does not apply to an agricultural operation that is conducted in the normal and ordinary course of agricultural operations or conducted in accordance with sound agricultural practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-44-202(3)(b): An agricultural operation undertaken in conformity with federal, state, and local laws and regulations, including zoning ordinances, are presumed to be operating within sound agricultural practices.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 4 - Chapter 45 - Kratom Consumer Protection Act
***************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 4-45-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Kratom Consumer Protection Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 4-45-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 4-45-102(1): "Commissioner" means the commissioner of the department.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-45-102(3)(c): a food supplement for special dietary use that is necessitated because of a physical, physiological, pathological, or other condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-45-102(4): "Kratom processor" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-45-102(4)(a): sells, prepares, or maintains a kratom product; or

Utah Code Annotated § 4-45-102(5): "Kratom product" mean food containing any part of a leaf of the plant Mitragyna speciosa.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-102(10)(b)(i): enhance the natural, scenic, or aesthetic qualities of the land; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-102(10)(b)(ii): facilitate the public's access to or use of the land for the enjoyment of the land's natural, scenic, or aesthetic qualities and for compatible recreational activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-102(10)(c): "Open land" does not include land whose predominant use is as a developed facility for active recreational activities, including baseball, tennis, soccer, golf, or other sporting or similar activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-102(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-102(11)(a): "State conservation efforts" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-102(11)(a)(i): efforts to optimize and preserve the uses of land for the benefit of the state's agricultural industry and natural resources; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-102(11)(a)(ii): conservation of working landscapes that if conserved, preserves the state's agricultural industry and natural resources, such as working agricultural land.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-102(11)(b): "State conservation efforts" does not include the purpose of opening private property to public access without the consent of the owner of the private property.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-102(12): Title 17, Chapter 41, Agriculture, Industrial, or Critical Infrastructure Materials Protection Areas
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-102(12)(a): "Working agricultural land" means agricultural land for which an owner or producer engages in the activity of producing for commercial purposes crops, orchards, livestock, poultry, aquaculture, livestock products, or poultry products and the facilities, equipment, and property used to facilitate the activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-102(12)(b): Title 17, Chapter 41, Agriculture, Industrial, or Critical Infrastructure Materials Protection Areas "Working agricultural land" includes an agricultural protection area established under


Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-103 Application of chapter to wildlife issues.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter may not be construed or applied to supersede or interfere with the powers and duties of the Division of Wildlife Resources or the Wildlife Board underUtah Code Annotated § 4-46-103(1): conservation and management of protected wildlife within the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-103(2): a program or initiative to restore and conserve habitat for fish and wildlife; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-103(3): acquisition, ownership, management, and control of real property or a real property interest, including a leasehold estate, an easement, a right-of-way, or a conservation easement.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-201 Land Conservation Board.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-201(1): Title 17D, Chapter 3, Conservation District Act There is created a Land Conservation Board consisting of:

Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-201(1)(e): Title 17D, Chapter 3, Conservation District Act seven persons from the profit and nonprofit private sector:

Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-201(1)(e)(vii): one representative of land trusts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-201(1)(e)(viii): Title 17D, Chapter 3, Conservation District Act one representative of an association representing conservation districts created under

Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-202 Board duties and powers -- No regulatory authority -- Criteria.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-202(1): The board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-202(1)(a): administer the fund as provided in this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-202(1)(b): fulfill other responsibilities imposed on the board by the Legislature.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-202(2): The board may not exercise any regulatory authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-202(3): In carrying out the board's powers and duties under this chapter, the board shall adopt ranking criteria that is substantially similar to the ranking criteria used by the Agriculture Conservation Easement Program and Agriculture Land Easement as determined by the Natural Resources Conservation Service under the United States Department of Agriculture.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-301 LeRay McAllister Working Farm and Ranch Fund.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-301(1): There is created a restricted account within the General Fund entitled the " LeRay McAllister Working Farm and Ranch Fund."
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-301(2): The LeRay McAllister Working Farm and Ranch Fund shall consist of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-301(2)(a): appropriations by the Legislature;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-301(2)(b): grants from federal or private sources; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-301(2)(c): interest and earnings from the account.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-301(3): 4-46-201; 4-46-302 The Land Conservation Board created in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302 Use of money in fund -- Criteria -- Administration.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(1): 79-2-201 Subject to Subsection (2), the board may authorize the use of money in the fund, by grant, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(1)(a): a local entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(1)(b): 79-2-201 the Department of Natural Resources created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(1)(c): an entity within the department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(1)(d): a charitable organization that qualifies as being tax exempt under Section 501(c)(3), Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(a): The money in the fund shall be used for preserving or restoring open land and agricultural land.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(b): Except as provided in Subsection (2)(c), money from the fund:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(b)(i): may be used to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(b)(i)(A): establish a conservation easement under Title 57, Chapter 18, Land Conservation Easement Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(b)(i)(B): fund similar methods to preserve open land or agricultural land; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(b)(ii): may not be used topurchase a fee interest in real property to preserve open land or agricultural land.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(c): Money from the fund may be used to purchase a fee interest in real property to preserve open land or agricultural land if:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(c)(i): the property to be purchased is no more than 20 acres in size; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(c)(ii): with respect to a parcel purchased in a county in which over 50% of the land area is publicly owned, real property roughly equivalent in size and located within that county is contemporaneously transferred to private ownership from the governmental entity that purchased the fee interest in real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(d): Eminent domain may not be used or threatened in connection with any purchase using money from the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(e): A parcel of land larger than 20 acres in size may not be divided to create one or more parcels that are smaller than 20 acres in order to comply with Subsection (2)(c)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(f): A local entity, department, or organization under Subsection (1) may not receive money from the fund unless the local entity, department, or organization provides matching funds equal to or greater than the amount of money received from the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(g): In granting money from the fund, the board may impose conditions on the recipient as to how the money is to be spent.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(h): The board shall give priority to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(h)(i): working agricultural land; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(h)(ii): after giving priority to working agricultural land under Subsection (2)(h)(i), requests from the Department of Natural Resources for up to 20% of each annual increase in the amount of money in the fund if the money is used for the protection of wildlife or watershed.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(i)(i): The board may not make a grant from the fund that exceeds $1,000,000 until after making a report to the Legislative Management Committee about the grant.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(2)(i)(ii): The Legislative Management Committee may make a recommendation to the board concerning the intended grant, but the recommendation is not binding on the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(3): In determining the amount and type of financial assistance to provide a local entity, department, or organization under Subsection (1) and subject to Subsection (2)(i), the board shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(3)(a): the nature and amount of open land and agricultural land proposed to be preserved or restored;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(3)(b): the qualities of the open land and agricultural land proposed to be preserved or restored;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(3)(c): the cost effectiveness of the project to preserve or restore open land or agricultural land;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(3)(d): the funds available;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(3)(e): the number of actual and potential applications for financial assistance and the amount of money sought by those applications;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(3)(f): the open land preservation plan of the local entity where the project is located and the priority placed on the project by that local entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(3)(g): the effects on housing affordability and diversity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(3)(h): whether the project protects against the loss of private property ownership.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(4): If a local entity, department, or organization under Subsection (1) seeks money from the fund for a project whose purpose is to protect critical watershed, the board shall require that the needs and quality of that project be verified by the state engineer.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(5): An interest in real property purchased with money from the fund shall be held and administered by the state or a local entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(6)(a): The board may not authorize the use of money under this section for a project unless the land use authority for the land in which the project is located consents to the project.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(6)(b): To obtain consent to a project, the person who is seeking money from the fund shall submit a request for consent to a project with the applicable land use authority. The land use authority may grant or deny consent. If the land use authority does not take action within 60 days from the day on which the request for consent is filed with the land use authority under this Subsection (6), the board shall treat the project as having the consent of the land use authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(6)(c): An action of a land use authority under this Subsection (6) is not a land use decision subject to:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(6)(c)(i): Title 10, Chapter 9a, Municipal Land Use, Development, and Management Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-302(6)(c)(ii): Title 17, Chapter 27a, County Land Use, Development, and Management Act.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-303 Board to report annually.
--------------------------------------------------------
The board shall submit an annual report to the Infrastructure and General Government and Natural Resources, Agriculture, and Environmental Quality Appropriations Subcommittees:Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-303(1): specifying the amount of each disbursement from the fund;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-303(2): identifying the recipient of each disbursement and describing the project for which money was disbursed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-303(3): detailing the conditions, if any, placed by the board on disbursements from the fund.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-304 Agriculture Conservation Easement Account.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-304(1): There is created within the General Fund a restricted account known as the Agriculture Conservation Easement Account.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-304(2): 4-46-201 The Agriculture Conservation Easement Account consists of:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-304(2)(a): conservation easement stewardship fees;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-304(2)(b): grants from private foundations;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-304(2)(c): grants from local governments, the state, or the federal government;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-304(2)(d): 4-46-201 grants from the Land Conservation Board created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-304(2)(e): donations from landowners for monitoring and enforcing compliance with conservation easements;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-304(2)(f): donations from any other person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-304(2)(g): interest on account money.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-304(3): Upon appropriation by the Legislature, the department shall use money from the account to monitor and enforce compliance with conservation easements held by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-304(4): The department may not receive or expend donations from the account to acquire conservation easements.


Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-401 Division of Conservation created -- Director.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-401(1): Within the department there is created the Division of Conservation.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-401(2)(a): The director is the executive and administrative head of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-401(2)(b): The director shall administer this part subject to the administration and general supervision of the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-401(3): 4-46-201; 4-46-402; 23A-3-204; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 4-46-403 The division shall coordinate state conservation efforts by:
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-401(3)(a): 4-46-201 staffing the board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-401(3)(b): 4-46-402 coordinating with a conservation district in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-401(3)(c): coordinating with an agency or division within the department, the Department of Natural Resources, other state agencies, counties, cities, towns, local land trust entities, and federal agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-401(3)(d): facilitating obtaining federal funds in addition to state funds used for state conservation efforts;
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-401(3)(e): 23A-3-204 monitoring and providing for the management of conservation easements on state lands, including coordination with the Division of Wildlife Resources in the Division of Wildlife Resources' administration of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-401(3)(f): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 4-46-403 implementing rules made by the department in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-401(4): The division may cooperate with, or enter into agreements with, other agencies of this state and federal agencies in the administration and enforcement of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-402(1)(a): funding state conservation efforts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-402(1)(b): coordinating state conservation efforts.
Utah Code Annotated § 4-46-402(2): The division shall work with the conservation commission in coordinating with a conservation district.
